{{MedalCountry|{{fb|ESP}}}} {{MedalCompetition|[[UEFA European U-19 Championship]]}} {{Medal|W|[[2012 UEFA European U-19 Championship|2012 Estonia]]|}} }} '''Kepa Arrizabalaga Revuelta''' ({{IPA-eu|kepa aris̻aβalaɣa reβuelta|lang}}; {{IPA-es|ˈkepa ariθaβaˈlaɣa reˈβwelta|lang}}; born 3 October 1994) is a Spanish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] and the [[Spain national football team|Spain national team]]. He is sometimes referred to mononomously by his forename.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sefutbol.com/en/convocados/kepa-arrizabalaga|title=Kepa Arrizabalaga|publisher=[[Royal Spanish Football Federation]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190226000752/http://www.sefutbol.com/en/convocados/kepa-arrizabalaga|archive-date=26 February 2019|dead-url=no|accessdate=15 November 2017}}</ref>
Developed at [[Athletic Bilbao]], he played his first professional games on loan at [[SD Ponferradina|Ponferradina]] and [[Real Valladolid]], in [[Segunda División]]. He then returned to his first club, going on to appear in 54 matches across all competitions; in 2018, he signed with Chelsea.
Arrizabalaga won the [[2012 UEFA European Under-19 Championship|2012 European Championship]] with [[Spain national under-19 football team|Spain's under-19 team]] and made his [[Spain national football team|senior]] debut in 2017, being selected for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 World Cup]].
==Club career== ===Athletic Bilbao=== Born in [[Ondarroa]], [[Biscay]], Basque Country, Arrizabalaga joined [[Athletic Bilbao]]'s youth setup at [[Lezama Facilities|Lezama]] in 2004, aged ten. He made his senior debut with [[CD Basconia|the farm team]] in January 2012, in [[Tercera División]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.europapress.es/deportes/futbol-00162/noticia-chelsea-ficha-kepa-portero-mas-caro-historia-20180808231338.html|title=El Chelsea ficha a Kepa, el portero más caro de la historia|trans-title=Chelsea sign Kepa, most expensive goalkeeper in history|publisher=[[Europa Press (news agency)|Europa Press]]|language=es|date=8 August 2018|accessdate=9 January 2019}}</ref>
On 5 May 2012, Arrizabalaga was called up to the main squad for a [[La Liga]] match against [[Getafe CF]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.athletic-club.net/web/main.asp?a=0&b=1&c=2&d=1000&berria=12069&idi=2|title=Athletic Club-Getafe: Line-ups|publisher=Athletic Bilbao|date=5 May 2012|accessdate=11 December 2014}}</ref> but remained unused in the 0–0 draw at the [[San Mamés Stadium (1913)|San Mamés Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/marcador/futbol/2011_12/primera/jornada_37/ath_get/|title=Sin argumentos en la Catedral|trans-title=No arguments at the Cathedral|newspaper=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|first=Álvaro|last=Sánchez|language=es|date=5 May 2012|accessdate=11 December 2014}}</ref> He was also called up to pre-season in July, and on 23 September was also a [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] in another home game of the same outcome, against [[Málaga CF]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/eventos/marcador/futbol/2012_13/primera/jornada_5/ath_mga/|title=Europa les pesa|trans-title=Europe weighs on them|newspaper=Marca|location=Madrid|first=Ángel|last=Liceras|language=es|date=23 September 2012|accessdate=11 December 2014}}</ref>
Arrizabalaga was promoted to [[Bilbao Athletic|the reserves]] in January 2013, to cover for injured [[Jon Ander Serantes]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bizkaia.eldesmarque.com/athletic-club/33979-en-lezama-apuestan-fuerte-por-kepa-arrizabalaba|title=En Lezama apuestan fuerte por Kepa Arrizabalaga|trans-title=Lezama bets high on Kepa Arrizabalaga|publisher=El Desmarque|language=es|date=9 January 2013|accessdate=11 December 2014}}</ref> He made his debut for the B-side on 16 February 2013, keeping a [[Shutout|clean sheet]] in a 1–0 win over [[UD Logroñés]] for the [[Segunda División B]] championship.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uniondeportivalogroñes.com/index.php/8-destacados/131-bilbao-athletic-1-0-union-deportiva-logrones|title=Bilbao Athletic 1–0 Unión Deportiva Logroñés|publisher=UD Logroñés|language=es|date=16 February 2013|accessdate=11 December 2014}}</ref> On 3 March, he was [[Ejection (sports)|sent off]] towards the end of a 3–1 home win over [[SD Amorebieta]], as was teammate [[Jon García Herrero|Jon García]];<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bizkaia.eldesmarque.com/athletic-club/noticias/34732-el-bilbao-athletic-amenaza-el-liderato-del-alaves|title=El Bilbao Athletic amenaza el liderato del Alavés|trans-title=Bilbao Athletic threaten Alavés' lead|publisher=El Desmarque|language=es|date=4 March 2013|accessdate=29 November 2015}}</ref> in April he suffered a [[Athletic pubalgia|pubalgia]], only returning to the fields in September.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bizkaia.eldesmarque.com/athletic-club/37480-Kepa-Arrizabalaga-reaparece-casi-seis-meses-despu%C3%A9s-en-el-Bilbao-Athletic|title=Kepa Arrizabalaga reaparece casi seis meses después en el Bilbao Athletic|trans-title=Kepa Arrizabalaga reappears after nearly six months in Bilbao Athletic|publisher=El Desmarque|first=Javi|last=Beltrán|language=es|date=29 September 2013|accessdate=11 December 2014}}</ref>
Arrizabalaga appeared regularly for the B's after his return, but broke the first [[metacarpal]] of his right hand in January 2014,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.athletic-club.net/web/main.asp?a=0&b=1&c=2&d=1000&berria=13915&idi=2|title=Kepa Arrizabalaga's injury|publisher=Athletic Bilbao|date=22 January 2014|accessdate=11 December 2014}}</ref> being sidelined for a month. On 11 March, Getafe submitted a loan request to the ''Lions'' for him, as a replacement to injured [[Miguel Ángel Moyá]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aupaathletic.com/noticias/noticias-ver.asp?id=11023|title=El Getafe pide la cesión de Kepa Arrizabalaga|trans-title=Getafe ask for Kepa Arrizabalaga's loan|publisher=Aupa Athletic|language=es|date=11 March 2014|accessdate=11 December 2014}}</ref> but it was rejected a day later.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://athletic.elcorreo.com/noticias/2014-03-12/athletic-rechaza-ceder-hasta-20140312.html|title=El Athletic rechaza ceder hasta final de Liga al portero Kepa al Getafe|trans-title=Athletic reject loaning goalkeeper Kepa to Getafe until the end of the League|newspaper=[[El Correo]]|first=Javier|last=Ortiz de Lazcano|language=es|date=12 March 2014|accessdate=11 December 2014}}</ref>
On 5 January 2015, Arrizabalaga was loaned to [[Segunda División]]'s [[SD Ponferradina]] until June.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sdponferradina.com/-/mi|title=Kepa Arrizabalaga se incorpora a la Ponferradina|trans-title=Kepa Arrizabalaga added to Ponferradina|publisher=SD Ponferradina|language=es|date=5 January 2015|accessdate=5 January 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150109172714/http://www.sdponferradina.com/-/mi|archivedate=9 January 2015|df=}}</ref> He made his professional debut on the 11th, starting in a 1–1 home draw against [[Racing de Santander]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2015/01/11/futbol/2adivision/1421014655.html|title=El Racing encontró justo premio a su trabajo en el último minuto|trans-title=Racing's work paid off in the last minute|newspaper=Marca|location=Madrid|language=es|date=11 January 2015|accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref>
On 20 July 2015, Arrizabalaga moved to [[Real Valladolid]] also in the second tier, in a [[2015–16 Segunda División|season]]-long loan deal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.realvalladolid.es/noticias/actualidad/20072015/Kepa-cierra-la-porteria-del-Pucela/|title=Kepa cierra la portería del Pucela|trans-title=Kepa shuts down goal of Pucela|publisher=Real Valladolid|language=es|date=20 July 2015|accessdate=20 July 2015}}</ref> He played his first competitive game on 22 August, in a 0–1 loss at [[Córdoba CF]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/2015/08/23/futbol/equipos/cordoba/1440284201.html|title=Fidel resuelve en un gran partido del Córdoba|trans-title=Fidel the decider in a great Córdoba match|newspaper=Marca|location=Madrid|first=Alberto|last=Laz|language=es|date=23 August 2015|accessdate=7 September 2015}}</ref> and missed only three matches as his team finished 16th.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.diariodevalladolid.es/noticias/deportes/kepa-traera-dinero-zorrilla_125966.html|title=Kepa traerá dinero a Zorrilla|trans-title=Kepa will bring money to Zorrilla|newspaper=Diario de Valladolid|language=es|date=8 August 2018|accessdate=9 January 2019}}</ref>
After returning from loan, Arrizabalaga was definitely included in the first team, initially as third-choice behind [[Gorka Iraizoz]] and [[Iago Herrerín]]. He made his debut in the top flight on 11 September 2016, starting in a 1–0 away win over [[Deportivo de La Coruña]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/eventos/marcador/futbol/2016_17/la-liga/jornada_3/dep_ath/|title=Raúl García exhibe su pegada|trans-title=Raúl García shows his power|newspaper=Marca|location=Madrid|first=Jaime|last=Rincón|language=es|date=11 September 2016|accessdate=18 September 2016}}</ref>
On 22 January 2018, amid heavy transfer speculation linking him to [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]], Arrizabalaga renewed his contract – due to expire that June – until 2025.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11848/11218301/kepa-arrizabalaga-ends-real-madrid-speculation-by-signing-athletic-bilbao-deal|title=Kepa Arrizabalaga ends Real Madrid speculation by signing Athletic Bilbao deal|publisher=[[Sky Sports]]|date=22 January 2018|accessdate=23 January 2018}}</ref>
===Chelsea=== [[File:Chelsea 3 Arsenal 2 (43443195334).jpg|thumb|left|Arrizabalaga playing for Chelsea in a match against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in 2018]] On 8 August 2018, Athletic Bilbao announced on their website that Arrizabalaga had paid his required [[release clause]] (€80 million / £71.6 million),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.athletic-club.eus/en/noticias/19263/kepa-pays-termination-clause.html|title=Kepa pays termination clause|publisher=Athletic Bilbao|date=8 August 2018|accessdate=8 August 2018}}</ref> making him the [[List of most expensive association football transfers|world's most expensive goalkeeper]] only weeks after the record was set by [[Alisson (footballer, born 1992)|Alisson]]'s transfer to [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/aug/07/chelsea-kepa-arrizabalaga-athletic-bilbao-record|title=Chelsea to pay £71.6m for Athletic Bilbao goalkeeper Kepa Arrizabalaga|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|first=Dominic|last=Fifield|date=7 August 2018|accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref> Later that day, his move to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on a seven-year contract was confirmed,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.chelseafc.com/en/news/2018/8/8/kepa-arrives-at-chelsea|title=Kepa arrives at Chelsea|publisher=Chelsea F.C.|date=8 August 2018|accessdate=8 August 2018}}</ref> replacing [[Thibaut Courtois]] who departed for [[Real Madrid CF|Real Madrid]] and he made his [[Premier League]] debut three days later in a 3–0 away win against [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]];<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/45067371|title=Huddersfield Town 0–3 Chelsea|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|first=Michael|last=Emons|date=11 August 2018|accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref> he went on to keep six clean sheets<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.goal.com/en-us/news/chelseas-kepa-relishing-being-worlds-most-expensive-keeper/ph9py6s9dsx616jcv411ad0jq|title=Chelsea's Kepa relishing being world's most expensive keeper|publisher=[[Goal (website)|Goal]]|date=10 October 2018|accessdate=9 January 2019}}</ref> in the team's 12-match unbeaten run in the league, before a 3–1 defeat at the hands of [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.skysports.com/football/tottenham-vs-chelsea/390883|title=Tottenham 3–1 Chelsea: Maurizio Sarri's unbeaten start ended|publisher=Sky Sports|first=Ron|last=Walker|date=24 November 2018|accessdate=25 November 2018}}</ref>
On 24 January 2019, in the second leg of the [[EFL Cup]] semi-final, Arrizabalaga saved a [[Penalty (association football)|penalty]] from Tottenham's [[Lucas Moura]] in a 4–2 [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|shootout]] win at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]], helping his team go through to the [[2019 EFL Cup Final|final]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.sportinglife.com/football/news/chelsea-make-spurs-pay-the-penalty/157724|title=Carabao Cup semi-final: Chelsea beat Tottenham 4–2 on penalties to book final clash with Manchester City at Wembley|newspaper=[[Sporting Life (British newspaper)|Sporting Life]]|date=24 January 2019|accessdate=24 January 2019}}</ref>
On 24 February 2019, during the [[2019 EFL Cup Final]] against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]], with the match at 0–0 near the end of extra time, [[Maurizio Sarri]] called for Arrizabalaga to be substituted off for [[Willy Caballero]] for the upcoming penalty shootout; Sarri was concerned over his leg cramping a few minutes prior after making a diving save. However, Arrizabalaga refused to be substituted, gesticulating and remaining on the field. During the shootout, he saved one penalty as Chelsea lost the shoot-out 4–3.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Burt |first1=Jason |last2=Tyers |first2=Mike |title=Manchester City take the honours after Kepa Arrizabalaga antics overshadow otherwise drab League Cup final |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2019/02/24/chelsea-vs-manchester-city-carabao-cup-final-2019-live-score/ |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=25 February 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=WATCH: Kepa Arrizabalaga defies furious Chelsea boss Maurizio Sarri in Carabao Cup final |url=https://news.sky.com/story/watch-kepa-arrizabalaga-defies-furious-chelsea-boss-maurizio-sarri-in-carabao-cup-final-11647428 |publisher=[[Sky News]] |accessdate=25 February 2019}}</ref> After the game, both Arrizabalaga and Sarri said that the situation was a misunderstanding, with Sarri incorrectly believing that Arrizabalaga was too injured with a cramp to continue.<ref>{{cite web |title=Maurizio Sarri: Kepa Arrizabalaga incident a 'misunderstanding', says Chelsea boss |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47352319 |publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=25 February 2019}}</ref> Later on, Arrizabalaga met with Sarri and apologised to him and to the rest of the club. He was fined a week's worth of pay as a result of his actions, with Sarri leaving the decision of any further discipline up to the club, due to the club rules.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/47365945 |title=Kepa Arrizabalaga: Chelsea goalkeeper fined & apologises for Wembley incident |date=25 February 2019 |website=[[BBC Sport]] |access-date=26 February 2019}}</ref> Arrizabalaga was dropped from the starting lineup for Caballero in Chelsea's next match, a Premier League game against Tottenham.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.goal.com/en/news/its-a-message-to-the-group-sarri-explains-reasoning-for-dropping-/fei9ryhrddhg13xh86pt31i0v|title='It's a message to the group' - Sarri explains reasoning for dropping Kepa|publisher=Goal.com|date=28 February 2019|accessdate=1 March 2019}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:Kepa Arrizabalaga (6) (cropped).jpg|thumb|upright|Arrizabalaga with [[Spain national under-19 football team|Spain U19]] in 2012]] After appearing for [[Spain national under-18 football team|Spain's under-18s]], Arrizabalaga was called up to [[Spain national under-19 football team|the under-19 team]] for [[2012 UEFA European Under-19 Championship|that year]]'s [[UEFA European Under-19 Championship|UEFA European Championship]]. He was the starter during the tournament, as his side were crowned champions;<ref name="U19">{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/under19/history/season=2012/|title=Spain make it six of the best in Estonia|publisher=UEFA|accessdate=10 December 2014}}</ref> highlights included a 3–3 semi-final success against [[France national under-19 football team|France]], where he saved two penalties in the shootout.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/news/newsid=1840396.html|title=Spain finally see off France in semi-final shoot-out|publisher=UEFA|date=12 July 2012|accessdate=11 December 2014}}</ref>
Arrizabalaga missed the [[2013 FIFA U-20 World Cup]] due to injury, being replaced in the [[2013 FIFA U-20 World Cup squads#Spain|tournament squad]] by [[Rubén Yáñez]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sefutbol.com/kepa-arrizabalaga-deja-concentracion-lesion-y-se-perdera-mundial-turquia|title=Kepa deja la concentración por lesión y se pierde el Mundial de Turquía|trans-title=Kepa leaves training camp due to injury and misses World Cup in Turkey|publisher=Royal Spanish Football Federation|language=es|date=7 June 2013|accessdate=11 December 2014}}</ref> On 8 November 2013 he was called up to the [[Spain national under-21 football team|under-21 team]], along with Athletic teammate [[Iker Muniain]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.athletic-club.net/web/main.asp?a=0&b=1&c=2&d=1000&berria=13702&idi=2|title=Under21 Call-up|publisher=Athletic Bilbao|date=8 November 2013|accessdate=11 December 2014}}</ref>
Arrizabalaga was called up to the [[Spain national football team|senior side]] on 22 March 2017 ahead of a [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|2018 FIFA World Cup qualifier]] against [[Israel national football team|Israel]] and a [[Exhibition game|friendly]] with [[France national football team|France]], as a late replacement for the injured [[Pepe Reina]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.india.com/sports/kepa-arrizabalaga-gets-spain-call-as-pepe-reina-suffers-injury-1950330/|title=Kepa Arrizabalaga gets Spain call as Pepe Reina suffers injury|publisher=India.com|date=22 March 2017|accessdate=23 March 2017}}</ref> He earned his first [[Cap (sport)|cap]] on 11 November of that year, playing the full 90 minutes in a 5–0 friendly win over [[Costa Rica national football team|Costa Rica]] in [[Málaga]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/90minutes/ct-hoy-silva-nets-brace-spain-thrash-costa-rica-in-friendly-20171111-story.html|title=Silva nets brace, Spain thrash Costa Rica in friendly|newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=11 November 2017|accessdate=12 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sefutbol.com/en/match-report-spain-thrash-costa-rica-malaga-5-0-0|title=Match report: Spain thrash Costa Rica in Málaga (5–0)|publisher=Royal Spanish Football Federation|date=11 November 2017|accessdate=15 November 2017}}</ref>
Arrizabalaga was named in Spain's [[2018 FIFA World Cup squads#Spain|23-man squad]] for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] in Russia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/morata-misses-out-on-spain-world-cup-squad/1ub1qz7jod09i1lfvdcy84ea2l|title=Morata misses out on Spain's 23-man World Cup squad|publisher=Goal|date=21 May 2018|accessdate=21 May 2018}}</ref>

Roma|Roma]] | caps4 = 26 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 2017– | clubs5 = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] | caps5 = 56 | goals5 = 3 | nationalyears1 = 2010–2011 | nationalteam1 = [[Germany national youth football team|Germany U18]] | nationalcaps1 = 8 | nationalgoals1 = 4 | nationalyears2 = 2011–2012 | nationalteam2 = [[Germany national youth football team|Germany U19]] | nationalcaps2 = 14 | nationalgoals2 = 1 | nationalyears3 = 2012 | nationalteam3 = [[Germany national youth football team|Germany U20]] | nationalcaps3 = 2 | nationalgoals3 = 0 | nationalyears4 = 2012–2014 | nationalteam4 = [[Germany national under-21 football team|Germany U21]] | nationalcaps4 = 10 | nationalgoals4 = 1 | nationalyears5 = 2014– | nationalteam5 = [[Germany national football team|Germany]] | nationalcaps5 = 29 | nationalgoals5 = 1 | club-update = 18:27, 17 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 21:39, 19 November 2018 (UTC) | medaltemplates = {{MedalCountry|{{GER}}}} {{MedalCompetition|[[FIFA Confederations Cup]]}} {{Medal|W|[[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup|2017]]|}} }} '''Antonio Rüdiger''' ({{IPA-de|anˈto:nio ˈʁy:diˌgɐ}}; born 3 March 1993) is a German professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)|defender]] for English club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] and the [[Germany national football team|Germany national team]].
He began his career at [[VfB Stuttgart]], representing [[VfB Stuttgart II|their reserves]] in [[3. Liga]] and the first team in the [[Bundesliga]]. In 2015 he joined [[A.S. Roma|Roma]], initially on loan and a year later for a €9 million fee. He was signed by Chelsea in 2017 for an estimated £27 million.
Rüdiger made his international debut for [[Germany national football team|Germany]] in March 2014. He was forced to miss [[UEFA Euro 2016]] due to an injury suffered earlier in the season but he was part of the squad that won the [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup]]. He kept his spot in [[2018 FIFA World Cup squads#Germany|the squad]] for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 World Cup]].
==Club career== ===VfB Stuttgart=== On 23 July 2011, Rüdiger made his debut for [[VfB Stuttgart II]] in the [[3. Liga]] against [[Arminia Bielefeld]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dfb.de/index.php?id=505718&no_cache=1&action=showSchema&lang=D&liga=bl3m&saison=11&saisonl=2011&spieltag=1&spielid=1280&cHash=03a240bdf9bb846d8dc2cc86da33d26e|title= Arminia Bielefeld – VfB Stuttgart II 1:2 (1:0)|publisher=[[German Football Association]]|accessdate=27 January 2012|date=23 July 2011 | language = German}}</ref>
On 29 January 2012, Rüdiger made his [[Bundesliga]] debut for [[VfB Stuttgart]]'s first team in a home professional match against [[Borussia Mönchengladbach]], he was replaced by [[Raphael Holzhauser]] in the 79th minute of a 3–0 defeat.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2012/01/29/germany/bundesliga/vfb-stuttgart-1893-ev/borussia-monchengladbach/1122103/|title=Stuttgart vs. Borussia M'gladbach – 29 January 2012 – Soccerway|website=uk.soccerway.com|language=en|access-date=7 November 2017}}</ref>
On 19 April 2013, Rüdiger extended his contract with [[VfB Stuttgart]] until June 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vfb.de/en/aktuell/meldungen/news/2013/vertragsverlaengerung-antonio-ruediger-vfb-stuttgart/page/2235-1-1-.html|title=Antonio Rüdiger extends contract with VfB|date=19 April 2013|work=vfb.de|publisher=VfB Stuttgart|accessdate=19 April 2013}}</ref> On 4 May he received a [[Red card (soccer)|red card]] in the 74th minute of a 2–0 home defeat against [[SpVgg Greuther Fürth|Greuther Fürth]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2013/05/04/germany/bundesliga/vfb-stuttgart-1893-ev/spvgg-greuther-furth/1301053/|title=Stuttgart vs. Greuther Fürth – 4 May 2013 – Soccerway|website=uk.soccerway.com|language=en|access-date=7 November 2017}}</ref> On 1 June, Rüdiger played in the final of the DFB Pokal in a match lost 3–2 against [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayer Munich]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2013/06/01/germany/dfb-pokal/fc-bayern-munchen/vfb-stuttgart-1893-ev/1469854/|title=Bayern München vs. Stuttgart – 1 June 2013 – Soccerway|website=uk.soccerway.com|language=en|access-date=7 November 2017}}</ref> He finished his second season in the first team with 24 appearances, plus 4 appearances and 2 goals in the reserve team.<ref name=":0" />
On 20 October 2013, Rüdiger was sent off with a [[Red card (soccer)|red card]] in the 84th minute of a 3–3 away draw against [[Hamburger SV]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2013/10/20/germany/bundesliga/hamburger-sv/vfb-stuttgart-1893-ev/1487101/|title=Hamburger SV vs. Stuttgart – 20 October 2013 – Soccerway|website=uk.soccerway.com|language=en|access-date=6 November 2017}}</ref> Rüdiger finished the 2013–14 season with 35 appearances and 2 goals.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/players/antonio-rudiger/192187/|title=Germany – A. Rüdiger – Profile with news, career statistics and history – Soccerway|website=uk.soccerway.com|language=en|access-date=6 November 2017}}</ref> Rüdiger finished the following season with only 20 appearances and 1 assist due to various injuries.
===Roma=== On 19 August 2015, [[Serie A]] side [[A.S. Roma|Roma]] signed Rüdiger on loan from VfB Stuttgart for €4 million. The clubs agreed on an optional €9 million transfer fee at the end of the one-year contract.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.asroma.it/en/news/roma_complete_rudiger_signing | title = Roma complete Rüdiger signing | date = 19 August 2015 | accessdate = 19 August 2015 | work = asroma.it | publisher = A.S. Roma}}</ref>
On 12 September, he made his debut in a 2–0 away win over [[Frosinone Calcio|Frosinone]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2015/09/12/italy/serie-a/frosinone-calcio/as-roma/2120398/|title=Frosinone vs. Roma – 12 September 2015 – Soccerway|website=uk.soccerway.com|language=en|access-date=6 November 2017}}</ref> On 9 January 2016 he scored his first goal for Roma in the 4th minute of a 1–1 home draw against [[A.C. Milan|Milan]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2016/01/09/italy/serie-a/as-roma/ac-milan/2120563/|title=Roma vs. Milan – 9 January 2016 – Soccerway|website=uk.soccerway.com|language=en|access-date=6 November 2017}}</ref> He finished his season-long loan to Roma with 37 appearances and 2 goals.<ref name=":0" /> On 30 May, Roma officially signed Rüdiger from for €9 million + €0.5m bonuses on a four-year contract.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asroma.com/it/notizie/2016/05/la-roma-ha-esercitato-il-diritto-di-opzione-per-l-acquisizione-di-antonio-rudiger|title= La Roma ha esercitato il diritto di opzione per l'acquisizione di Antonio Rudiger | date = 30 May 2016| accessdate = 31 May 2016 | publisher = A.S. Roma|language=Italian}}</ref>
On 23 February 2017, as a substitute replacing [[Kostas Manolas]] in the 46th minute of a 1–0 home defeat against [[Villarreal CF|Villareal]] in the round of 32 of the [[UEFA Europa League]], he was sent off with a double yellow card in the 81st minute.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2017/02/23/europe/uefa-cup/as-roma/villarreal-club-de-futbol/2380714/|title=Roma vs. Villarreal – 23 February 2017 – Soccerway|website=uk.soccerway.com|language=en|access-date=6 November 2017}}</ref> On 30 April he was sent off with a [[Red card (soccer)|red card]] in the 93rd minute in [[Derby della Capitale]] against Lazio in a 3–1 home defeat.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2017/04/30/italy/serie-a/as-roma/ss-lazio-roma/2306085/|title=Roma vs. Lazio – 30 April 2017 – Soccerway|website=uk.soccerway.com|language=en|access-date=6 November 2017}}</ref> Rüdiger finished his second season at Roma with 35 appearances and 4 assists.<ref name=":0" />
===Chelsea===
====2017–18 season==== On 9 July 2017, Rüdiger joined [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] from Roma for a reported initial fee of £29 million on a five-year deal.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40550502|title=Antonio Rudiger: Chelsea sign Roma defender for a reported initial fee of £29m| date = 9 July 2017 | accessdate = 9 July 2017 | publisher = BBC Sport}}</ref> He was given the number 2 shirt.<ref>{{cite web | url = https://weaintgotnohistory.sbnation.com/2017/7/9/15943710/chelsea-confirm-antonio-rudiger-shirt-number| title = Antonio Rüdiger inherits Chelsea legend's shirt number | website = sbnation.com | date = 9 July 2017 | access-date = 13 August 2017 | first = David | last = Pasztor}}</ref>
He made his debut on 6 August as a substitute replacing [[Marcos Alonso Mendoza|Marcos Alonso]] in the 79th minute in a 4–1 loss on penalties to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] in the [[2017 FA Community Shield]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2017/08/06/england/community-shield/arsenal-fc/chelsea-football-club/2461684/|title=Arsenal vs. Chelsea – 6 August 2017 – Soccerway|website=uk.soccerway.com|language=en|access-date=6 November 2017}}</ref> He made his [[Premier League]] debut six days later in a 3–2 defeat against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2017/08/12/england/premier-league/chelsea-football-club/burnley-fc/2462796/|title=Chelsea vs. Burnley – 12 August 2017 – Soccerway|website=uk.soccerway.com|language=en|access-date=6 November 2017}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Chelsea in the round of 16 of the [[EFL Cup]] in a 2–1 win over [[Everton F.C.|Everton]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2017/10/25/england/league-cup/chelsea-football-club/everton-football-club/2594014/|title=Chelsea vs. Everton – 25 October 2017 – Soccerway|website=uk.soccerway.com|language=en|access-date=6 November 2017}}</ref> and his first league goal was the only one of a home win over [[Swansea City]] on 29 November.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/chelsea-1-swansea-0-antonio-rudiger-the-unlikely-hero-as-antonio-conte-is-sent-to-the-stands-a3705631.html|title=Chelsea 1 Swansea 0: Antonio Rudiger the unlikely hero|website=www.standard.co.uk|language=en|access-date=29 November 2017}}</ref>
====2018–19 season==== On 20 October, Rüdiger scored his first goal of the season, opening the scoring in a 2–2 home draw against [[Manchester United]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.chelseafc.com/en/news/2018/10/20/report---|title=REPORT: CHELSEA 2 MANCHESTER UNITED 2|website=www.chelseafc.com|language=en|access-date=21 October 2018}}</ref>
==International career== Rüdiger was eligible to play for Germany and [[Sierra Leone national football team|Sierra Leone]], his mother's homeland<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.footballsierraleone.net/as-roma-sign-antonio-ruediger-on-loan/ |title= AS Roma sign Antonio Ruediger on loan |accessdate= 1 April 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160416073732/http://www.footballsierraleone.net/as-roma-sign-antonio-ruediger-on-loan/ |archivedate= 16 April 2016}}</ref> and was a member of the several German national youth football teams up to the [[Germany national under-21 football team|Germany U21]] team.
He made his debut for the [[Germany national football team|German national senior team]] on 13 May 2014 in a 0–0 draw against [[Poland national football team|Poland]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/match/131992/germany-vs-poland/report | title=Germany 0–0 Poland | publisher=www.goal.com | accessdate=14 May 2014}}</ref> Although he was initially included in his nation's 23-man squad for [[UEFA Euro 2016]], Rüdiger was later ruled out of the tournament due to injury, after tearing the [[anterior cruciate ligament]] in his right knee during a training session on 7 June.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.us/germany/story/2888155/antonio-rudiger-tears-acl-in-germany-training-for-euro-2016|title=Antonio Rudiger tears ACL in Germany training, ruled out of Euro 2016|publisher=ESPN FC|date=7 June 2016|accessdate=8 June 2016}}</ref>
Rüdiger was part of the German national squad which won the [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup]] in Russia. He played four matches in the tournament, including the 1–0 win over [[Chile national football team|Chile]] in the [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup|final]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Johnston|first1=Neil|title=Chile 0–1 Germany|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40464139|accessdate=11 January 2018|publisher=BBC Sport|date=2 July 2017}}</ref> On 8 October 2017, he headed his first international goal in a 5–1 home win over [[Azerbaijan national football team|Azerbaijan]] in [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|World Cup qualifying]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Germany 5–1 Azerbaijan|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41533920|accessdate=11 January 2018|publisher=BBC Sport|date=8 October 2017}}</ref>
Rüdiger was included in Germany's final 23-man squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]] on 4 June 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dw.com/en/germany-announce-final-world-cup-squad-with-manuel-neuer-without-leroy-san%C3%A9/a-44064011|title=Germany announce final World Cup squad, with Manuel Neuer, without Leroy Sané|publisher=Deutsche Welle|accessdate=4 June 2018}}</ref> On 24 June, he picked up for the second group stage match against [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]] as first choice [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|centre-back]] [[Mats Hummels]] suffered an injury, the game ended 2–1 win for Germany.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/world-cup/world-cup-2018-germany-sweden-mats-hummels-a8414891.html|title=World Cup 2018: Mats Hummels says Germany's dramatic win over Sweden could be their turning point|publisher=The Independent|accessdate=1 August 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/jun/23/toni-kroos-germany-sweden-world-cup-match-report|title=Toni Kroos brings off late miracle for Germany to stun Sweden|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=1 August 2018}}</ref> Four days later, he did not play the last group stage match and his side were knocked out by [[South Korea national football team|South Korea]] after a 2–0 defeat.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2018/jun/27/world-cup-2018-south-korea-v-germany-live|title=South Korea 2–0 Germany: World Cup 2018 – as it happened|publisher=The Guardian|accessdate=1 August 2018}}</ref>
==Style of play== Normally a centre-back, Rüdiger is a versatile defender, who is also capable of playing as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|full-back]] on either flank.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.calciomercato.com/news/rudiger-dall-inter-ai-milioni-di-conte-la-roma-blinda-il-leader--57489 |title=Rudiger, dall'Inter ai milioni di Conte: la Roma blinda il leader della difesa 2.0 |publisher=www.calciomercato.com |language=Italian |date=10 February 2017 |accessdate=21 October 2018 }}</ref> In 2015, ''[[ESPN]]'' described him as a "...tall, quick and athletic defender who is ... comfortable with the ball at his feet", also touting him as an "interesting prospect" who "...has all the necessary physical attributes to become a top-level centre-back."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/blog/the-scouts-notebook/78/post/2514270/stuttgart-and-germany-defender-antonio-rudiger-profile |title=Rising star Antonio Rudiger would be best served by Bundesliga stay |publisher=ESPN FC |author1=Nick Dorrington |date=7 July 2015 |accessdate=20 October 2018 }}</ref> His Chelsea profile also describes him as a "tough tackler" and a "commanding presence in the air."<ref name="Chelsea profile"/>
==Personal life== Rüdiger's father, Matthias Rüdiger, is [[Germans|German]], while his mother Lily is originally from [[Sierra Leone]]. He is the half-brother of [[Sahr Senesie]].<ref name="DFB">{{cite web|url=https://www.dfb.de/news/detail/antonio-ruediger-manchmal-musst-du-volles-risiko-gehen-31460/|title=Antonio Rüdiger: "Manchmal musst du volles Risiko gehen"|publisher=[[German Football Association]]|accessdate=21 October 2012|date=24 February 2012|language=German}}</ref>
In October 2018 he stated that authorities needed to do more to deal with [[Racism in association football|racism in the sport]].<ref>https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45970660</ref>

'''Jorge de Amorim Campos''' (born 17 August 1964), a.k.a. '''Jorginho''', is a Brazilian retired [[Association football|footballer]] who played mainly as a [[Defender (association football)#Full back|right back]], and is a current manager.
A quick, technically gifted, and hard-working full-back,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.orlandosentinel.com/1994-06-15/features/9406150766_1_baggio-great-soccer-players-goals-in-world|title=Baggio Takes Great Strides Toward Soccer Greatness|publisher=The Orlando Sentinel|author1=Mike Zizzo|date=15 June 1994|accessdate=24 September 2015}}</ref> he is regarded as one of the best full-backs of his generation, and as one of the greatest Brazilian defenders of all time.<ref>{{cite web|title=Brazil's greatest defenders|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/18621/6120873/brazils-greatest-defenders|work=Sky Sports|accessdate=15 December 2015}}</ref> He played in his country for five different clubs, and also spent six years in Germany, namely with [[FC Bayern Munich|Bayern Munich]]; additionally, he was part of the [[Brazil national football team|Brazilian team]] that won the [[1994 FIFA World Cup|1994 World Cup]].
==Playing career== ===Club=== Born in [[Rio de Janeiro]], Jorginho started playing professionally for local side [[America Football Club (RJ)|América Football Club]], moving after just one season to [[Clube de Regatas do Flamengo]].
In 1989, he went overseas, joining German [[Bundesliga]] outfit [[Bayer 04 Leverkusen]]. With most teams in the country playing in a [[Formation (association football)|5–3–2 or 3–5–2 formation]], his tremendous offensive ability was put to good use, and he scored five goals for Bayer during [[1991–92 Bundesliga|his third and final season]].
Staying in the country, Jorginho signed with league giants [[FC Bayern Munich]] in [[1992–93 Bundesliga|1992–93]], backed by a defensive line which included [[Olaf Thon]], [[Thomas Helmer]] and later [[Lothar Matthäus]]. He won the national title in his second year but, after the loan return of [[Markus Babbel]], a [[Defender (association football)#Centre-back|central defender]] which also operated on [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|the right flank]], was restricted to just ten league contests in 1994–95.
After still appearing with success for [[J. League]]'s [[Kashima Antlers]], winning both [[J. League Division 1|the league]] and [[List of J-League Player of the Year|MVP]] titles in [[1996 J. League|1996]], Jorginho returned to Brazil and played until 39, with [[São Paulo FC]], [[CR Vasco da Gama]] and [[Fluminense Football Club]]. In 2001, he paired at Vasco with both [[Romário]] and [[Bebeto]], but did not seem to get along with the pair.
===International=== Jorginho was capped 64 times for the [[Brazil national football team|Brazilian national team]], scoring three goals. He played at both the [[1990 FIFA World Cup|1990]] and the [[1994 FIFA World Cup|1994]] [[FIFA World Cup]]s.
In the latter edition, he played all the matches as the nation emerged victorious. Jorginho was [[Penalty card#Yellow card|booked]] in the second-round match against the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]], but was named in the [[FIFA World Cup awards#All-Star Team|All-Star squad]] a few days later. He contributed two assists in the tournament, including a cross in the semifinals against [[Sweden national football team|Sweden]] that helped Romário score the winning goal. He also performed solidly against [[Italy national football team|Italy]] in the [[1994 FIFA World Cup Final|final]], including a play in which he freed himself from a double-team. However, he got injured after just twenty minutes of play, and was replaced by [[Cafú]].
In 2006, Jorginho was hired as the head coach of first side América. However, on 31 July of that same year, he was hired as Brazil's assistant, joining the staff of former national side teammate [[Dunga]]. In two 2008 [[Exhibition game|friendlies]], he took over for the head manager, following Dunga's dismissal in the previous game and subsequent ban from the [[Brazilian Football Confederation]]; he led the team to two 1–0 wins, against the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] and Sweden.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://soccernet.espn.go.com/news/story?id=480289&cc=4716 | title = Dunga banned for four games by Brazilian tribunal | publisher = [[ESPN Soccernet]] | date = 8 November 2007 | accessdate = 19 February 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/braz-coach-triv.html | title = Brazilian National Team Coaches | publisher = [[Rec.Sport.Soccer Statistics Foundation|RSSSF]] | accessdate = 19 February 2012}}</ref> Both left the national team following the [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010 World Cup]] quarterfinal loss against [[Netherlands national football team|Holland]].
Internationally, Jorginho also helped [[Brazil Olympic football team|the Olympic team]] [[Football at the 1988 Summer Olympics|win silver]] at the [[1988 Summer Olympics]] in [[Seoul]].<ref>{{FIFA player|63515}}</ref>
==Managerial career== Jorginho started his managerial career with his first club America in 2005. In the following year, he was appointed [[Dunga]]'s assistant at the [[Brazil national football team|Brazil national team]], remaining with the role until 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://extra.globo.com/esporte/auxiliar-d-dunga-entre-2006-2010-na-selecao-jorginho-elogia-escolha-da-cbf-13338689.html|title=Auxiliar de Dunga entre 2006 e 2010 na seleção, Jorginho elogia escolha da CBF|trans-title=Dunga's assistant between 2006 and 2010 at the ''Seleção'', Jorginho praises CBF's choice|publisher=Extra|language=pt|date=22 July 2014|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref>
On 30 August 2010, Jorginho was announced as the new [[Goiás Esporte Clube|Goiás]] manager.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.com.br/noticia/145208_jorginho-e-o-novo-tecnico-do-goias-e-tem-apresentacao-marcada-para-esta-segunda-feira|title=Jorginho é o novo técnico do Goiás e tem apresentação marcada para esta segunda-feira|trans-title=Jorginho is the new manager of Goiás and has presentation scheduled for this Monday|publisher=[[ESPN Brasil]]|language=pt|date=30 August 2010|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref> Dismissed on 8 November,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globoesporte.globo.com/futebol/times/goias/noticia/2010/11/jorginho-e-demitido-do-goias-e-arthur-neto-e-o-novo-treinador.html|title=Jorginho é demitido do Goiás, e Arthur Neto já é o novo treinador|trans-title=Jorginho is fired from Goiás, and Arthur Neto already is the new manager|publisher=Globo Esporte|language=pt|date=8 November 2010|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref> he was appointed manager of [[Figueirense FC|Figueirense]] the following 1 March.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://oglobo.globo.com/esportes/jorginho-o-novo-tecnico-do-figueirense-2817145|title=Jorginho é o novo técnico do Figueirense|trans-title=Jorginho is the new manager of Figueirense|publisher=[[O Globo]]|language=pt|date=1 March 2011|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref>
On 21 December 2011, Jorginho left ''Figueira'' and was named at the helm of Kashima Antlers, a club he already represented as a player.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globoesporte.globo.com/futebol/noticia/2011/12/jorginho-confirma-acerto-com-kashima-antlers.html|title=Técnico Jorginho confirma acerto com o Kashima Antlers|trans-title=Manager Jorginho confirms deal with Kashima Antlers|publisher=Globo Esporte|language=pt|date=21 December 2011|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref> He returned to Brazil on 17 March 2013, being appointed [[Clube de Regatas do Flamengo|Flamengo]] manager,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flamengo.com.br/noticias/futebol/jorginho-e-o-novo-tecnico-do-flamengo|title=Jorginho é o novo técnico do Flamengo|trans-title=Jorginho is the new manager of Flamengo|publisher=CR Flamengo|language=pt|date=17 March 2013|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref> but was sacked on 6 June.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://oglobo.globo.com/esportes/campeonato-brasileiro-2013/jorginho-demitido-do-flamengo-8606553|title=Jorginho é demitido do Flamengo|trans-title=Jorginho is fired from Flamengo|publisher=O Globo|language=pt|date=6 June 2013|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref>
Jorginho was subsequently in charge of [[Associação Atlética Ponte Preta|Ponte Preta]] and [[Al-Wasl F.C.|Al-Wasl]] before being named manager of former club Vasco on 16 August 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.com.br/noticia/536089_jorginho-e-o-novo-treinador-do-vasco-e-ja-comanda-treino-nesta-segunda|title=Jorginho é o novo treinador do Vasco e já comanda treino nesta segunda|trans-title=Jorginho is the new manager of Vasco and already takes over trainings this Monday|publisher=ESPN Brasil|language=pt|date=16 August 2015|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref> Despite failing to [[2015 Campeonato Brasileiro Série A|avoid relegation]], he was maintained and won the [[2016 Campeonato Carioca]]; after [[2016 Campeonato Brasileiro Série B|achieving immediate promotion]], he resigned on 28 November 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globoesporte.globo.com/futebol/times/vasco/noticia/2016/11/apos-quase-um-ano-e-meio-jorginho-conversa-com-eurico-e-acerta-saida.html|title=Após quase um ano e meio, Jorginho conversa com Eurico e acerta saída|trans-title=After nearly one-and-a-half year, Jorginho talks with Eurico and agrees departure|publisher=Globo Esporte|language=pt|date=28 November 2016|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref>
On 1 June 2017 Jorginho was appointed manager of [[Esporte Clube Bahia|Bahia]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.esporteclubebahia.com.br/jorginho/|title=Novo comando|trans-title=New command|publisher=EC Bahia|language=pt|date=1 June 2017|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref> but his reign only lasted nearly two months.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://globoesporte.globo.com/ba/futebol/times/bahia/noticia/apos-derrota-para-o-sport-bahia-demite-jorginho.ghtml|title=Após derrota para o Sport, Bahia demite Jorginho|trans-title=After defeat to Sport, Bahia dismiss Jorginho|publisher=Globo Esporte|language=pt|date=31 July 2017|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref> The following 21 May he replaced fired [[Marcelo Chamusca]] at the helm of [[Ceará Sporting Club|Ceará]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cearasc.com/noticia/jorginho-e-o-novo-treinador-cearasc|title=Jorginho é o novo treinador do Ceará para a temporada 2018|trans-title=Jorginho is the new manager of Ceará for the 2018 season|publisher=Ceará SC|language=pt|date=21 May 2018|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref> but resigned on 4 June after alleging "personal reasons";<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cearasc.com/noticia/jorginho-nao-e-mais-treinador-do-ceara|title=Jorginho não é mais treinador do Ceará|trans-title=Jorginho is no longer manager of Ceará|publisher=Ceará SC|language=pt|date=4 June 2018|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref> the day after his resignation, he was announced back at Vasco.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://oglobo.globo.com/esportes/jorginho-anunciado-como-novo-tecnico-do-vasco-22749277|title=Jorginho é anunciado como novo técnico do Vasco|trans-title=Jorginho is announced as new manager of Vasco|publisher=O Globo|language=pt|date=5 June 2018|access-date=11 June 2018}}</ref>
Jorginho was fired on 13 August 2018, after only 10 matches.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://globoesporte.globo.com/futebol/times/vasco/noticia/jorginho-nao-e-mais-o-tecnico-do-vasco.ghtml|title=Durou pouco: após 10 jogos, Jorginho é demitido do Vasco|trans-title=It did not last long: after 10 matches, Jorginho is fired from Vasco|publisher=Globo Esporte|language=pt|date=13 August 2018|access-date=14 August 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== Jorginho is a born-again Christian. Alongside compatriots [[Cláudio Taffarel]] and [[Bismarck Barreto Faria|Bismarck]] – also footballers – he was featured sharing his faith in a special version of the film ''[[Jesus (1979 film)|Jesus]]'', produced and distributed during the [[1998 FIFA World Cup|1998 World Cup]].
He also founded the club ''Bola Pra Frente'' in his Rio de Janeiro [[slum]] of Guadalupe.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.stern.de/reise/fernreisen/rio-de-janeiro-die-wiege-der-fussballgoetter-555336.html | title = Rio de Janeiro: Die Wiege der Fußballgötter |trans-title=Rio de Janeiro: The Gods of football's cradle | publisher = [[Stern (magazine)|Stern]] | date = 21 February 2006 | language = German | accessdate = 19 February 2012}}</ref>

11 August 2018 (UTC) }} '''Daniel Noel Drinkwater''' (born 5 March 1990) is an English professional [[association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] and the [[England national football team|English national team]]. He has previously spent time on loan at [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]], [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]], [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] and [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]], and also played for [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] and [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]]. Drinkwater has also played internationally for England at [[England national under-18 football team|under-18]] and [[England national under-19 football team|under-19 levels]]. He is a Premier League winner, having won the competition with Leicester in the 2015–16 season.
==Club career== ===Manchester United=== Born in [[Manchester]],<ref name=Hugman1011/> Drinkwater joined the [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] academy at the age of nine, progressing through the ranks before earning a trainee contract in July 2006.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} In his first season at the club, Drinkwater became a regular in the Manchester United under-18 team, making 27 appearances and scoring two goals.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} He received his first taste of reserve team action that same season, coming off the bench to replace [[Ritchie Jones]] in a 5–2 [[Premier Reserve League]] win at home to [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]].{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} The following season, Drinkwater consolidated his position in the under-18s team while increasing his presence in the reserves.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} In the 2008 Lancashire Senior Cup final against [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] on 31 July 2008, Drinkwater came on as a 56th-minute substitute for [[Rodrigo Possebon]] before scoring the winning goal three minutes from full-time.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}} In the 2008–09 season, Drinkwater became a regular in the reserve team, making 18 appearances and getting on the scoresheet twice.{{citation needed|date=March 2016}}
At the end of the season, he was called up to the Manchester United first team for their [[dead rubber]] league match against [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] on 24 May 2009. He was named on the bench, but did not take to the field.<ref>{{cite news |first=Ian |last=Hughes |title=Hull 0–1 Man Utd |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8048308.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 May 2009 |accessdate=15 August 2009}}</ref>
====Loans==== To gain first-team experience, on 14 August 2009, Drinkwater joined [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] on loan for the duration of the 2009–10 season.<ref>{{cite news |title=Drinkwater moves to Huddersfield |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/h/huddersfield_town/8201452.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=14 August 2009 |accessdate=15 August 2009}}</ref> He made his debut for the club the very next day, coming on in the 72nd minute for [[Gary Roberts (footballer, born 1984)|Gary Roberts]] in a 3–1 win at home to [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Huddersfield 3–1 Southampton |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/8200493.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 August 2009 |accessdate=15 August 2009}}</ref> His first goal for Huddersfield came three days later in a 7–1 home win over [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]], five minutes after coming on as a 64th-minute substitute.<ref>{{cite news |title=Huddersfield 7–1 Brighton |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/8205231.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 August 2009 |accessdate=18 August 2009}}</ref> He made his first start for Huddersfield in a 1–0 defeat at [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]] on 22 August.<ref name=sb0910/>
On 8 July 2010, Manchester United agreed for Drinkwater to spend a season-long loan spell at [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]]. As they were under a transfer embargo at the time, Cardiff said that the move would be completed once this had been lifted.<ref>{{cite news |title=Man U youngster Daniel Drinkwater joins Cardiff on loan |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/8799988.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 July 2010 |accessdate=8 July 2010}}</ref> The move was eventually confirmed on 6 August 2010, once the embargo had been removed.<ref>{{cite web |title=Embargo lifted, players registered |url=http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10335~2113888,00.html |publisher=Cardiff City F.C. |date=6 August 2010 |accessdate=6 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324115635/http://www.cardiffcityfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10335~2113888%2C00.html |archivedate=24 March 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Drinkwater's competitive debut for Cardiff two days later, in their 1–1 home draw with [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]] on the opening day of the [[2010–11 Football League]] season.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff 1–1 Sheff Utd |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/8881637.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=8 August 2010 |accessdate=8 August 2010}}</ref>
Despite the loan having originally been intended to last the entire season, Manchester United recalled Drinkwater from Cardiff on 25 January 2011. During his time with Cardiff, Drinkwater made 12 appearances, including nine in the [[EFL Championship|Championship]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Danny Drinkwater returns to Man United from Cardiff |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/cardiff_city/9373359.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 January 2011 |accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
Just three days after his return to Manchester United, Drinkwater joined [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] on 28 January 2011 on loan until the end of the season.<ref>{{cite news |title=Watford sign Manchester United midfielder Drinkwater |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/w/watford/9380244.stm |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
On 23 August 2011, Drinkwater joined [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] on loan until 2 January 2012,<ref>{{cite web |first=Adam |last=Marshall |title=Danny joins Barnsley |url=http://www.manutd.com/en/News-And-Features/Football-News/2011/Aug/drinkwater-joins-barnsley.aspx |publisher=Manchester United F.C. |date=23 August 2011 |accessdate=23 August 2011}}</ref> which was later extended until 30 June 2012.<ref>{{cite web |title=Drinkwater deal sealed |url=http://www.barnsleyfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10309~2568857,00.html |publisher=Barnsley F.C. |date=6 January 2011 |accessdate=7 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120703210640/http://www.barnsleyfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10309~2568857,00.html |archivedate=3 July 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> He made 17 Championship appearances for the Tykes, scoring in a 5–3 loss at his former team Cardiff on 22 October.<ref>{{cite news |title=Cardiff 5–3 Barnsley |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/15319693 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=22 October 2011 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref>
===Leicester City=== [[File:Danny Drinkwater 20170114.jpg|thumb|upright|Drinkwater playing for [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] in 2017]]
On 20 January 2012, Drinkwater joined [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]] from Manchester United for an undisclosed fee.<ref>{{cite web |title=Leicester land Drinkwater |url=http://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0,,10274~2582456,00.html |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |date=20 January 2012 |accessdate=20 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120122223926/http://www.lcfc.com/page/LatestNews/0%2C%2C10274~2582456%2C00.html |archivedate=22 January 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
After being named [[EFL Championship Player of the Month|Championship Player of the Month]] for December 2013,<ref>{{cite web |title=Drinkwater wins Player of the Month |url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/100114-drinkwater-wins-player-of-the-month-1284869.aspx |publisher=Leicester City F.C. |date=10 January 2014 |accessdate=13 March 2014}}</ref> he was also one of three players who received a nomination for the Championship Player of the Year Award.<ref>{{cite news |title=Football League Awards: Danny Ings named Player of the Year |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/26566746 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 March 2014 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref> Drinkwater had his most successful year as a professional, scoring seven goals and being named to the [[PFA Team of the Year (2010s)#Championship 5|PFA Championship Team of the Year]] alongside teammates [[Kasper Schmeichel]] and [[Wes Morgan]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Leicester-City-trio-make-PFA-Championship-Team/story-21021037-detail/story.html |title=Leicester City trio make the PFA Championship Team of the Year |newspaper=Leicester Mercury |date=27 April 2014 |accessdate=17 June 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140430052007/http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Leicester-City-trio-make-PFA-Championship-Team/story-21021037-detail/story.html |archivedate=30 April 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> as Leicester were promoted to the [[Premier League]] after winning the Championship.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/apr/05/leicester-city-promoted-premier-league |title=Leicester City promoted to Premier League after QPR defeat |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=5 April 2014 |accessdate=17 June 2015}}</ref> On 17 June 2014, Drinkwater signed a new four-year deal with Leicester after helping the Foxes win promotion to the Premier League for the first time in ten years.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www1.skysports.com/transfer/news/11712/9352511/transfer-news-leicester-midfielder-danny-drinkwater-signs-new-four-year-contract |title=Transfer news: Leicester midfielder Danny Drinkwater signs new four-year contract |publisher=Sky Sports |date=17 June 2014 |accessdate=17 June 2014}}</ref>
Drinkwater played consistently as the Foxes won the Premier League title in [[2015–16 Premier League|2015–16]], alongside his midfield partners [[N'Golo Kanté]], [[Marc Albrighton]] and [[Riyad Mahrez]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Laurence|first=Martin|title=Why Riyad Mahrez, and not Jamie Vardy, has been the player of the season so far|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/who-scored-blog/2015/dec/08/riyad-mahrez-jamie-vardy-player-season-premier-league|accessdate=25 January 2016|newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |date=8 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2016/may/02/leicester-city-champions-premier-league|title=The Leicester Supremacy – A Triumph That Was Never Supposed to Happen|newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=3 May 2016}}</ref> He scored his first top-flight goal on 23 January 2016, to open a 3–0 win over [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] at the [[King Power Stadium]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Shamoon |last=Hafez |title=Leicester City 3–0 Stoke City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35331047 |publisher=BBC Sport|date=23 January 2016 |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref>
On 25 August 2016, Drinkwater signed a contract to remain with the club until 2021.<ref>{{cite web|title=Danny Drinkwater signs long-term Leicester contract|url=http://www.lcfc.com/news/article/2016-17/danny-drinkwater-signs-long-term-leicester-contract-3270111.aspx|accessdate=25 August 2016|publisher=Leicester City F.C.|date=25 August 2016}}</ref>
===Chelsea=== On 1 September 2017, Drinkwater signed for Premier League champions [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on a five-year contract, for a £35 million fee.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41119060 |title=Danny Drinkwater: Chelsea sign midfielder from Leicester |publisher=BBC Sport |date=1 September 2017 |accessdate=1 September 2017}}</ref> Due to a thigh injury that ruled him out previously, he made his debut on 25 October in the last 16 of the EFL Cup, playing an hour of a 2–1 home win over Everton.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Johnson|first1=Simon|title=Chelsea analysis: Danny Drinkwater debut a boost but Ethan Ampadu and Charly Musonda have work to do|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/chelsea-analysis-danny-drinkwater-debut-a-boost-but-ethan-ampadu-and-charly-musonda-have-work-to-do-a3668036.html|accessdate=26 October 2017|work=London Evening Standard|date=25 October 2017}}</ref> Drinkwater made his first Premier League start for the Blues in a 1–1 draw against Liverpool at Anfield on 25 November.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/nov/25/liverpool-chelsea-premier-league-match-report|title=Liverpool denied victory over Chelsea after Willian's late equaliser | date= 25 November 2017 |work=The Guardian}}</ref> On 30 December, he scored his first goal for Chelsea, a well-executed half volley, in a 5–0 home win over [[Stoke City]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.sbs.com.au/news/willian-shines-as-chelsea-crush-stoke |title=Willian shines as Chelsea crush Stoke |publisher=SBS |date=31 December 2017}}</ref> His first season at Chelsea saw him make 22 appearances in all competitions, including four in the Blues’ triumphant [[FA Cup]] campaign. However, injury meant Drinkwater was not involved in the final, against his old club [[Manchester United]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.football.london/chelsea-fc/players/chelsea-injury-news-manchester-united-14524387|date=19 May 2018|department=football.london|accessdate=21 May 2018|title=Drinkwater, David Luiz, Ampadu – latest Chelsea injury news and expected return dates}}</ref>
==International career== Drinkwater made his debut for the [[England national under-18 football team|England under-18 team]] in their 2–0 win over Ghana, where he scored the second goal of the match.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-u18s/News/2009/EnglandGhanareport |title=Super-Dan |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=23 February 2011 |date=20 November 2007}}</ref> His second under-18 cap came in a 2–0 win over [[Austria national under-18 football team|Austria]].<ref name=faprofile>{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/England/All-Teams/Players/D/Danny-Drinkwater |title=Danny Drinkwater |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=11 April 2017}}</ref>
He also made appearances for the [[England national under-19 football team|England under-19s]] between 2008 and 2009. His first appearance came in their match against [[Albania national under-19 football team|Albania]] on 8 October 2008. His final appearance for the England under-19s came against [[Ukraine national under-19 football team|Ukraine]] on 2 August 2009.<ref name=faprofile/>
He was called up to the full [[England national football team|England]] squad for the first time on 17 March 2016, ahead of friendlies against [[Germany national football team|Germany]] and the [[Netherlands national football team|Netherlands]].<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/mar/17/danny-drinkwater-leicester-england|title= Leicester's Danny Drinkwater steps out of shadows to merit England place|date=17 March 2016|newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |accessdate=18 March 2016}}</ref> He made his debut 12 days later in the latter match, a 2–1 loss at [[Wembley Stadium]] in which he was [[man of the match]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Leicester City news: Drinkwater named man of the match on England debut and Vardy's rise continues|url=http://www.leicestermercury.co.uk/Leicester-City-NEWS-Drinkwater-named-man-match/story-29015395-detail/story.html|accessdate=30 March 2016|newspaper=Leicester Mercury|date=29 March 2016}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Drinkwater was named in [[Roy Hodgson]]'s 26-man provisional squad for [[UEFA Euro 2016]] but was one of three players axed for the final selection.<ref>{{cite news|title=Euro 2016: Marcus Rashford in England squad – Townsend and Drinkwater miss out|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36413882|accessdate=31 May 2016|publisher=BBC Sport|date=31 May 2016}}</ref>
