(on loan from [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]) |clubnumber = 40 |youthyears1 = 2010–2017 |youthclubs1 = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] |years1 = 2017– |clubs1 = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] |caps1 = 0 |goals1 = 0 |years2 = 2017–2018 |clubs2 = → [[Forest Green Rovers F.C.|Forest Green Rovers]] (loan) |caps2 = 39 |goals2 = 0 |years3 = 2018– |clubs3 = → [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]] (loan) |caps3 = 26 |goals3 = 0 |club-update = 18:45, 16 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Bradley Ray Collins''' (born 18 February 1997) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays for [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]], on loan from [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]]. ==Career== Born in [[Southampton]], Collins joined [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in 2010 at under-12 level, and signed a scholarship in the summer of 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/teams/on-loan-players/bradley-collins.html|title=Profile|accessdate=1 November 2017|publisher=Chelsea F.C.}}{{cite web|url=https://weaintgotnohistory.sbnation.com/chelsea-fc-transfer-rumours-news/2017/7/7/15934738/chelsea-academy-goalkeeper-bradley-collins-forest-green-rovers-loan|title=Chelsea Academy goalkeeper to spend the season in League Two|date=7 July 2017|accessdate=25 November 2017|publisher=SB Nation}} He turned professional in 2014.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/chelsea/11482537/Who-are-Chelsea-FA-Youth-Cup-wonderkids.html|title=Who are Chelsea's FA Youth Cup wonderkids?|date=27 April 2015|accessdate=1 November 2017|publisher=The Telegraph}} He was the under-18 first-choice goalkeeper for the 2014–15 season, winning the UEFA Youth League and FA Youth Cup. He was the under-19 and under-21 first-choice for the 2015–16 season. In July 2016 he signed a new contract with the club, until June 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2016/07/new-contracts-for-academy-duo.html|title=New contracts for Academy duo|date=1 July 2016|accessdate=1 November 2017|publisher=Chelsea F.C.}} In July 2017 he signed a season-long loan deal with [[EFL League Two|League Two]] club [[Forest Green Rovers F.C.|Forest Green Rovers]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40536581|title=Bradley Collins: Forest Green Rovers sign Chelsea goalkeeper on loan|date=7 July 2017|accessdate=11 July 2017|publisher=BBC Sport}} He made his senior professional debut on 5 August 2017, in a league game against [[Barnet F.C.|Barnet]] which ended in a 2–2 draw. On 31 August 2018, Collins joined [[EFL League One|League One]] side [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]] on loan until January 2019.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45369424|title=Brad Collins: Chelsea goalkeeper joins Burton Albion on loan until January|date=31 August 2018|accessdate=31 August 2018|publisher=BBC web|url=https://www.derbytelegraph.co.uk/burton/chelseas-bradley-collins-extending-loan-2337137|title=Chelsea's Bradley Collins on extending his loan spell with Burton Albion|date=17 December He appeared in 134 [[Primeira Liga]] games over ten seasons, almost always representing [[S.C. Braga|Braga]]. He also played professionally in Italy, Turkey, Croatia and England. After winning the first of his 36 [[Cap (sport)|caps]] for [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] in 2009, Eduardo was part of the squads in two [[FIFA World Cup|World Cups]] and as many [[UEFA European Championship|European Championships]], starting in the [[2010 FIFA World Cup|2010 edition of the former tournament]]. ==Club career== Eduardo was born in [[Mirandela]], [[Bragança District]]. A product of [[S.C. Braga]]'s youth system, he first appeared in the [[Primeira Liga]] during [[2006–07 Primeira Liga|2006–07]] when he served a six-month loan at [[S.C. Beira-Mar]]. In [[2007–08 Primeira Liga|the following season]] he was also loaned, this time to [[Vitória F.C.|Vitória de Setúbal]], and was as a key player in a [[Carlos Carvalhal]]-led side that [[2007–08 Taça da Liga|won]] the inaugural [[Taça da Liga|Portuguese League Cup]] and thus [[2008–09 UEFA Cup|qualified]] for the [[UEFA Europa League|UEFA Cup]], with a ''[[Man of the match]]'' display in the final against [[Sporting Clube de Portugal]] where he saved three attempts in the [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shootout]].{{cite news|url=http://www.record.xl.pt/futebol/futebol-nacional/taca-da-liga/detalhe/carlos-carvalhal-eduardo-da-pontos-e-tacas.html|title=Carlos Carvalhal: "Eduardo dá pontos e Taças"|trans-title=Carlos Carvalhal: "Eduardo gives points and Cups"|newspaper=[[Record (newspaper)|Record]]|language=pt|date=22 March 2008|accessdate=15 January 2016}} Eduardo returned to Braga for the [[2008–09 Primeira Liga|2008–09 campaign]], playing in all the league matches and also in the [[Minho Province|Minho]] team's [[2008–09 UEFA Cup|UEFA Cup round-of-16 run]].{{cite news|url=http://www.record.pt/futebol/futebol-nacional/liga-nos/sp--braga/detalhe/eduardo-arrasado.html|title=Eduardo arrasado|trans-title=Eduardo destroyed|newspaper=Record|language=pt|date=21 March 2009|accessdate=27 February 2018}} The same happened in [[2009–10 Primeira Liga|the following year]] – with them finishing in their best-ever position, second – as he only conceded 20 goals, joint-best in the competition.{{cite web|url=https://www.tsf.pt/desporto/interior/guarda-redes-eduardo-nao-promete-continuidade-no-braga-1568007.html|title=Guarda-redes Eduardo não promete continuidade no Braga|trans-title=Goalkeeper Eduardo does not promise to remain at Braga|publisher=[[TSF (radio station)|TSF]]|language=pt|date=12 May 2010|accessdate=27 February 2018}} On 7 July 2010, Eduardo signed a four-year contract with [[Serie A]]'s [[Genoa C.F.C.]] for €4.8 million,{{cite web|url=http://www.genoacfc.it/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=10055&Itemid=31|title=Un altro colpo Mondiale per il Genoa|trans-title=Another World Cup strike for Genoa|publisher=Genoa C.F.C|language=it|date=7 July 2010|accessdate=8 July 2010}}Genoa C.F.C. S.p.A. ''bilancio'' (financial report and accounts) on 31 December 2010 (in Italian), [http://www.registroimprese.it PDF purchased from Italian C.C.I.A.A.] replacing departed [[Marco Amelia]]. Braga would also receive a 25% future transfer fee if the former sold the player.{{cite web|url=http://www.football-italia.net/jul08r.html|title=Preziosi explains Eduardo deal|publisher=Football Italia|date=8 July 2010|accessdate=8 July 2010}} Eduardo started all the games but one for the Italians in [[2010–11 Serie A|his first and only season]], in a final midtable position. In July 2011 he returned to his country and joined [[S.L. Benfica]] on loan, with the [[Lisbon]] club having an option to buy at the end of [[2011–12 Primeira Liga|the campaign]];{{cite news|url=https://www.jn.pt/desporto/interior/genova-confirma-emprestimo-de-eduardo-ao-benfica-1911948.html|title=Génova confirma empréstimo de Eduardo ao Benfica|trans-title=Genoa confirm loan of Eduardo to Benfica|newspaper=[[Jornal de Notícias]]|language=pt|date=17 July 2011|accessdate=27 February 2018}} during his spell at the ''[[Estádio da Luz]]'', he appeared in only nine competitive matches.{{cite web|url=https://www.vavel.com/pt/futebol-internacional/649659-euro-2016-rx-dos-guarda-redes-eduardo.html|title=Euro 2016: RX dos Guarda-redes – Eduardo|trans-title=Euro 2016: Goalkeeper XR – Eduardo|publisher=[[Vavel]]|language=pt|date=20 May 2016|accessdate=27 February 2018}} On 26 June 2012, Eduardo signed for [[İstanbul Büyükşehir Belediyespor (football)|İstanbul Büyükşehir Belediyespor]] in a temporary deal, joining countryman [[Carlos Carvalhal]] (coach) at the [[Süper Lig]] team.{{cite news|url=http://www.abola.pt/nnh/ver.aspx?id=338688|title=Eduardo no Istambul BB|trans-title=Eduardo to Istambul BB|newspaper=[[A Bola]]|language=pt|date=26 June 2012|accessdate=26 June 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120629032028/http://www.abola.pt/nnh/ver.aspx?id=338688|archivedate=29 June 2012}} The following summer he returned to both Portugal and Braga, while still owned by Genoa.Genoa C.F.C. S.p.A. ''bilancio'' (financial report and accounts) on 31 December 2013 (in Italian), [http://www.registroimprese.it PDF purchased from Italian C.C.I.A.A.] On 27 June 2014, Eduardo joined several compatriots at Croatian side [[GNK Dinamo Zagreb]] after agreeing to a three-year contract.{{cite web|url=http://gnkdinamo.hr/hr/novosti/vijesti/veliko-pojacanje-na-golu-eduardo-potpisao-za-dinamo!.html|title=Veliko pojačanje na golu: Eduardo potpisao za Dinamo!|trans-title=Big boost in goal: Eduardo signs for Dinamo!|publisher=GNK Dinamo Zagreb|language=hr|date=27 June 2014|accessdate=27 June 2014}} On 25 August 2016, after 95 competitive appearances, he signed with [[Premier League]] club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on a one-year deal, being brought in to provide experienced cover and competition to [[Thibaut Courtois]] and [[Asmir Begović]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2016/08/eduardo-transfer-completed.html|title=Eduardo transfer completed|publisher=Chelsea F.C|date=25 August 2016|access-date=25 August 2016}} In spite of his team being crowned [[2016–17 Premier League|league champions]], Eduardo did not receive a medal as he did not appear in any games.{{Cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2017/05/13/which-chelsea-players-wont-receive-premier-league-winners-medals-6634995/|title=Which Chelsea players WON’T receive Premier League winners’ medals?|publisher=Metro|date=13 May 2017|access-date=25 May 2017}} He agreed to a one-year contract extension on 23 May 2017, with technical director [[Michael Emenalo]] calling him "a model professional".{{Cite web|url=https://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2017/05/new-deal-for-eduardo.html|title=New deal for Eduardo|publisher=Chelsea F.C|date=23 May 2017|access-date=23 May 2017}} Despite being listed on Chelsea's released list following the conclusion of [[2017–18 Premier League|2017–18]], Eduardo signed a new one-year contract in July.{{Cite web|url=http://sportwitness.co.uk/chelsea-player-signs-one-year-extension-loaned-strange-move/|title=Chelsea player signs one year extension to be loaned out, strange move|publisher=Sport Witness|author=Lucas Sposito|date=5 July 2018|accessdate=5 July 2018}} Early in the same month, he agreed to join Dutch team [[SBV Vitesse]] on a [[2018–19 Eredivisie|season]]-long loan.{{Cite web|url=https://www.chelseafc.com/en/news/2018/7/6/eduardo-moves-to-vitesse|title=Eduardo loaned to Vitesse|publisher=Chelsea F.C|date=6 July 2018|accessdate=6 July 2018}} He made his competitive web|url=https://www.omroepgelderland.nl/nieuws/2321194/Vitesse-wint-van-Viitorul-en-gaat-door-in-Europa|title=Vitesse wint van Viitorul en gaat door in Europa|trans-title=Vitesse beat Viitorul and {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox football biography |name = Ola Aina |image = Ola Aina 2016.jpg |image_size = 200 |caption = |fullname = Temitayo Olufisayo Olaoluwa Aina{{cite web |url=https://www.premierleague.com/news/612828 |title=Updated squads for 2017/18 Premier League confirmed |publisher=Premier League |date=2 February 2018 |accessdate=10 February 2018}} |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1996|10|8|df=y}}{{cite web |title=Ola Aina |url=http://www.11v11.com/players/ola-aina-250021/|work=11v11.com |publisher=AFS Enterprises|accessdate=16 January 2016}} |birth_place = [[London Borough of Southwark|Southwark]], [[London]], England |height = 1.75 m |position = [[Defender (association_football)#Wing-back|Wing-back]] |currentclub = [[Torino F.C.|Torino]]
(on loan from [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]) |clubnumber = 34 |youthyears1 = 2007–2015 |youthclubs1 = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] |years1 = 2015– |clubs1 = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] |caps1 = 3 |goals1 = 0 |years2 = 2017–2018 |clubs2 = → [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] (loan) |caps2 = 44 |goals2 = 0 |years3 = 2018– |clubs3 = → [[Torino F.C.|Torino]] (loan) |caps3 = 20 |goals3 = 1 |nationalyears1 = 2011–2012 |nationalteam1 = [[England national under-16 football team|England U16]] |nationalcaps1 = 6 |nationalgoals1 = 0 |nationalyears2 = 2012–2013 |nationalteam2 = [[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] |nationalcaps2 = 11 |nationalgoals2 = 0 |nationalyears3 = 2013 |nationalteam3 = [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] |nationalcaps3 = 1 |nationalgoals3 = 0 |nationalyears4 = 2013–2015 |nationalteam4 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] |nationalcaps4 = 13 |nationalgoals4 = 0 |nationalyears5 = 2015–2016 |nationalteam5 = [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] |nationalcaps5 = 6 |nationalgoals5 = 0 |nationalyears6 = 2017– |nationalteam6 = [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] |nationalcaps6 = 8 |nationalgoals6 = 0 |club-update = 16:08, 10 February 2019 (UTC) |ntupdate = 17:05, 17 November 2018 (UTC) }} '''Temitayo Olufisayo Olaoluwa "Ola" Aina''' (born 8 October 1996) is a Nigerian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association_football)#Wing-back|wing-back]] for Italian club [[Torino F.C.|Torino]], on loan from English club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], and the [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria national team]]. ==Club career== ===Chelsea=== ====Early career==== Ola Aina signed for Chelsea as an under-11 and made his youth team debut as a schoolboy in the 2012–13 season and went on to start in both legs of the semi-final and final of the FA Youth Cup. In his youth career, he has also represented Chelsea in the under-18s, under-19s, and under-21 levels.{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/teams/first-team/ola-aina.html |title=Ola Aina Chelsea Profile |accessdate=23 August 2016 |publisher=Chelsea F.C.}} On 19 July 2014, Aina made his first-team debut in a pre-season friendly against [[AFC Wimbledon]], after [[Todd Kane]]'s injury. Aina started the match and was [[Substitute (association football)|substituted]] at half-time for [[Branislav Ivanović]] as Chelsea went on to win 3–2.{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2014/07/afc-wimbledon-v-chelsea.html |title=Match report: AFC Wimbledon 2 Chelsea 3 |date=19 July 2014 |publisher=Chelsea F.C.|accessdate=26 August 2016}} Before the 2015–16 season, he was included in the pre-season tour, playing three matches in the [[2015 International Champions Cup|International Champions Cup]]. After impressing Chelsea manager [[José Mourinho]], Aina was included in the first-team squad for the [[2015–16 Chelsea F.C. season|campaign]]. Although he spent the entire season training full-time with the first-team, he continued his role in the under-21s and under-19s sides. On 23 September 2015, Aina was included in the match-day squad against [[Walsall F.C.|Walsall]] in the fourth round of the [[2015–16 Football League Cup|League Cup]], although he was an unused substitute.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/34265632 |title=Walsall 1–4 Chelsea |date=23 September 2015|publisher=BBC Sports|accessdate=26 August 2016}} Due to a lack of first-team opportunities, Aina refused a new contract despite his current contact ending at the end of the season.{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/arsenal-join-transfer-race-sign-7161465 |title=Arsenal join transfer race to sign Chelsea's England Under-21 right-back Ola Aina |date=11 January 2016|accessdate=26 August 2016}} ====2016–17 season==== On 6 July 2016, he signed a new four-year contract, ending the rumours of him leaving the London side.{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2016/07/aina-seals-new-deal.html |title=Aina seals new deal |date=6 July 2016 |publisher=Chelsea F.C.|accessdate=26 August 2016}} After signing a new contract, Aina was included in the travelling squad to Austria and the United States. He went on to play in all six pre-season matches. On 23 August 2016, Aina was given his professional debut by manager [[Antonio Conte]] in a 3–2 victory over [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]] in the [[2016–17 EFL Cup|EFL Cup]], being replaced by [[John Terry]] in the 77th minute.{{Cite news |title=Chelsea 3–2 Bristol Rovers |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37091061 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 August 2016 |accessdate=23 August 2016}} On 15 October 2016, he made his [[Premier League]] debut in a 3–0 victory over reigning champions [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], replacing goalscorer [[Victor Moses]] in the 82nd minute.{{Cite news |title=Chelsea 3–0 Leicester City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37594219 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=15 October 2016 |accessdate=15 October 2016}} ====Loan to Hull City==== On 11 July 2017, Chelsea announced that they had loaned Aina to [[EFL Championship|Championship]] side [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]].{{Cite news |title=First loan for Aina |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2017/07/aina-out-on-loan.html |publisher=Chelsea Official Site |date=11 July 2017 |accessdate=11 July 2017}} He made his debut on the opening day of the season, 5 August 2017, away to [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]], in a 1–1 draw.{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40760772 | title = Aston Villa 1–1 Hull City | date = 5 August 2017 | work = BBC Sport | publisher = BBC | accessdate = 5 August 2017}} He scored the only goal in a 1–0 defeat of [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] in the third-round of the [[FA Cup]] on 6 January 2018.{{cite news | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42519393 | title = Blackburn Rovers 0–1 Hull City | date = 6 January 2018 | work = BBC Sport | publisher = BBC | accessdate = 6 January 2018}} ====Loan to Torino==== On 14 August 2018, Aina joined Italian club [[Torino F.C.|Torino]] on a season-long loan after signing a new three-year deal with Chelsea.{{Cite news |title=New contract and loan for Aina |url=https://www.chelseafc.com/en/news/2018/8/14/new-contract-and-loan-for-aina |publisher=Chelsea Official Site |date=14 August 2018 |accessdate=14 August 2018}} He made his [[Serie A]] debut a few days later in Torino's 0–1 opening day defeat at home to [[A.S. Roma|Roma]], coming on as a substitute in place of fellow right-back [[Lorenzo De Silvestri]] who went off injured after just 25 minutes.{{cite web|url=http://www.legaseriea.it/en/serie-a/match-report/2018-19/UNICO/UNI/1/TORROM|title=Fixtures and Results - Season 2018-19 - 1^ Match Day - Lega Serie A|website=www.legaseriea.it|accessdate=19 August 2018}} ==International career== ===England youth teams=== Aina has represented England at [[England national under-16 football team|under-16]], [[England national under-17 football team|under-17]], [[England national under-18 football team|under-18]], [[England national under-19 football team|under-19]] and [[England national under-20 football team|England under-20]] levels. ===Nigeria=== [[File:Ola Aina-Nigeria.jpg|thumb|right|Aina with Nigeria against Argentina, Uzomedia]] On 28 March 2017, Aina was pictured alongside [[Chuba Akpom]] of [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] after discussions with [[Nigeria Football Federation]] president, [[Amaju Pinnick]].{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-ng/news/4110/nigerians-abroad/2017/03/28/34076632/chelseas-ola-aina-brighton-and-hove-albions-chuba-akpom|title=Chelsea's Ola Aina, Brighton and Hove Albion's Chuba Akpom pledge allegiance to Nigeria|author=Oludare, Shina|date=28 March 2017|publisher=Goal Nigeria|accessdate=28 March 2017}} In May 2017, Aina pledged his international future to Nigeria and obtained a Nigerian passport in preparation to making the switch from England to Nigeria.{{cite web|url=http://dailypost.ng/2017/05/12/nff-confirms-ola-aina-joel-bazee-now-nigerian-passports-tammy-abraham-follow/|title=NFF confirms Ola Aina, Joel Bazee now have Nigerian passports, Tammy Abraham to follow|date=12 May 2017|publisher=|accessdate=15 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=http://www.vanguardngr.com/2017/05/nff-formally-applies-ainas-intl-switch/|title=NFF formally applies for Aina's int'l switch – Vanguard News|date=4 May 2017|publisher=|accessdate=15 May 2017}}{{cite web|url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/football/3481081/chelsea-ola-aina-nigeria-england/|title=Chelsea's London-born starlet Ola Aina poised to snub England and play for Nigeria|date=4 May 2017|publisher=|accessdate=15 May 2017}} In the same month, he was called up for the first time to play for Nigeria.{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/nigeria/story/3122106/chelseas-ola-aina-gets-nigeria-call|title=Chelsea's Ola Aina gets Nigeria call|publisher=|accessdate=17 May 2017}} In May 2018 he was named in Nigeria’s preliminary 30 man [[Nigeria national football team| squad]] for the [[2018 World Cup]] in [[Russia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/amp/news/revealed-every-world-cup-2018-squad-23-man-preliminary-lists/oa0atsduflsv1nsf6oqk576rb|title=Revealed: Every World Cup 2018 squad - 23-man & preliminary lists & when will they be announced? |website= Goal.com|publisher=|accessdate=17 May 2018}} However, he did not make the final 23.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44346451|title=World Cup 2018: Arsenal's Iwobi in Nigeria's 23-man squad|date=3 June 2018|publisher=|accessdate=20 August 2018|work=BBC Sport}} ==Club nationalteam-update = 21:43, 21 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Trevoh Tom Chalobah''' (born 5 July 1999) is an English professional footballer who plays for [[EFL Championship]] club [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] on loan from [[Premier League]] club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]. ==Club career== ===Chelsea=== Born in [[Freetown]], [[Sierra Leone]], Chalobah signed his first professional contract with Chelsea in June 2016 and signed a new contract in March 2018.{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2018/03/chalobah-commits.html|title=Chalobah commits|publisher=Chelsea F.C.|accessdate=20 May 2018}} His youth honours at Chelsea include the [[UEFA Youth League]] in 2015–16, the [[FA Youth Cup]] in 2015–16 and 2016–17, and the [[Professional Development League|Under-18 Premier League]] in 2016–17.{{cite web|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/trevoh-chalobah-enjoys-danceoff-with-brother-nathaniel-as-chelsea-under18s-celebrate-fa-youth-cup-a3525231.html?amp|title=Chalobah brothers perform dance-off after FA Youth Cup win|work=London Evening Standard|accessdate=20 May 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/04/28/who-are-chelseas-fa-youth-cup-winning-stars/trevoh-chalobah/|title=Who are Chelsea's FA Youth Cup winning stars?|work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=20 May 2018}} He was named by [[Antonio Conte]] as a substitute for the [[2018 FA Cup Final]] victory against [[Manchester United]] on 19 May 2018 at [[Wembley Stadium]] despite never having previously played a professional game.{{cite web|url=https://www.talksport.com/football/chelsea-news-who-trevoh-chalobah-youngster-bench-fa-cup-final?amp|title=Chelsea FC news: Who is Trevoh Chalobah, Blues youngster on bench for FA Cup final|first=Billy|last=Hawkins|date=19 May 2018|publisher=Talksport|accessdate=20 May 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/962290/Chelsea-team-news-Blues-name-shock-player-not-in-FA-Cup-programme/amp|title=Chelsea team news: Blues name shock player NO-ONE knows... he's not in FA Cup programme – Football|work=Daily Express|accessdate=20 May 2018}} Chelsea won the match 1–0, and Chalobah did not enter the field. ====Ipswich Town (loan)==== He signed for [[EFL Championship]] club [[Ipswich Town]] on a season-long loan deal in June 2018,{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44606798|title=Trevoh Chalobah: Chelsea's England youth international joins Ipswich Town on loan|date=25 June 2018|publisher=BBC Sport}} and made his professional debut on 4 August, starting in a 2–2 draw with [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]].{{cite web |title=Chelsea’s great defensive talent makes impressive senior debut |url=https://www.chelsea-news.co/2018/08/vide-chelseas-great-defensive-talent-makes-impressive-senior-debut/ |website=Chelsea News |accessdate=7 August 2018 |date=7 August 2018}}{{cite news |last1=Salt |first1=Nathan |title=How did Premier League loan stars get on in the Football League? |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-6031199/As-Mason-Mount-scores-Derby-did-Premier-League-loan-stars-fare-Football-League.html |accessdate=7 August 2018 |work=Daily Mail |date=6 August 2018}} Two weeks later he scored his first goal, equalising in a 1–1 draw with [[Aston Villa]] at [[Portman Road]].{{cite news |title=Ipswich Town 1–1 Aston Villa |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45152569 |accessdate=18 August 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=18 August 2018}} ==International career== He has represented England at youth level from Under-16 up to Under-19, captaining all three teams at various stages. In November 2014, Chalobah captained the [[England national under-16 football team|England under-16 team]] against [[Scotland national under-16 football team|Scotland]] in the [[Victory Shield]].{{cite news |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2014/nov/20/england-u16-scotland-victory-shield-report |title=England U16s see off Scotland in Victory Shield encounter|first=Jamie |last=Bradbury |publisher=The Football Association |date=20 November 2014 |accessdate=25 October 2018}} In May 2016, Chalobah was captain of the [[England national under-17 football team|England under-17 team]] that lost to [[Spain national under-17 football team|Spain]] in the quarter-final of the [[2016 UEFA European Under-17 Championship]].{{cite news |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2016/may/15/spain-england-report-150516 |title=England Under-17s miss out on semi-final after loss to Spain|first=Peter |last=Maxwell |publisher=The Football Association |date=15 May 2016 |accessdate=25 October 2018}} Chalobah was included in the [[England national under-19 football team|England under-19]] squad for the [[2017 UEFA European Under-19 Championship]].{{cite news |title=Young Lions squad for U19 Euro|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2017/jun/26/england-u19-squad-for-euros-260617 |accessdate=25 October 2018 |publisher=The Football Association |date=26 June 2017}} An ankle injury sustained in the final group game against [[Germany national youth football team#Germany national under-19 squad|Germany]] ruled him out for the rest of the tournament.{{cite news |title=Same again please|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2017/jul/11/euro-u19-semi-final-preview-110717 |accessdate=25 October 2018 |publisher=The Football Association |date=11 July 2017}} England went on to defeat [[Portugal national under-19 football team|Portugal]] in the final.{{cite web|title=European Under-19 Championship: England beat Portugal in final|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40619862|publisher=BBC Sport|date=15 July 2017|accessdate=25 October 2018}} ==Personal life== His brother [[Nathaniel Chalobah]] is also a professional footballer; he has played for Chelsea and [[S.S.C. Napoli]] and is now at [[Watford F.C.|Watford]].{{cite web|url=https://www.football.london/chelsea-fc/players/chelsea-wonderkids-abramovich-ampadu-chalobah-14257525|title=The Chelsea wonderkids Abramovich must not ignore this summer|first=Oliver|last=Harbord|date=19 April 2018|website=Football.london|accessdate=20 May 2018}} ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 10 February 2019}} {| class=wikitable style="text-align: center" |+ Appearances and goals by club, season and competition |- !rowspan=2|Club !rowspan=2|Season !colspan=3|League !colspan=2|[[FA Cup]] !colspan=2|[[EFL Cup]] !colspan=2|Other !colspan=2|Total |- !Division!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals!!Apps!!Goals |- |rowspan=3|[[Chelsea F.C. On 11 January 2017, along with Chelsea teammates [[Charlie Colkett]] and [[Islam Feruz]], Dabo joined League One side [[Swindon Town F.C.|Swindon Town]] on loan for the remainder of the 2016–17 season.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38589947|title=Charlie Colkett, Islam Feruz and Fankaty Dabo: Chelsea trio join Swindon on loan|date=11 January 2017|accessdate=12 January 2017|publisher=BBC Sport}} Three days later, Dabo made his Swindon Town debut in a 2–1 away victory against Bolton Wanderers, featuring for the entire 90 minutes. On 5 February 2017, Dabo scored his first goal for Swindon in their local derby against [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]]. On 25 June 2017, Dabo joined Dutch side [[SBV Vitesse|Vitesse]] on a season-long loan.{{Cite news |title=Vitesse loan for defender Dabo |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2017/06/vitesse-loan-for-defender-dabo.html |publisher=Chelsea Official Site |date=25 June 2017 |accessdate=25 June 2017}} In August 2018 Dabo returned on loan to the Netherlands, this time with [[Sparta Rotterdam]].https://www.sparta-rotterdam.nl/fankaty-dabo-komt-chelsea/ ==International career== Dabo was born in England and is of Sierra Leonean descent.{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/teams/on-loan-players/fankaty-dabo.html|title=Fankaty Dabo|website=www.chelseafc.com}} He has represented England at [[England national under-16 football team|under-16]], [[England national under-17 football team|under-17]] and [[England national under-20 football team|under-20]] youth levels.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/england/all-teams/players/d/fankaty-dabo|title=Profile|accessdate=14 January 2017|publisher=The Football Association}} ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 12 May |nationalgoals6 = 0 |club-update = 12:46, 10 March 2019 (UTC) |nationalteam-update = 18:28, 16 October 2018 (UTC) }} '''Jay Rhys Dasilva''' (born 22 April 1998) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)|defender]] for {{English football updater|BristolC}} club [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]], on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] from {{English football updater|Chelsea}} club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], and the [[England national under-21 football team|England national under-21 team]]. ==Club career== ===Chelsea=== Dasilva joined Chelsea from [[Luton Town F.C.|Luton Town]] in 2012, aged just thirteen, along with his brothers Cole and Rio,{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2088254/Jay-Rio-Cole-Dasilva-Footballing-brothers-aged-just-12-13-signed-Chelsea.html|title=Now that's a hat-trick! The three footballing brothers aged just 12 and 13 signed by Chelsea in deal that could net their club £1m|date=18 January 2012|accessdate=14 January 2017|newspaper=Daily Mail|location=London}} and was quickly integrated into the club's youth setup, making his under-18 debut as an under-15 the following year. The following season, he made 23 appearances for the youth team, including scoring in the [[2013–14 FA Youth Cup]] final first leg against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2615464/Fulham-3-Chelsea-2-Charly-Musondas-late-strike-boosts-Blues-Youth-Cup-final.html|title=Fulham 3 Chelsea 2: Charly Musonda's late strike boosts Blues in Youth Cup final|date=29 April 2014|accessdate=14 January 2017|newspaper=Daily Mail|location=London}} During his second full season with the under-18s, Dasilva won the [[2014–15 FA Youth Cup]], as well as the [[2014–15 UEFA Youth League]], playing all but one game in the UEFA Youth League. He signed his first professional contract in July 2015,{{cite web|url=http://www.squawka.com/news/chelsea-sign-jay-dasilva-to-a-professional-contract/415188|title=Chelsea sign Jay Da Silva to a professional contract|date=10 July 2015|accessdate=14 January 2017|publisher=Squawka}} having forced himself into Chelsea's under-21 side, where he established himself as a key player over the next year. He became one of the only players in history to win three [[FA Youth Cup]]s, alongside teammate [[Jake Clarke-Salter]] and five of the famed [[Busby Babes]], when he was part of the Chelsea side that lifted the [[2015–16 FA Youth Cup]].{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/teams/on-loan-players/jay-dasilva.html|title=Jay Dasilva|accessdate=14 January 2017|publisher=Chelsea F.C.}} He was also a member of the Chelsea side that claimed the [[2015–16 UEFA Youth League]], however he was an unused substitute in the final victory against [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|PSG]].{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefayouthleague/season=2016/matches/round=2000699/match=2019575/index.html|title=Chelsea defeat Paris to retain Youth League title|date=18 April 2016|accessdate=14 January 2017|publisher=UEFA}} ====Charlton Athletic (loan)==== On 30 December 2016, Dasilva was loaned to [[EFL League One|League One]] side [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]].{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2016/12/charlton-loan-move-for-dasilva.html|title=Charlton loan move for Dasilva|date=30 December 2016|accessdate=14 January 2017|publisher=Chelsea F.C.}} He made his debut for ''The Addicks'' on 14 January 2017, coming on as a substitute for [[Lewis Page]] against [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]]. He was brought on in the 28th minute, but was later substituted in the 80th minute of the game.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/38539095|title=Charlton Athletic 0–0 Millwall|date=14 January 2017|accessdate=14 January 2017|publisher=BBC Sport}} On 4 April 2017, Dasilva was given his first start for Charlton by manager [[Karl Robinson]], in their 2–0 home defeat against [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]], featuring for the entire 90 minutes.{{Cite news |title=Charlton Athletic 0–2 Milton Keynes Dons |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39312460 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 April 2017 |accessdate=29 April 2017}} On 21 July 2017, Dasilva signed a new contract with Chelsea until 2021 and rejoined Charlton Athletic for a second loan spell.{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2017/07/new-deal-and-loan-for-dasilva.html|title=New deal and loan for Dasilva|date=21 July 2017|accessdate=21 July 2017|publisher=Chelsea F.C.}} On 7 May 2018, Dasilva was voted the 2017–18 Fans Player of the Year.{{cite web|url=https://www.cafc.co.uk/news/view/5af08928d8cc1/jay-dasilva-named-201718-player-of-the-year|title=Jay Dasilva named 2017/18 Player of the Year|date=7 May 2018|accessdate=14 May 2018|publisher=Charlton Athletic F.C.}} ====Bristol City (loan)==== On 9 August 2018, Dasilva joined [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] on a season long loan from Chelsea.[https://www.bcfc.co.uk/news/city-sign-chelsea-defender-dasilva/ City sign Chelsea defender Dasilva] [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]]. 9 August 2018. Retrieved 9 August 2018. ==International career== Dasilva has represented England at [[England national under-16 football team|under-16]], [[England national under-17 football team|under-17]], [[England national under-18 football team|under-18]],{{cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/england/all-teams/players?p=354511|title=Profile|accessdate=14 January 2017|publisher=The Football Association}} [[England national under-19 football team|under-19]],{{cite web |title=England's matches: The under 19's: 2010–20 |url=http://www.englandfootballonline.com/MatchRsl/MatchRslTmU19pg2.html |website=England Football Online |publisher=Chris Goodwin, Glen Isherwood & Peter Young |date=20 July 2018 |accessdate=11 August 2018}} [[England national under-20 football team|under-20]]{{cite web |title=England's matches: The under 20's |url=http://www.englandfootballonline.com/MatchRsl/MatchRslTmU20.html |website=England Football Online |publisher=Chris Goodwin, Glen Isherwood & Peter Young |date=28 March 2018 |accessdate=11 August 2018}} and [[England national under-21 football team|under-21]] youth levels.{{cite web |title=England's matches: The under 21's: 2010–20 |url=http://www.englandfootballonline.com/MatchRsl/MatchRslTmU21pg4.html |website=England Football Online |publisher=Chris Goodwin, Glen Isherwood & Peter Young |date=9 June 2018 |accessdate=11 August 2018}} He was called up to the England under-16 team shortly after joining Chelsea's youth ranks for a [[Victory Shield]] game against [[Scotland national under-16 football team|Scotland]].{{cite '''Joshua David Grant''' (born August 7, 1967) is a retired American professional [[basketball player]]. The 6'9" (2.06 m), 223 pound (101 kg) [[Forward (basketball)|forward]] graduated from [[East High School (Salt Lake City)|East High School]] in [[Salt Lake City, Utah]] in 1986<ref name=autogenerated4>http://utahutes.cstv.com/genrel/040808aaa.html, accessed November 15, 2010.</ref> and attended the [[University of Utah]], where he was an important player and still holds multiple basketball records. Among other honors, Grant was named to Utah's All-Century Men's Basketball Team on February 12, 2008<ref>University of Utah's All-Century {{cite web |url=http://utahutes.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/021208aaa.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-07-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217221956/http://utahutes.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/021208aaa.html |archivedate=2013-12-17 |df= }}, accessed November 15, 2010</ref> and was inducted into the University's Crimson Club Hall of Fame on April 8, 2008.<ref name=autogenerated1 />
Grant was selected with the sixteenth pick of the second round of the 1993 NBA draft (43rd pick overall) by the Denver Nuggets and was traded to the Golden State Warriors on a draft night trade.<ref name=autogenerated9 /> Grant played for the Warriors during the 1993-1994 season, and then played abroad for several years.
==College career==
Grant played for the [[Utah Utes men's basketball|University of Utah Utes]] from 1988-1993 (he was forced to take a medical red-shirt year because of a knee injury during the 1991-92 season).
Grant played under coach [[Lynn Archibald]] for one season, and then under [[Rick Majerus]] for the rest of his college career. The period during which Grant played under Majerus marked the beginning of a highly successful period for the Utes under Majerus throughout the 1990s, which culminated with the Utes' appearance in the NCAA championship game in 1998. The Utes won [[Western Athletic Conference|WAC]] regular season championships in 1991 and 1993, and the 1991 team went to the Sweet Sixteen of the NCAA Tournament, eventually being eliminated by [[Jerry Tarkanian|Jerry Tarkanian's]] defending champion [[UNLV Runnin' Rebels basketball|UNLV Runnin' Rebels]] to finish 30-4 for the season.<ref>Utah Utes 1990-91 Season, http://utahutes.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/archive/utah-m-baskbl-yearlyres.html, accessed November 15, 2010.</ref> Grant was the captain of the Utah team for three years (1991, 1992, 1993).<ref name=autogenerated2>http://utahutes.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/archive/utah-m-baskbl-captains.html, accessed November 15, 2010.</ref>
=== Honors ===
Grant received many honors for his collegiate career at Utah, where he was a four-year letter earner (1989, 1990, 1991, 1993).<ref name=autogenerated3>http://utahutes.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/archive/061200aaj.html, accessed November 15, 2010</ref> He was first-team all-WAC twice (1991, 1993) <ref name=autogenerated10 /> and second team all-WAC once (1990).<ref name=autogenerated8>http://utahutes.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/archive/061200aag.html, accessed November 15, 2010.</ref> Grant was named WAC player of the year twice (1991, 1993),<ref name=autogenerated10>{{cite web |url=http://utahutes.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/021208aaa.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-07-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217221956/http://utahutes.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/021208aaa.html |archivedate=2013-12-17 |df= }}, accessed November 15, 2010.</ref> and during those same two years, was also named to the WAC All-Tournament Team,<ref name=autogenerated5>http://www.wacsports.com/pdf4/386683.pdf, accessed November 15, 2010.</ref> and the Utes won WAC regular-season championships.<ref name=autogenerated6>http://utahutes.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/archive/utah-m-baskbl-yearlyres.html, accessed November 15, 2010.</ref>
In 2008, Grant was honored by the University of Utah as part of its men's basketball program's centennial celebration when he was named to the University of Utah Men's Basketball "All Century Team" on February 12, 2008.<ref name=autogenerated10 /> Grant was also honored on April 8, 2008, when he was inducted to the University of Utah's Crimson Club Hall of Fame in 2008.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web |url=http://www.crimsonclub.utah.edu/RelatedLinks-HOFInductees.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-01-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720103611/http://www.crimsonclub.utah.edu/RelatedLinks-HOFInductees.htm |archivedate=2011-07-20 |df= }} & http://utahutes.cstv.com/genrel/040808aaa.html, accessed November 15, 2010.</ref>
Grant also participated in several events that are among some of the most memorable in Utah men's basketball history. He dunked over 7'6" center Sean Bradley of arch-rival [[Brigham Young University|BYU]] on February 16, 1991, which was voted as the 41st greatest moment in Utah basketball history.<ref>Moment 41, 100 Greatest Moments in Utah Basketball History, http://utahutes.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/utah-baskbl-41-70.html, accessed November 15, 2010.</ref> Other events of the 100 Greatest Moments in Utah's Basketball History that Grant participated in include:
* 33. March 17, 1991 - Utah 85 Michigan State 84 to go to Sweet 16. The game went to double overtime, and Grant had 29 points for the Utes.<ref>http://utahutes.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/utah-baskbl-18-40.html , accessed November 15, 2010.</ref> * 42. March 2, 1991 - Utah beats BYU 72-71 OT (30-4 season).<ref>http://utahutes.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/utah-baskbl-41-70.html, accessed November 15, 2010.</ref> * 72. Feb 16, 1991 - Utah wins WAC with an 81-74 victory over BYU.<ref name="utahutes.cstv.com">http://utahutes.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/utah-baskbl-71-100.html, accessed November 15, 2010.</ref> * 98. Feb 27, 1993 - Largest crowd ever recorded in the [[Huntsman Center]] (15,755).<ref name="utahutes.cstv.com"/>
=== Records === Grant holds multiple records in many categories for Utah, including several all-time records, such as: * Third highest scorer all-time with 2000 total points.<ref name=autogenerated7>{{cite web|url=http://utahutes.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/archive/061200aac.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070914101928/http://utahutes.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/archive/061200aac.html |archivedate=2007-09-14 |df= }}, accessed November 15, 2010.</ref> * Third in total rebounds with 1066.<ref name=autogenerated7 /> * Most total offensive rebounds with 337.<ref name=autogenerated7 /> * Second in total defensive rebounds with 839.<ref name=autogenerated7 /> * Fourth in total field goals made with 727.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://utahutes.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/archive/061200aac.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-12-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070914101928/http://utahutes.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/archive/061200aac.html |archivedate=2007-09-14 |df= }}, accessed November 15, 2010</ref> * Third in total three-point field goals made with 153.<ref name=autogenerated7 /> * Second in all-time steals with 191.<ref name=autogenerated7 /> * Seventh in all-time assists with 387.<ref name=autogenerated7 /> * Fourth in blocked shots with 109.<ref name=autogenerated7 /> * Third in total games played with 131.<ref name=autogenerated7 />
Grant also holds many Utah records for individual games or seasons,<ref>[http://utahutes.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/archive/061200aak.html Miscellaneous Records - The Official Athletic Site of the University of Utah<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120307135809/http://utahutes.cstv.com/sports/m-baskbl/archive/061200aak.html |date=2012-03-07 }}</ref> as well as several WAC records, which are not listed here.
==Professional career==
Josh Grant was drafted as the 16th pick of the second round in the 1993 NBA draft (43rd overall) by the Denver Nuggets and was traded to the Golden State Warriors in a draft night trade with a 1994 second-round draft pick (eventually used to select [[Anthony Miller (basketball)|Anthony Miller]] of Michigan) for [[Darnell Mee]].<ref name=autogenerated9>Josh Grant, https://www.basketball-reference.com, accessed November 15, 2010.</ref> Grant played for the Warriors during the 1993-1994 season before playing abroad for several years.
Despite having a relatively positive scouting report,<ref>Josh Grant, 1993 Usenet Draft, http://www.ibiblio.org/craig/draft/1993_draft/scout/sf.html, accessed November 15, 2010.</ref> Grant was waived after one season. During the 1993-94 season, Grants statistics were:
{{NBA player statistics start}} |- | align="left" | [[1993–94 NBA season|1993–94]] | align="left" | [[Golden State Warriors|Golden State]] | 53 || 0 || '''7.2''' || .404 || .279 || .759 || 1.7 || 0.5 || 0.3 || 0.2 || 3.0 {{s-end}}
Grant played professionally in Europe for nine more years, playing on teams in Spain, France, Greece and Italy.<ref name=autogenerated4 />
==Personal==
Grant graduated from [[East High School (Salt Lake City)|East High School]] in Salt Lake City in 1986, where he was an all-state player twice, and was named the Gatorade Player of the Year in Utah as a senior, after leading his team to a third-place finish in the state tournament.<ref name=autogenerated4 />
Grant also served a two-year mission for [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] in London from 1986 to 1988.<ref>http://utahutes.cstv.com/genrel/040808aaa.html ,accessed November 15, 2010.</ref>
After his basketball career, Grant earned a master's degree in teaching. He was a history teacher and head boys' basketball coach at Lake Forrest High School and [[Niles West High School]] in the Chicago, Illinois area.<ref name=autogenerated4 />
Grant currently works as a regional development officer for the University of Utah, as part of the University's outreach program to alumni and friends. As part of this job, he travels around the country meeting alums and working to establish new relationships and strengthen ties with alums and friends on behalf of the university.<ref>http://togetherwereach.net/newsletter/stories/spring_2010/mgo.html, accessed November 15, 2010.</ref>

'''Michael Anthony James Hector''' (born 19 July 1992) is a professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)|centre back]] for [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] on loan from [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]].{{cite web |url=https://www.skysports.com/football/news/11703/11486918/michael-hector-joins-sheffield-wednesday-from-chelsea-on-loan |title=Michael Hector joins Sheffield Wednesday from Chelsea on loan |publisher=SkySports |date=31 August 2018 |accessdate=1 September 2018}} Hector began his career in the youth teams at [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] and [[Thurrock F.C.|Thurrock]] before moving to [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] in 2009 where he joined the Academy. In his first two seasons at the club he spent time on loan at a succession of [[Non-league football|non-league]] sides including [[Didcot Town F.C.|Didcot Town]], [[Oxford City F.C.|Oxford City]] and [[Horsham F.C.|Horsham]]. Hector signed professional terms with Reading in May 2010 and joined [[League of Ireland]] side [[Dundalk F.C.|Dundalk]] on loan in February 2011. He made his [[The Football League|Football League]] debut for [[Barnet F.C.|Barnet]] in November 2011 and his successful spell with the club culminated with Hector winning the Young Player of the Season award. He signed a new contract at Reading in summer 2012 and soon after joined [[Shrewsbury F.C.|Shrewsbury]] on a six-month loan. Another temporary spell, this time with [[Aldershot Town F.C.|Aldershot Town]] followed, before moving to [[Cheltenham Town F.C.|Cheltenham Town]] on loan in January 2013. He spent the first half of the 2013–14 season at [[Aberdeen F.C.|Aberdeen]] and made his Reading debut in January 2014.{{citation needed|date=December 2017}} Hector was born in England but chose to represent [[Jamaica national football team|Jamaica]] at international level, being selected in their squad for the [[2015 Copa América]]. == Club career == === Early career === Hector was born in [[East Ham]], London. He began his career at [[Millwall F.C.|Millwall]] before moving on to [[Thurrock F.C.|Thurrock]] where he played in the youth team. He was spotted by [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] after playing against them in a friendly for Barking Abbey and joined on scholarship terms at the start of the 2009–10 season.{{cite news |url=http://www.getbracknell.co.uk/sport/football/readingfc/s/2102256_reading_fc_defender_knows_he_has_a_hec_of_a_chance |last=Fordham |first=Jonny |title=Reading FC defender knows he has a Hec of a chance |newspaper=Bracknell Forest Standard |date=27 October 2011 |accessdate=9 February 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/team/player-profile/index.aspx?playerid=451949&tcmuri=181062 Town]] in November.{{cite news |url=http://www.getwokingham.co.uk/sport/football/goalpost/s/2058952_bracknell_town_fc_2_frome_town_fc_3 |last=Freeland |first=Darrell |title=Bracknell Town FC 2 Frome 2010–11 season again saw Hector go out on several loan spells. news |url=http://www.oxfordmail.co.uk/sport/8345458.FOOTBALL__Brooks_leaves_Oxford_City_as_three_arrive/ |title=Brooks leaves Oxford City as three arrive |newspaper=Oxford Mail |accessdate=9 February |url=http://www.hornetsreview.co.uk/Archive/2010-11/Billericay%28h%29.htm |title=Horsham 1 Bellericay Town 2 |publisher=Horsham F.C |accessdate=9 February 2013 |deadurl=yes extend Hector loan |newspaper=West Sussex County Times |accessdate=9 February 2013}} His spell at Horsham was marred by three red cards, including two dismissals in successive games prompting manager John Maggs to accuse referees of "destroying" the young defender.{{cite news |url=http://www.wscountytimes.co.uk/sport/football/local-football/maggs-slams-referees-over-hector-red-cards-1-2335627 |title=Maggs slams referees over Hector red cards |newspaper=West Sussex County Times |accessdate=9 February 2013}} ==== Dundalk ==== On 1 February 2011, days after returning from Horsham, Hector |publisher=Dundalk F.C |accessdate=9 February 2013}} The red cards received during his time at Horsham meant Hector was unable to officially sign for Dundalk until 16 February though he played in four pre-season friendlies in the meantime.{{cite web |url=http://www.dundalkfc.com/focus-on-hector/ |title=Focus on Hector! |publisher=Dundalk F.C |accessdate=9 February 2013}} His competitive debut came |url=http://www.dundalkfc.com/players-2013/first-team-squad/michael-hector/ |title=First team squad: Michael Hector |publisher=Dundalk F.C |accessdate=9 February 2013}} Although Dundalk had initially hoped to extend Hector's loan for the rest of the season, he suffered a knee injury in May and he returned to Reading the following month.{{cite web |url=http://www.dundalkfc.com/hector-to-remain-with-reading/ |title=Hector to remain with Reading |publisher=Dundalk F.C |accessdate=9 February 2013}} ==== The Football League ==== Hector spent the next five months working his way back to full fitness and on 3 November he joined [[EFL League Two|League Two]] side [[Barnet F.C.|Barnet]] on an initial one-month youth loan.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15582242 |title=Barnet sign defenders Paul Downing and Michael Hector |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=9 February 2013}} After an impressive start to his spell his loan was extended for a further month, and, on 23 December, was renewed until the end of the season.{{cite news |newspaper=Barnet & Potters Bar Times |accessdate=9 February 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://www.london24.com/sport/barnet_extend_loans_of_reading_and_west_brom_youngsters_1_1162334 |title=Barnet extend February 2013}} No move materialised though and Hector signed a new contract at Reading in summer 2012.{{cite web |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10306~2756901,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120620160401/http://www.readingfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0%2C%2C10306~2756901%2C00.html |archivedate=20 June 2012 |title=Royals aim to extend ten contracts |accessdate=9 February 2013 |deadurl=yes}} On 24 July he joined [[EFL League One|League One]] side [[Shrewsbury Town F.C.|Shrewsbury Town]] on a six-month loan but after falling out of contention, he returned to Reading on 7 November to train and play reserve games.{{cite web |publisher=Reading F.C |title=Hector Loaned |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/news/article/hector-loaned-262161.aspx F.C.|Aldershot Town]] until 1 January.{{cite web |url=http://www.shrewsburytown.com/news/article/22nov12-helan-and-hector-recalled-502375.aspx?pageView=full |title=Loanees return to Reading and Man City |publisher=Shrewsbury Town F.C |accessdate=22 November 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/news/article/loan-update-211112-501680.aspx |title=Loan Update |publisher=Reading F.C web |url=http://www.ctfc.com/news/article/hector-on-loan-628297.aspx |title=Hector in on loan |publisher=Cheltenham Town F.C |accessdate=30 January 2013}} He made his debut in a 2–1 win over [[Torquay United F.C.|Torquay United]] on 2 February and earned praise from manager [[Mark Yates (footballer)|Mark Yates]] for his performance.{{cite web |url=http://www.ctfc.com/news/article/yates-post-torquay-h-633475.aspx |title=We were excellent |publisher=Cheltenham Town F.C |accessdate=29 January 2016}} On 28 February his loan was extended for another month{{cite web |url=http://www.ctfc.com/news/article/hector-extends-loan-685541.aspx |title=Hector extends loan |publisher=Cheltenham Town F.C |accessdate=28 February 2013}} and at the end of |publisher=Cheltenham Town F.C |accessdate=28 March 2013}} He scored his first Cheltenham goal with the winner against [[Gillingham F.C.|Gillingham]] on 13 April, securing a play-off spot for the club in the process.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22049487 |title=Cheltenham 1–0 Gillingham |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=14 April 2013}} He played in both legs of the play-off Town 0–1 Northampton Town |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=8 May 2013}} ==== Aberdeen ==== On 26 July 2013, Hector joined [[Aberdeen F.C.|Aberdeen]] on loan for six months.{{cite web |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/news/article/hector-joins-aberdeen-947231.aspx |title=Hector agrees Dons loan |publisher=Reading F.C |accessdate=26 July 2013}} Upon his arrival Aberdeen manager [[Derek McInnes]] described him as "a big strong lad who comes with a good pedigree".{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25449776 |title=Aberdeen's on-loan defender Michael Hector in Reading return |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=22 December 2013}} In November, he scored his only goal for the Dons with a 20-yard strike in a 4–0 win against [[Partick Thistle F.C.|Partick Thistle]].{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/24699697 |title=Aberdeen 4–0 Partick Thistle |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=22 December 2013}} It was confirmed the following month that Hector's spell would not be extended due to an injury crisis at his parent club,{{cite news |url=http://www.getreading.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/michael-hector-wants-return-reading-6375049 |last=Watts |first=Charles |date=5 December 2013 |title=Michael Hector wants to return to Reading FC and realise his dream |newspaper=Reading Post |accessdate=6 January 2014}} though McInnes was hopeful that he could re-sign him at the end of the transfer window providing Reading's situation improved.{{cite web |url=http://sport.stv.tv/football/clubs/aberdeen/259208-derek-mcinnes-not-giving-up-on-extending-michael-hectors-aberdeen-loan/ |title=Derek McInnes not giving up on extending Michael Hector's Aberdeen loan |publisher=STV Sport |accessdate=6 January 2014}} Hector became a fans' favourite and despite not re-signing for the Dons, travelled to Glasgow to watch Aberdeen win the [[2014 Scottish League Cup Final]]. === Reading === Hector made his debut as a late substitute in Reading's 7–1 win over [[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]] in January 2014.{{cite web |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/news/article/report-bolton-h-180144-1302188.aspx |title=Royals put seven past Bolton |publisher=Reading F.C |accessdate=19 January 2014}} He made two |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/news/article/four-changes-for-royals-1405646.aspx |title=Four changes for Royals |publisher=Reading F.C |accessdate=9 March 2014}} He went on to make nine appearances in total, including four starts,{{Soccerbase season|55414|2013|name=Michael Hector|accessdate=9 March 2014}} and at the end of the season was offered a new contract,{{cite web |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/news/article/hector-taylor-to-discuss-deals-060514-1539489.aspx |title=Hector & Taylor to discuss deals |publisher=Reading F.C |accessdate=11 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140507033114/http://www.readingfc.co.uk/news/article/hector-taylor-to-discuss-deals-060514-1539489.aspx |archivedate=7 May 2014 |deadurl=unfit}} which he signed in May, keeping him with the club until 2016 with the option of a further year.{{cite web |title=Taylor and Hector agree deals |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/news/article/hector-and-taylor-agree-deals-300513-1591485.aspx |publisher=Reading F.C |accessdate=30 May 2014}} The following summer Hector signed a new three-year contract with Reading until the summer of 2018.{{cite web |title=Hector pens new three-year deal |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/news/article/hector-signs-new-contract-010615-2476829.aspx |publisher=Reading F.C. |accessdate=1 June 2015 |date=1 June 2015}} === Chelsea === In a deadline day deal, Hector signed for Premier League club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] on 1 September 2015. As part of the deal, he was sent back on loan to [[Reading F.C.|Reading]] for the 2015–16 season.{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2015/09/hector-deal-completed.html |title=Hector deal completed |publisher=Chelsea F.C.}} Hector returned to Chelsea on 28 April 2016, a week before his loan deal was due to expire.{{cite web |title=Chelsea duo return to the Bridge |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/news/article/chelsea-duo-lucas-piazon-michael-hector-return-stamford-bridge-3083631.aspx |publisher=Reading F.C. |accessdate=28 April 2016}} After the arrival of [[Antonio Conte]], Hector trained with the first-team and was included in the squad of the Austrian tour and U.S. tour during [[2016–17 Chelsea F.C. season#Pre-season|pre-season]].{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2016/08/frankfurt-switch-for-hector.html |title=Frankfurt switch for Hector |date=14 August 2016 |publisher=Chelsea F.C.}} ==== Eintracht Frankfurt (loan) ==== [[File:Zen-Aintr (2).jpg|thumb|upright|Hector playing for [[Eintracht Frankfurt]] in 2017]] On 14 August 2016, Hector joined German side [[Eintracht Frankfurt]] on a season-long loan, making this his 13th loan in his career.{{Cite news |title=Frankfurt switch for Hector |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2016/08/frankfurt-switch-for-hector.html |publisher=Chelsea F.C. |date=14 August 2016 |accessdate=14 August 2016}} On 21 August 2016, Hector made his debut against [[1. FC Magdeburg]] in the first round of the [[2016–17 DFB-Pokal|DFB-Pokal]]. He was sent-off after receiving a second-yellow in 100th minute; Eintracht Frankfurt went on to advance to the second round after winning 4–3 in the penalty shootout.{{cite web |url=http://www.espnfc.us/match?gameId=452458 |title=1. FC Magdeburg 1–1 Eintracht Frankfurt |date=21 August 2016 |publisher=ESPN FC}} He scored his first Eintracht Frankfurt goal, a stoppage time equaliser against Hertha BSC on 24 September.{{Cite news |url=http://www.espnfc.com/eintracht-frankfurt/match/456855/hometeam-awayteam/report |title=Eintracht Frankfurt 3–3 Hertha Berlin |publisher=ESPN FC |accessdate=1 August 2017}} ==== Hull City (loan) ==== On 27 July 2017, Hector signed a season-long loan deal with [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]].{{cite news |title=Hector Joins on Loan From Chelsea |url=https://www.hullcitytigers.com/news/articles/2017/201718-michael-hector-signing/ |accessdate=27 July 2017 |publisher=Hull City A.F.C. |date=27 July 2017}} He made his debut on the opening day of the season, 5 August 2017, away at [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]], in a 1–1 draw.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/40760772 |title=Aston Villa 1–1 Hull City |date=5 August 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=5 August 2017}} Hector scored his first goal for Hull City on 28 October 2017, with the final goal in a 2–3 defeat at home to [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41703335 |title=Hull City 2–3 Nottingham Forest |date=28 October 2017 |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |accessdate=28 October 2017}} == International career == Hector was called up to the [[Jamaica national football team]] on 27 February 2015 for friendly games against [[Venezuela national football team|Venezuela]] and [[Cuba national football team|Cuba]].{{cite web |title=Four Newcomers For Jamaica's Reggae Boyz Football Squad |url=http://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/sports/20150227/four-newcomers-jamaicas-reggae-boyz-football-squad |publisher=Gleaner (Jamaica) |accessdate=27 February 2015 |date=27 February 2015}} Later that year he was included in their [[2015 Copa América]] squad, having received international clearance to represent them.{{cite web |title=Hector and McCleary gearing up for Messi and Argentina |url=http://www.readingfc.co.uk/news/article/reading-football-club-copa-america-michael-hector-garath-mccleary-2455344.aspx |publisher=Reading F.C. |accessdate=13 May 2015 |date=13 May 2015}} He made his debut on 13 June, playing the full 90 minutes as Jamaica lost 1–0 to holders [[Uruguay national football team|Uruguay]] in their opening [[2015 Copa América Group B|group]] match in [[Antofagasta]].{{cite news |title=Uruguay 1–0 Jamaica: Copa America champions start with a win |url=http://www.goal.com/en/match/uruguay-vs-jamaica/1947887/report?ICID=SP_HN_3 |accessdate=14 June 2015 |publisher=Goal.com |date=13 June 2015}} == Personal life == Hector attended [[Langdon Academy|Langdon School, Newham]]{{citation needed|date=April 2012}} and is the son of former [[Essex County Cricket Club|Essex]] cricketer [[Pat Hector]].
