(football)|Fenerbahçe]] (loan) | caps7 = 6 | goals7 = 2 | nationalyears1 = 2005 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-16 football team|England U16]] | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 2006–2007 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] | nationalcaps2 = 15 | nationalgoals2 = 9 | nationalyears3 = 2008–2009 | nationalteam3 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] | nationalcaps3 = 12 | nationalgoals3 = 2 | nationalyears4 = 2010 | nationalteam4 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps4 = 1 | nationalgoals4 = 0 | nationalyears5 = 2012–2018 | nationalteam5 = [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] | nationalcaps5 = 37 | nationalgoals5 = 12 | club-update = 3 March 2019 }} '''Victor Moses''' (born 12 December 1990) is a Nigerian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] on either flank for [[Süper Lig]] club [[Fenerbahçe S.K. (football)|Fenerbahçe]], on loan from [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]].
Moses began his career in the [[Football League Championship|Championship]] with [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], before his performances caught the eye of [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]], where he made his [[Premier League]] debut in 2010. After two years, his game had improved to the extent that European champions Chelsea were interested, and he signed for them in the summer of 2012. Despite ten goals in all competitions during his first season, he spent his second season on [[loan (sports)|loan]] to [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], his third on loan at [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] and his fourth on loan at [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]].
Born in Nigeria, Moses represented [[England national youth football team|England youth teams]] at [[England national under-16 football team|under-16]], [[England national under-17 football team|under-17]], [[England national under-19 football team|under-19]] and [[England national under-21 football team|under-21]] levels, but opted to play for [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] as opposed to being fully [[cap (sport)|cap]]ped for [[England national football team|England]]. He has gained over 35 caps for Nigeria since his debut in 2012 and played in their winning campaign at the [[2013 Africa Cup of Nations]], as well as the campaign in the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].
==Club career== ===Early life and career=== Moses was born in [[Lagos]], Nigeria,<ref name=Hugman1011/> the son of a Christian pastor. When he was 11, his parents were killed in [[Miss World riots|religious riots]] in [[Kaduna]] when rioters invaded their home. Moses was playing football in the street at the time. A week later, after being hidden by friends, his relatives paid for him to travel to the UK to claim asylum. He was placed with a foster family in South London.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2012/sep/14/victor-moses-interview-chelsea|title=Victor Moses: they should be proud of me, looking down being proud|last=Hytner|first=David|date=2012-09-14|website=the Guardian|language=en|access-date=2018-06-26}}</ref><ref name="MosesAsylum">{{cite news |last= Kelso |first= Paul |date=20 May 2005 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2005/may/20/football.immigration |title=14-year-old asylum seeker becomes school's football hero |newspaper=The Guardian |accessdate=23 July 2008 |location= London}}</ref><ref name="Independent1">{{cite news|title=FA Cup: Orphaned Victor Moses feels very much at home with Chelsea|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/fa-league-cups/fa-cup-orphaned-victor-moses-feels-very-much-at-home-with-chelsea-8527874.html|website=The Independent|accessdate=11 November 2014}}</ref> He attended [[Harris Academy South Norwood|Stanley Technical High School]] (now known as the Harris Academy) in [[South Norwood]]. Scouted playing football in the local Tandridge League for Cosmos 90 FC, [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] approached him, with the club's [[Selhurst Park]] stadium just streets away from his school.<ref name="Independent1"/>
Offered a place in the Eagles' academy, Palace recommended him to the fee-paying [[Whitgift School]] in [[Croydon]], where former [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] and [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] star [[Colin Pates]] was coaching the school football team.<ref name="Independent1"/> Moses first came to prominence at 14 after scoring 50 goals for Palace's under-14s side. Playing for three years at both Whitgift and Palace, Moses scored over 100 goals as well as helping Whitgift win many School Cups, including a National Cup where Moses scored all five goals in the final against [[Healing School]] of [[Grimsby]] at the [[Walkers Stadium]], Leicester.<ref>{{cite web|title=Looking back at when Liverpool and Chelsea ace Victor Moses stunned Healing's dream team |url=http://www.grimsbytelegraph.co.uk/Looking-Liverpool-Chelsea-ace-Victor-Moses/story-20471306-detail/story.html |website=Grimsby Telegraph |accessdate=11 November 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141112012838/http://www.grimsbytelegraph.co.uk/Looking-Liverpool-Chelsea-ace-Victor-Moses/story-20471306-detail/story.html |archivedate=12 November 2014 }}</ref>
===Crystal Palace=== Moses made his first team debut for Palace at the age of 16 on 6 November 2007 in a 1–1 draw with [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]] in the [[EFL Championship|Championship]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Cardiff 1–1 Crystal Palace|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/7076416.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=11 November 2014}}</ref> He kept his place in the side thereafter and scored his first senior goal on 12 March 2008 in a 1–1 draw with [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]].<ref>{{cite news|title=West Brom 1–1 Crystal Palace|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/7287966.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=11 November 2014}}</ref> In total, Moses played 16 times in [[2007–08 Crystal Palace F.C. season|2007–08]] as Palace reached the [[2008 Football League play-offs#Championship|Championship play-offs]] where they lost out to [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Bristol City v C Palace as it happened|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_1/7399418.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=11 November 2014}}</ref> At the end of the season, he signed a new contract at Selhurst Park, much to delight of manager [[Neil Warnock]], who stated, "Victor signing is a huge coup for the club; I've told Victor he could go as high as he wants. He's improving every day and I am delighted that he has signed this deal as he is a player who will go from strength to strength."<ref>{{cite news|title=Moses signs four-year Palace deal|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/crystal_palace/7529661.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=11 November 2014}}</ref>
Moses score twice in 32 appearances in [[2008–09 Crystal Palace F.C. season|2008–09]] as Palace had a disappointing campaign, finishing in 15th position.<ref name=sb0809>{{Soccerbase season|47716|2008|name=Victor Moses|accessdate=7 December 2012}}</ref> In [[2009–10 Crystal Palace F.C. season|2009–10]], Moses went on a run of six goals in eight matches but Palace were suffering huge financial problems and the club went into administration in January 2010.<ref>{{cite news|title=Crystal Palace deducted 10 points|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/crystal_palace/8484824.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=11 November 2014}}</ref>
===Wigan Athletic=== On the final day of January 2010, he completed a £2.5 million transfer to [[Premier League]] side [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]] after Palace went into administration.<ref>{{cite news| date = 31 January 2010| url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/leagues/championship/crystalpalace/7121319/Victor-Moses-joins-Wigan-Athletic-as-Crystal-Palace-fire-sale-begins.html| title = Victor Moses joins Wigan Athletic as Crystal Palace fire sale begins| newspaper = The Daily Telegraph| accessdate = 31 January 2010| location = London| first = Jonathan| last = Liew}}</ref> He made his debut on 6 February 2010 as a substitute against [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] in a 1–1 draw.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/8493730.stm|title=Sunderland 1–1 Wigan|date=6 February 2010|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=1 March 2010}}</ref> On 20 March 2010, Moses came on as a substitute against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] and got his first assist for the club, setting up [[Hugo Rodallega]] for an injury time winner.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wiganlatics.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10429~2001372,00.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612181312/http://www.wiganlatics.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10429~2001372,00.html |archivedate=12 June 2010 |title=Victor-ious |publisher= Wigan Athletic FC|date=22 March 2010 |accessdate=12 October 2013}}</ref> He scored his first goal for Wigan on 3 May 2010 against [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]].<ref>{{cite news| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_prem/8649742.stm| title = Wigan 2–2 Hull| publisher= BBC Sport| date = 3 May 2010| accessdate = 3 May 2010}}</ref>
Moses picked up two injuries at the start of the [[2010–11 in English football|2010–11 season]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clicklancashire.com/my-click/my-real-life/127932-wigan-athletic-winger-victor-moses-wants-tottenham-hotspur-shot.html |title=Wigan Athletic winger Victor Moses wants Tottenham Hotspur shot |work=Click Lancashire |date=26 August 2010 |accessdate=1 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120310202954/http://www.clicklancashire.com/my-click/my-real-life/127932-wigan-athletic-winger-victor-moses-wants-tottenham-hotspur-shot.html |archivedate=10 March 2012 }}</ref> and found it difficult to make it back into the first-team due to increased competition for places. He scored his first league goal of the season on 13 November 2010 in a 1–0 win against West Bromwich Albion.<ref>{{cite news| url = https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/moses-and-nzogbia-lead-wigan-out-of-wilderness-2133596.html| title = Moses and N'Zogbia lead Wigan out of wilderness| date = 14 November 2010| accessdate = 16 November 2010| location = London| newspaper = The Independent| first = Darren| last = Witcoop}}</ref>
Following the departure of winger [[Charles N'Zogbia]], Moses became a regular starter for Wigan in the [[2011–12 in English football|2011–12 season]]. On 10 December 2011, he scored his first goal of the season against West Brom – his first goal since scoring against the same team last season.
===Chelsea=== ====2012–13 season==== [[File:Victor Moses Fabio Santos 2012 FIFA Club World Cup.jpg|thumb|Moses and [[Fábio Santos Romeu|Fábio Santos]] of [[Corinthians Paulista|Corinthians]] in the [[2012 FIFA Club World Cup Final]]]] On 23 August 2012, Wigan accepted a fifth bid from [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] after they finally met Wigan's asking price after four previously unsuccessful bids. The player was given permission to speak with Chelsea.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.wiganlatics.co.uk/news/article/12-08-23-club-statement-victor-moses-331637.aspx |title=Club confirm Victor Moses bid accepted |publisher=Wigan Athletic F.C |date=23 August 2012 |accessdate=23 August 2012}}</ref> On 24 August, Chelsea announced that the transfer of Moses had been completed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2899473 |title=Moses Transfer Completed |publisher=Chelsea F.C |date=24 August 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131028165252/http://www.chelseafc.com/news-article/article/2899473 |archivedate=28 October 2013 }}</ref> Moses played his first game for Chelsea when he appeared as a [[substitute (association football)|substitute]] against [[West London derby#Chelsea vs QPR derby|West London]] rivals [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] on 15 September.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www1.skysports.com/football/live/match/261597/report |title=Anton refuses to shake on it |work=Sky Sports |date=15 September 2012 |accessdate=22 July 2013 }}</ref>
Moses made his full debut for Chelsea when he started the [[Football League Cup#Third round|League Cup]] game against [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] and scored his first goal after 71 minutes in a game that finished 6–0 to the Blues.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/19632463 |title=Chelsea 6–0 Wolves |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 September 2012 |accessdate=29 August 2013}}</ref> Moses started his first [[2012–13 UEFA Champions League group stage#Group E|Champions League]] game against [[FC Nordsjælland|Nordsjælland]]. On 31 October, Moses was named [[Man of the Match]] against [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] in the [[2012–13 Football League Cup|League Cup]], a game Chelsea won 5–4.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.adifferentleague.co.uk/p6_0_17387_chelsea-focus-revenge-is-sweet-in-man-utd-win.html |title=Chelsea Focus – Revenge is sweet in Man Utd win |date=2 November 2012 |accessdate=2 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121104075335/http://www.adifferentleague.co.uk/p6_0_17387_chelsea-focus-revenge-is-sweet-in-man-utd-win.html |archivedate=4 November 2012 }}</ref>
On 3 November 2012, Moses scored his first Premier League goal for Chelsea in the match against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]], which ended in a 1–1 draw.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://espnfc.com/us/en/report/345755/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=5901|title=Swansea 1–1 Chelsea|publisher=ESPN FC|date=3 November 2012 |accessdate=3 November 2012}}</ref> Four days later, he scored his first Champions League goal for Chelsea against [[FC Shakhtar Donetsk|Shakhtar Donetsk]]; Moses replaced [[Oscar (footballer, born 1991)|Oscar]] in the 79th minute and went on to head in [[Juan Mata]]'s corner with seconds left to secure a 3–2 win.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20150427 |title=Chelsea 3–2 Shakhtar Donetsk |date=7 November 2012 |accessdate=7 November 2012 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 5 January 2013, Moses opened his scoring tally for the year with a powerful drive into the bottom corner whilst playing in the [[FA Cup]] Third Round against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]], as Chelsea came from 1–0 behind to beat the Saints 1–5.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20863303 |title=Demba Ba scored twice on his Chelsea debut as the FA Cup holders came from behind against Southampton to ease into the fourth round at St Mary's Stadium. |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 January 2013 |accessdate=22 July 2013 }}</ref>
Moses scored his first [[2012–13 UEFA Europa League|Europa League]] goal for Chelsea in a 3–1 home win against [[FC Rubin Kazan|Rubin Kazan]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/21963641|title=Fernando Torres scored twice to help Chelsea take a huge stride towards the Europa League's last four. |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 April 2013 |accessdate=22 July 2013 }}</ref> and then his second in the reverse fixture a week later.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/22023533 |title=Chelsea sealed their place in the Europa League semi-finals despite a careless second-leg defeat against Rubin Kazan in Russia. |publisher=BBC Sport |date=11 April 2013 |accessdate=22 July 2013 }}</ref> He continued his fine form in the competition by scoring his side's first goal in the 1–2 away win at [[FC Basel|Basel]] on 25 April.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2013/matches/round=2000360/match=2010092/postmatch/report/index.html |title=Last-gasp Luiz strike leaves Chelsea in charge |publisher=UEFA |date=25 April 2013 |accessdate=22 July 2013 }}</ref> He also scored in the reverse match against Basel when the Blues won 3–1 at home and secured their participation in the [[2013 UEFA Europa League Final|Europa League Final]],<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/chelsea/10033915/Chelsea-3–FC-Basle-1-agg-5–2-match-report.html |title=Chelsea 3 FC Basle 1; agg 5–2: match report |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=2 May 2013 |accessdate=22 July 2013 }}</ref> a match in which Moses did not feature but the Blues nonetheless won 2–1 against [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] in [[Amsterdam]] on 15 May.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2013/matches/round=2000361/match=2010095/postmatch/report/index.html |title=Ivanović heads Chelsea to Europa League glory |publisher=UEFA |date=15 May 2013 |accessdate=22 July 2013 }}</ref>
====2013–14 season: Loan to Liverpool==== On 2 September 2013, Moses signed for [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] on a season-long [[loan (sports)|loan]] deal.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/media-watch/sky-sports-moses-deal-completed |title=Moses deal completed |publisher=Liverpool FC |date=2 September 2013 |accessdate=2 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130905103418/http://www.liverpoolfc.com/news/media-watch/sky-sports-moses-deal-completed |archivedate=5 September 2013 }}</ref> He scored on his debut on 16 September against Swansea City in a 2–2 draw.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/24012560|title= Swansea 2 Liverpool 2 |date=16 September 2013|work=BBC Sport|accessdate=27 May 2018}}</ref> On 25 January 2014, he scored the first goal of a 2–0 victory against [[A.F.C. Bournemouth|Bournemouth]] in the fourth round of the [[FA Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Bournemouth 0 – 2 Liverpool|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/25789339|accessdate=7 February 2014|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=25 January 2014}}</ref> Due to the form of [[Raheem Sterling]] during the [[2013–14 Liverpool F.C. season|2013–14]] season, Moses found opportunities hard to come by under [[Brendan Rodgers]], playing 22 games of which only nine were starts.<ref>{{cite news |title=Chelsea fury as Liverpool sideline striker Victor Moses|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/chelsea/10554657/Chelsea-fury-as-Liverpool-sideline-striker-Victor-Moses.html|work=The Daily Telegraph|location=London|accessdate=16 November 2014}}</ref>
====2014–15 season: Loan to Stoke City==== On 16 August 2014, Moses joined [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] on loan for the [[2014–15 Stoke City F.C. season|2014–15]] season.<ref>{{cite web|title=Moses moves to Stoke|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2014/08/moses-moves-to-stoke.html|website=Chelsea F.C|accessdate=16 August 2014}}</ref> He made his Premier League debut for Stoke City on 30 August in a 1–0 win away at [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Man City 0–1 Stoke|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/28907276|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=16 September 2014}}</ref> In Stoke's 1–0 win over [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]] on 29 September, Moses provided the assist for the lone goal scored by [[Peter Crouch]] and was voted [[Man of the Match]] for his performance.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke 1–0 Newcastle|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29305924|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=6 October 2014}}</ref> On 19 October, in a 2–1 win against Swansea City, Moses won a penalty after going down under a challenge from [[Àngel Rangel]]; after the match, Swansea manager [[Garry Monk]] claimed that Moses dived.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke 2–1 Swansea|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29586592|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=14 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Swansea boss Garry Monk criticises 'cheat' Victor Moses|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29682896|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=14 November 2014}}</ref> ''[[Match of the Day 2]]'' pundit [[John Hartson]] also claimed Moses had cheated, but later apologised to Moses for his comments.<ref>{{cite web|title=John Hartson apologises to Stoke's Victor Moses over 'cheat' claims|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29770009|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=14 November 2014}}</ref> Moses scored his first goal for Stoke on 1 November in a 2–2 draw with [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke 2–2 West Ham|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/29768017|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=14 November 2014}}</ref> He suffered a thigh injury against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] on 22 November which ruled him out for eight weeks.<ref>{{cite web|title=Victor Moses: Stoke City striker faces eight weeks out|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/30210377|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=29 November 2014}}</ref> On 17 January 2015, Moses returned to the starting line-up against [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], which ended in a 1–0 win for Stoke.<ref>{{cite web|title=Leicester City vs Stoke City|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2015/01/17/england/premier-league/leicester-city-fc/stoke-city-fc/1703921/|website=Soccerway|date=17 January 2015}}</ref> On 21 February, Moses scored a 90th-minute penalty to earn Stoke a 2–1 victory over Midlands rivals [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] at [[Villa Park]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Aston Villa 1–2 Stoke|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31466727|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=14 April 2015}}</ref> He also scored in a 2–0 victory over [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] on 4 March.<ref>{{cite web|title=Stoke 2–0 Everton|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/31616988|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=14 April 2015}}</ref>
With [[André Schürrle]] and [[Mohamed Salah]] leaving on a permanent basis and on loan, respectively, it was announced that Chelsea manager [[José Mourinho]] attempted to recall Moses back from Stoke mid-season, only for the winger to reject the move back.<ref>{{cite news|title=Victor Moses rejected return to Chelsea|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/chelsea/11486800/Victor-Moses-rejected-return-to-Chelsea.html|work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=20 March 2015}}</ref> Moses suffered a hamstring injury whilst playing against West Ham on 11 April, which ruled him out for the rest of the season.<ref>{{cite web|title=Victor Moses returns to Stamford Bridge with injury|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/chelsea/11535854/Chelsea-news-Victor-Moses-returns-to-Stamford-Bridge-with-injury.html|work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=14 April 2015}}</ref>
====2015–16 season: Loan to West Ham United==== [[File:West Ham United Vs Manchester City (24366292089).jpg|thumb|right|Moses on the ball during his [[loan (sports)|loan]] spell with [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]], playing against [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] in 2016]] After a successful season on loan with Stoke, Moses returned to the Blues and made appearances in all four of the preseason games and scored once, against [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Paris Saint-Germain 1–1 Chelsea |url=http://www.sportsmole.co.uk/football/chelsea/live-commentary/live-commentary-psg-vs-chelsea_235428.html |date=25 July 2015}}</ref> Moses made his first competitive appearance since the return on 2 August 2015 against [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] for the [[2015 FA Community Shield|Community Shield]] when he replaced [[John Terry]] in the 82nd minute. The match ended with Chelsea losing 1–0.<ref>{{cite web|title=FA Community Shield: Arsenal vs Chelsea|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/live/football/33500342 |publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=20 August 2015}}</ref> Moses was also included on the bench during the first game of the season against Swansea City, although he did not make an appearance as Chelsea drew 2–2.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2015/08/08/england/premier-league/chelsea-football-club/swansea-city-afc/2043051/ |title=Chelsea vs. Swansea City 2 – 2 (8/8/15) |date=8 August 2015 |publisher=Soccerway }}</ref>
On 1 September 2015, Moses joined West Ham United on a season-long loan.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Moses signs on loan |url=http://www.whufc.com/News/Articles/2015/September/1-September/Moses-signs-on-loan |publisher=West Ham United |date=1 September 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150902153252/http://www.whufc.com/News/Articles/2015/September/1-September/Moses-signs-on-loan |archivedate=2 September 2015 }}</ref> Before joining West Ham United on loan, Moses signed a new four-year contract, which will keep him at Chelsea until 2019.<ref>{{Cite news |title=New Deal for Moses |url=https://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2015/08/new-deal-for-moses.html |publisher=Chelsea FC |date=1 September 2015}}</ref> Moses made his West Ham debut on 14 September in a 2–0 home win against Newcastle United, where he was named Man of the Match.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34171138 | title=West Ham 2–0 Newcastle United | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=15 September 2015}}</ref> In his second game, on 19 September away against Manchester City, Moses scored his only West Ham goal, in a 1–2 win.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/34191909 | title=Manchester City 1–2 West Ham | publisher=BBC Sport | accessdate=20 September 2015}}</ref> On 5 December, during the match against Manchester United, Moses suffered a hamstring injury that ruled him out until February.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.espnfc.us/west-ham-united/story/2744994/west-ham-forward-victor-moses-to-undergo-scan-on-hamstring | title=West Ham's Victor Moses to undergo scan on hamstring injury | publisher=ESPN | date=7 December 2015}}</ref>
In April, it was revealed that the loan deal also had an option to make the move permanent at the end of the season, but West Ham decided to turn down the option.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11685/10230070/west-ham-to-let-alex-song-victor-moses-and-emmanuel-emenike-leave-8211-sky-sources |title=West Ham to let Alex Song, Victor Moses and Emmanuel Emenike leave – Sky sources |date=4 April 2016 |publisher=SkySports}}</ref>
====2016–17 season==== [[File:Leicester 0 Chelsea 3 (31510599933).jpg|thumb|right|Moses ''(centre)'' with national teammate ''Wilfred Ndidi'' (right) playing for Chelsea against champions [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]], 2017]] After impressing new manager [[Antonio Conte]] during preseason, Moses was included in the first-team squad. On 15 August 2016, Moses played his first league game for Chelsea in three years, coming off the bench for [[Eden Hazard]] against West Ham United in a 2–1 win.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37006707 |title=Chelsea 2–1 West Ham: Costa's late strike earns Conte's first Premier League win|date=15 August 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 23 August, Moses made his first start and scored his first goal since his return, in the Second round of the [[2016–17 EFL Cup|EFL Cup]] against [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]] in a 3–2 victory.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Chelsea 3–2 Bristol Rovers |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37091061 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 August 2016 |accessdate=23 August 2016}}</ref>
After back to back league defeats, Conte converted into a [[Formation (association football)#3–4–3|3–4–3 formation]] with Moses playing as a right-sided [[Rightwingback|wing-back]] in the following match against Hull City. His performance as a wing-back helped Chelsea to a 2–0 victory and also earned him the Man of the Match.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37459840 |title=Hull City 0–2 Chelsea |date=1 October 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 15 October 2016, Moses scored his second league goal of the season against Leicester City in a 3–0 home win.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37594219 |title=Chelsea 3–0 Leicester City|date=15 August 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 26 November 2016, Moses scored the winner in a 2–1 victory against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] and was named the Man of the Match.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/chelsea-vs-tottenham/356457 |title=Chelsea 2–1 Tottenham Hotspur: Blues maintain hold of top spot| publisher=Sky Sports| date=26 September 2016}}</ref> Moses played 40 games in all competitions for Chelsea in the 2016–17 season, scoring four goals.<ref name="sb1617" /> With Chelsea winning the Premier League title, Moses became the Nigerian player with the most Premier League appearances for a title winning team.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pulse.ng/sports/football/chelseas-victor-moses-is-a-premier-league-winner-id6670904.html|title=Chelsea"s Victor Moses is a Premier League winner|first=Steve|last=Dede|accessdate=29 May 2017}}</ref> On 27 May 2017, he played in the [[2017 FA Cup Final]] against Arsenal which Chelsea lost 2–1. Having been booked for a foul on [[Danny Welbeck]] earlier, he was given a second booking, resulting in a red card, after diving in the [[penalty area]]. He became the fifth player to be sent off in an FA Cup final.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dailypost.ng/2017/05/28/fa-cup-final-victor-moses-joins-four-players-hall-shame/|title=FA Cup final: Victor Moses joins four other players in hall of shame|date=28 May 2017|accessdate=29 May 2017}}</ref>
====2017–18 season==== Moses scored the opening goal in the [[2017 FA Community Shield]], which Chelsea lost to [[Arsenal F.C.–Chelsea F.C. rivalry|rivals]] Arsenal on penalties.<ref>{{cite news|title=Arsenal lift Community Shield|date=6 August 2017|accessdate=21 February 2018|work=thefa.com|publisher=The Football Association|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2017/aug/04/fa-community-shield-arsenal-chelsea-report-060817}}</ref>
====2018–19 season: Loan to Fenerbahçe==== In January 2019, Moses signed an eighteen-month loan deal with Turkish side, Fenerbahçe.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46984393|title=Victor Moses: Chelsea winger completes Fenerbahce loan|date=25 January 2019|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=26 January 2019}}</ref> On 1 February 2019, Moses scored his first league goal of the season for Fenerbahce in a 2-0 win against Goztepe S.K. <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.legit.ng/1219383-fenerbahce-2-0-goztepe-victor-moses-scores-turkish-league-goal.html|title=Fenerbahçe 2 - 0 Göztepe: Victor Moses scores first Turkish league goal Read more: https://www.legit.ng/1219383-fenerbahce-2-0-goztepe-victor-moses-scores-turkish-league-goal.html|accessdate=1 February 2019}}</ref>
==International career== ===England=== ====U16 and U17 level==== Despite originally hailing from Lagos, Nigeria, Moses initially chose to represent his adopted home of [[England national football team|England]], featuring for the [[England national under-16 football team|under-16 team]], in which he won the [[Victory Shield]] in 2005, and [[England national under-17 football team|under-17]] level. He travelled with the squad to the [[2007 UEFA European Under-17 Football Championship|2007 UEFA European U-17 Championship]] in Belgium, scoring three times (including the only goal in the semi-final win over [[France national under-17 football team|France]]) to help [[John Peacock (footballer)|John Peacock]]'s side to the competition final, where they were narrowly beaten by a single goal by [[Spain national under-17 football team|Spain]], though Moses managed to finish as the competition's top scorer and collect the Golden Boot for doing so.
That same summer, the squad travelled to [[South Korea]] for the [[2007 FIFA U-17 World Cup|FIFA U-17 World Cup]]. Moses finished as the Young Lions' top scorer, netting three times in the [[2007 FIFA U-17 World Cup#Group B|Group B fixtures]], but sustained an injury in the victory over [[Brazil national under-17 football team|Brazil]] that ruled him out of the competition. Moses' teammates went on to reach the [[2007 FIFA U-17 World Cup#Quarterfinals|quarterfinal stage]].
====U19s==== Following that tournament, Moses was promoted to the [[England national under-18 football team|under-18]] squad, and following his goalscoring exploits for [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]]'s first-team, he was promoted to the [[England national under-19 football team|under-19]] side without appearing sufficiently for the U-18s to actually collect a cap. He went with the U-19s to the [[2008 UEFA European Under-19 Football Championship|2008 UEFA European U-19 Championship]] in the [[Czech Republic]], playing two matches and picking up one assist as the Young Lions failed to make it out of [[2008 UEFA European Under-19 Football Championship#Group B|Group B]]. Speculation grew as manager [[Stuart Pearce]] snubbed him that Moses would return to play for [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] in the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]]—this move never materialised.
====U21s==== Moses was promoted to the under-21 squad at the beginning of the [[2010–11 Premier League|2010–11 season]] and made his debut against [[Uzbekistan national under-21 football team|Uzbekistan]] in a 2–0 win.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://thefa.com/England/mens-under-21s/News/match-centre/2010/EnglandvUzbekistan/Teamsheets?p=ts&mid=102750 |archive-url=https://www.webarchive.org.uk/wayback/archive/20110402053009/http://www.thefa.com/England/mens-under-21s/News/match-centre/2010/EnglandvUzbekistan/Teamsheets?p=ts&mid=102750 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2 April 2011 |title=Teamsheets |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=1 October 2012}}</ref>
===Nigeria=== [[File:Iran and Nigeria match at the FIFA World Cup 2014-06-12 15.jpg|thumb|right|Moses playing for [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] against [[Iran national football team|Iran]] at the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].]] Moses was selected to play for [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] against [[Guatemala national football team|Guatemala]] in February 2011, but the friendly was cancelled.<ref>[http://www.kickoff.com/news/19690/shola-ameobi-victor-moses-get-nigeria-call.php Ameobi, Moses get Nigeria call]. kickoff.com. 14 January 2011.</ref> He then accepted a call-up in March 2011 for Nigeria's games against [[Ethiopia national football team|Ethiopia]] and [[Kenya national football team|Kenya]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/africa/9431866.stm |title=Victor Moses gets late Nigeria call |publisher=BBC Sport |date=24 March 2011 |accessdate=7 December 2012}}</ref> However, he was ruled out of those games because his application to [[FIFA]] to switch nationalities was not received in time. It was announced on 1 November 2011 that FIFA had cleared both Moses and [[Shola Ameobi]] to play for Nigeria.<ref>{{cite news| url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/15524642.stm| title = Fifa clears Shola Ameobi, Moses to play for Nigeria| date = 1 November 2011| publisher = BBC Sport| accessdate = 1 November 2011}}</ref> Moses was called up to Nigeria's 23-man squad for the [[2013 Africa Cup of Nations]], scoring two penalties in their final group stage game against Ethiopia, which Nigeria needed to win to go through. For the second, Ethiopian goalkeeper [[Sisay Bancha]] was given his second booking in the events leading to the penalty and was sent off. Ethiopia had already used all three substitutes so their holding midfielder went in goal, and missed Moses' penalty. The game ended 2–0. Nigeria went on to win the tournament, their third such title. Moses started in the final and played the entire game.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20970786|title=Nations Cup 2013: Nigeria pick six locally-based players|author=Oluwashina Okeleji|date=10 January 2013|accessdate=10 January 2013|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref>
Moses was selected for Nigeria's squad for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup]]<ref>https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/nigeria/10810433/Nigeria-World-Cup-2014-squad.html</ref> and started in their opening group match and the Round of 16 match against [[France national football team|France]] as they lost 2–0.<ref>https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/27969976</ref>
[[File:FWC 2018 - Group D - NGA v ISL - Photo 37.jpg|thumb|left|Moses taking a free kick for [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] during the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].]] Upon [[Gernot Rohr]]'s assumption as Nigeria's head coach in August 2016, Moses featured regularly in the [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification|FIFA 2018 qualifying matches]].<ref>{{cite news| url =http://www.espnfc.com/nigeria/story/2984833/premier-league-duo-victor-moses-odion-ighalo-earn-nigeria-recalls| title= Premier League duo Victor Moses, Odion Ighalo earn Nigeria recalls| date =30 October 2016| publisher = ESPN FC | accessdate = 12 November 2016}}</ref> Moses scored a brace for Nigeria during a [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification|FIFA 2018 qualifying match]] against [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] in November 2016, helping them secure a 3–1 victory.<ref>{{cite news| url =http://metro.co.uk/2016/11/12/chelsea-duo-victor-moses-and-john-obi-mikel-seal-win-for-nigeria-6254332/| title= Chelsea duo Victor Moses and John Obi Mikel seal win for Nigeria| date =12 November 2016| work =Metro|location=UK| accessdate = 12 November 2016}}</ref>
In May 2018 he was named in Nigeria’s preliminary 30 man [[Nigeria national football team|squad]] for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 World Cup]] in [[Russia]], where he got a crucial equalizer against Argentina, though, his side lost the game in the dying minutes to see Argentina through while Nigeria got eliminated.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/amp/news/revealed-every-world-cup-2018-squad-23-man-preliminary-lists/oa0atsduflsv1nsf6oqk576rb|title=Revealed: Every World Cup 2018 squad - 23-man & preliminary lists & when will they be announced? - Goal.com|publisher=}}</ref> After the tournament, it was announced by Moses on 15 August that he has retired from playing for Nigeria at international football.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45200919|title=Victor Moses: Chelsea's Nigeria winger announces international retirement at 27|publisher=BBC Sport|date=15 August 2018|accessdate=15 August 2018}}</ref>
==Personal life== Moses grew up supporting [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Victor Moses: Talentspotter|url=https://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/victor-moses-talentspotter|website=FourFourTwo|accessdate=16 June 2017|date=1 December 2009}}</ref> He has a son, Brentley, (born 2012) and a daughter, Nyah, (born 2015).<ref>{{cite web|title=Victor Moses dedicates brace to his son Brentley|url=http://www.goal.com/en-ng/news/4687/2015-afcon-qualification/2013/01/30/3713255/victor-moses-dedicates-brace-to-his-son-brentley|website=Goal.com|accessdate=16 November 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Congratulations Mr and Mrs Moses|url=http://www.chelsea.vitalfootball.co.uk/article.asp?a=550384|website=Chelsea Vital|accessdate=9 February 2015}}</ref>

(UTC) | nationalteam-update = 20:52, 2 January 2019 (UTC) }} '''Mason Tony Mount''' (born 10 January 1999) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] of the [[EFL Championship|Championship]], on [[Loan (sports)|loan]] from {{English football updater|Chelsea}} club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]. ==Club career== ===Chelsea=== Mount was born in [[Portsmouth]], Hampshire.{{cite news |url=https://www.portsmouth.co.uk/sport/football/portsmouth-born-talent-signs-for-chelsea-1-7161622 |title=Portsmouth-born talent signs for Chelsea |first=Jeff |last=Marshman |newspaper=The News |location=Portsmouth |date=15 January 2016 |accessdate=10 October 2018}} He was playing under-6 football in local leagues as a four-year-old and spent one day a week training in the academies of [[Portsmouth F.C.|Portsmouth]], [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] and [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]].{{cite news |url=https://www.vi.nl/pro/overig/mason-mount-vitesse-pareltje-dat-uitzondering-op-chelsea-regel-moet-worden |title=Mason Mount, Vitesse-pareltje dat uitzondering op Chelsea-regel moet worden |trans-title=Mason Mount, Vitesse gem that should be the exception to Chelsea rule |first=Stef |last=De Bont |website=Voetbal International |date=14 December 2017 |accessdate=10 October 2018 |language=Dutch}} Mount joined Chelsea at the age of six, in 2005.{{citation needed|date=October 2018}} He made his [[Chelsea F.C. Under-23s and Academy|under-18]] debut as an under-15 during the [[2013–14 Chelsea F.C. season|2013–14 season]] and added several more appearances in the [[2014–15 Chelsea F.C. season|following season]].{{citation needed|date=October 2018}} Mount went on to play for both under-18 and under-21 teams during the [[2016–17 Chelsea F.C. season|2016–17 season]], in which he scored 10 goals in 30 appearances.{{citation needed|date=October 2018}} He signed a new four-year contract with Chelsea in July 2017.{{cite web |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2017/07/mount-signs-new-deal-and-heads-to-vitesse.html |title=Mount signs new deal and heads to Vitesse |publisher=Chelsea F.C. |date=24 July 2017 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171007232919/http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2017/07/mount-signs-new-deal-and-heads-to-vitesse.html |archivedate=7 October 2017}} ===Loan to Vitesse=== Mount joined Dutch [[Eredivisie]] club [[SBV Vitesse|Vitesse]] on 24 July 2017 on a season-long [[Loan (sports)|loan]]. He made his first-team debut on 26 August, as a 77th-minute [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] during Vitesse's 2–1 home defeat against [[AZ Alkmaar|AZ]].{{cite web |url=https://uk.soccerway.com/matches/2017/08/26/netherlands/eredivisie/sbv-vitesse/stichting-az/2462357/ |title=Vitesse vs. AZ 1–2 |website=Soccerway |publisher=Perform Group |accessdate=10 October 2018}} The following month, he was given his first start in Vitesse's [[KNVB Cup]] first-round defeat away to fifth-tier team [[AVV Swift|Swift]], playing the full 90 minutes of the 0–0 draw, which Swift won in a [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shoot-out]].{{cite web |url=https://uk.soccerway.com/matches/2017/09/20/netherlands/knvb-beker/swift/sbv-vitesse/2580810/ |title=Swift vs. Vitesse 0–0 |website=Soccerway |publisher=Perform Group |accessdate=10 October 2018}} He scored his first goal for Vitesse on 1 October in the 76th minute of a 1–1 home draw with [[FC Utrecht|Utrecht]].{{cite web |url=https://uk.soccerway.com/matches/2017/10/01/netherlands/eredivisie/sbv-vitesse/stichting-fc-utrecht/2462399/ |title=Vitesse vs. Utrecht 1–1 |website=Soccerway |publisher=Perform Group |accessdate=10 October 2018}} Mount went onto appear in the Eredivisie Team of the Week on several occasions and win the Vitesse Player of the Year award.{{cite web |url=https://weaintgotnohistory.sbnation.com/2018/4/29/17299438/mason-mount-becomes-third-chelsea-loanee-to-win-vitesse-player-of-the-year-award |title=Mason Mount becomes third Chelsea loanee to win Vitesse Player of the Year award |first=Ram |last=Srinivas |website=We Ain't Got No History |publisher=Vox Media |date=29 April 2018 |accessdate=10 October 2018}} During Vitesse's Eredivisie European play-off semi-final first leg against [[ADO Den Haag]] on 9 May 2018, Mount scored his first hat-trick, as Vitesse won 5–2 away. In the second leg, Mount scored in a 2–1 win as Vitesse won 7–3 on aggregate. In the first leg of the final against Utrecht, Mount opened the scoring but was booked and therefore suspended for the second leg. Mount made 39 appearances in all competitions for Vitesse, scoring 14 times, before returning to Chelsea. ===Loan to Derby County=== Mount joined [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] on 17 July 2018 on a season-long loan.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44860172 |title=Derby County sign youngsters Mason Mount and Harry Wilson on loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=17 July 2018 |accessdate=17 July 2018}} He scored a 60th-minute equaliser on his debut for Derby on 3 August 2018, during a 2–1 away victory over [[Reading F.C.|Reading]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44976502 |title=Reading 1–2 Derby County |first=Adam |last=Williams |publisher=BBC Sport |date=3 August 2018 |accessdate=10 October 2018}} ==International career== Mount has represented England at [[England national under-16 football team|under-16]], [[England national under-17 football team|under-17]], [[England national under-18 football team|under-18]] and [[England national under-19 football team|under-19]] levels.{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/england/all-teams/players?p=356955 |title=Mason Mount |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=12 August 2017}}{{dead link|date=October 2018}} Mount represented the under-17s at the [[2016 UEFA European Under-17 Championship]].{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2016/may/04/euro-finals-squad-announced-040516 |title=England under-17s squad named for Euro Championship |first=Nicholas |last=Veevers |publisher=The Football Association |date=4 May 2016 |accessdate=10 October 2018}} Mount was included in the under-19 team for the [[2017 UEFA European Under-19 Championship]].{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2017/jun/26/england-u19-squad-for-euros-260617 |title=Squad for U19 Euro |publisher=The Football Association |date=26 June 2017 |accessdate=10 October 2018}} He provided the assist for [[Lukas Nmecha]] to score the winning goal against [[Portugal national under-19 football team|Portugal]] in the final.{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2017/jul/15/report-2017-uefa-u19-championship-final-portugal-england-150717 |title=Portugal 1–2 England U19s |first=Andy |last=Walker |publisher=The Football Association |date=15 July 2017 |accessdate=10 October 2018}} He was subsequently named [[UEFA European Under-19 Championship#Golden Player Award|Golden Player]] of the tournament.{{cite web |url=https://www.uefa.com/under19/history/season=2017/goldenplayer/index.html |title=2017: Mason Mount |publisher=UEFA |date=25 July 2017 |accessdate=10 October 2018}} Following his impressive season with Vitesse, Mount was invited by manager [[Gareth Southgate]] to train with the [[England national football team|senior team]] for a week ahead of the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].{{cite news |url=https://www.portsmouth.co.uk/sport/football/pompey/portsmouth-born-mount-to-train-with-southgate-s-england-squad-1-8503986 |title=Portsmouth-born Mount to train with Southgate's England squad |first=Will |last=Rooney |newspaper=The News |location=Portsmouth |date=18 May 2018 |accessdate=10 October 2018}} He was called up to the senior team for the [[UEFA Nations League]] matches against [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]] and [[Spain national football team|Spain]] in October 2018.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45744731 |title=James Maddison, Jadon Sancho and Mason Mount named in England squad |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 October 2018 |accessdate=10 October 2018}} ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 1 January 2019}} {| class=wikitable (on loan from [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]) | clubnumber = 45 | youthyears1 = 2005–2013 | youthclubs1 = [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] | youthyears2 = 2013–2016 | youthclubs2 = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] | years1 = 2016– | clubs1 = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] | caps1 = 0 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2016–2017 | clubs2 = → [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] (loan) | caps2 = 24 | goals2 = 4 | years3 = 2017–2018 | clubs3 = → [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] (loan) | caps3 = 4 | goals3 = 0 | years4 = 2018 | clubs4 = → [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] (loan) | caps4 = 15 | goals4 = 2 | years5 = 2018–2019 | clubs5 = → [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] (loan) | caps5 = 14 | goals5 = 1 | years6 = 2019– | clubs6 = → [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] (loan) | caps6 = 1 | goals6 = 1 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-17 football team|England U17]] | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] | nationalyears1 = 2013 | nationalyears2 = 2013 | nationalcaps1 = 3 | nationalcaps2 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2016 | nationalteam3 = [[England national under-20 football team|England U20]] | nationalcaps3 = 2 | nationalgoals3 = 2 | nationalyears4 = 2016– | nationalteam4 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps4 = 6 | nationalgoals4 = 1 | club-update = 21:59, 12 January 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 19:41, 27 March 2018 (UTC) }} '''Kasey Remel Palmer''' (born 9 November 1996) is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] on loan from [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]. He also plays for [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]]s. ==Club career== ===Chelsea=== Palmer joined [[Charlton Athletic F.C.|Charlton Athletic]] at the age of nine, and featured for the club for the majority of his youth career.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-3524622/Kasey-Palmer-impressed-Chelsea-21s-nutmegged-Phil-Jones-youngster-looking-force-way-Guus-Hiddink-s-team-plans.html|title=Kasey Palmer impressed for Chelsea U 21s, but who is the youngster?|website=Mail Online|accessdate=19 April 2016}} Having represented his nation at youth level, Palmer attracted interest from [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] and made the move in March 2013. Due to their academy status, the Blues were able to sign Palmer for only a small compensation fee.{{Cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2306844/Kasey-Palmer-cost-Chelsea-800-000-Charlton-move.html|title=EXCLUSIVE: New-signing Palmer could cost Chelsea £800k after move from Charlton|website=Mail Online|accessdate=19 April 2016}} Making a handful of appearances for the [[Chelsea F.C. Reserves and Academy|Under-18s]] during the remainder of his inaugural season, Palmer became an influential figure in [[Adrian Viveash]]'s side for the 2013–14 while making sporadic appears from the bench for the [[Chelsea F.C. Reserves and Academy|Under-19s]] and [[Chelsea F.C. Reserves and Academy|Under-21s]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/teams/development-squad/under-21s/u21-player-profiles/kasey-palmer.html|title=Kasey Palmer|website=www.chelseafc.com|accessdate=19 April 2016}} His first success came with the Under-21s, when he made appearances in the semi-final and final of the end-of-season playoffs before [[Dermot Drummy]]'s team were named league champions. He later featured as a substitute in every round of the club’s successful [[FA Youth Cup]] campaign while netting twice. He also played in all four [[UEFA Youth League]] knockout ties, while scoring against [[FC Zenit Saint Petersburg|Zenit St Petersburg]] in the second round before the Blues lifted the cup. The 2015–16 season also proved successful for Palmer, who scored three goals in five matches as they retained their crown.{{Cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11668/10248901/paris-saint-german-1-2-chelsea-blues-retain-uefa-youth-league-crown|title=Paris Saint-Germain 1–2 Chelsea: Blues retain UEFA Youth League crown|website=Sky Sports|accessdate=19 April 2016}} Tipped as one of the academy's most promising talents, Palmer signed a new contract in February 2016, which committed his future to the club until the end of the 2018–19 season.{{Cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BBS4DysNLUr/|title=Instagram photo by Kasey Palmer • Feb 2, 2016 at 7:03pm UTC|website=Instagram|accessdate=19 April 2016}} He was given his first taste of senior football under manager [[Guus Hiddink]], being named as an unused substitute against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] in April 2016.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/35949311|title=Swansea City 1–0 Chelsea|last=Stadium|first=Dafydd Pritchard BBC Wales Sport at the Liberty|website=BBC Sport|accessdate=19 April 2016}} ====Loan to Huddersfield Town==== On 15 July 2016, Palmer joined [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] on a season-long [[Loan (sports)|loan]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.htafc.com/news/article/2016-17/huddersfield-town-kasey-palmer-chelsea-signing-transfer-loan-3187038.aspx|title=Chelsea’s Kasey Palmer joins Huddersfield Town on a season-loan Standard Loan|last=Threlfall-Sykes|first=David|accessdate=6 August 2016}} He made his professional debut on 6 August, replacing [[Jack Payne (footballer, born 1994)|Jack Payne]] in the 78th minute of a 2–1 win over [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]]. Palmer scored the winning goal after a minute on the pitch with just his second touch of the ball.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36929750|title=Huddersfield Town 2–1 Brentford|website=BBC Sport|accessdate=6 August 2016}} In the following league game against [[Newcastle United F.C.|Newcastle United]], Palmer once again came off the bench in the second-half, where he went on to set up Payne to score the winner with a through-ball to earn their second straight win.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/36993966 |title=Jack Payne grabbed a late winner as Huddersfield maintained Newcastle's losing start to the new season |date=13 August 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport}} After an extended period out through injury, Palmer returned to action in the Championship play off final as Huddersfield won promotion to the Premier League.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/live/2017/may/29/huddersfield-town-v-reading-championship-play-off-final-live|title=Huddersfield Town v Reading: Championship play-off final – as it happened|first=Barry|last=Glendenning|date=29 May 2017|publisher=|via=The Guardian}} On 3 July 2017, Palmer signed a contract extension with [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] tying him to the club until 2021.{{Cite news |title=Kasey Palmer on Twitter |url=https://twitter.com/kaseypalmer45/status/881958927168090115 |publisher=Kasey Palmer (Twitter) |date=3 July 2017 |accessdate=3 July 2017}} A day later, Palmer's loan spell at [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] was extended for a further season.{{Cite news |title=Loan return for Palmer |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2017/07/loan-return-for-palmer.html |publisher=Chelsea Official Site |date=4 July 2017 |accessdate=4 July 2017}} On 2 January 2018, Palmer announced via [[Twitter]] that he would be leaving Huddersfield following the termination of his loan, after only featuring in five games all season.{{Cite news |title=Kasey Palmer on Twitter |url=https://twitter.com/kaseypalmer45/status/948294545560735745 |publisher=Kasey Palmer (Twitter) |date=2 January 2018 |accessdate=2 January 2018}} ====Loan to Derby County==== On 31 January 2018, Palmer joined Championship side [[Derby County F.C.|Derby County]] on loan for the remainder of the campaign.{{Cite news |title=Palmer loaned to Derby |url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2018/01/palmer-loaned-to-derby.html |publisher=Chelsea Official Site |date=31 January 2018 |accessdate=31 January 2018}} He scored his first goal for Derby in a 2–2 draw against [[Leeds United]] on 21 February 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43053720 |title=Derby 2-2 Leeds |publisher=BBC Sport|date=21 February 2018|accessdate=21 February 2018}} ====Loan to Blackburn Rovers==== On 30 July 2018, Palmer joined Championship side [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] on a season-long loan.{{cite web |title=Kasey Palmer: Blackburn Rovers sign Chelsea forward on loan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45011507 |work=BBC Sport |date=30 July 2018}} ====Loan to Bristol City==== In January 2019 he moved on loan to [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]].https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46811927 In his first game he came off of the bench to score on his debut in a 2-1 win against Bolton Wanderers.https://www.bcfc.co.uk/news/palmer-reflects-on-a-perfect-debut/ ==International career== Palmer made his debut for [[England national under-17 football team|England Under-17s]] on 8 February 2013, playing for seven minutes in a 2–1 defeat to [[Germany national under-17 football team|Germany]]. His second appearance came just two days later, when England suffered another 2–1 defeat, this time to [[Portugal national under-17 football team|Portugal]]. His final appearance for the Under-17s came later that week, when he came off the bench in a 1–0 defeat to the [[Netherlands national under-17 football team|Netherlands]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/under-21/2016/jun/kasey-palmer-toulon-reflections-020616|title=England U21s' Kasey Palmer reflects on dream season with Toulon Tournament title - England {{!}} The FA|last=Association|first=The Football|website=www.thefa.com|accessdate=7 August 2016}} He has also made a single appearance for [[England national under-18 football team|England Under-18s]] on 14 October 2013. Palmer played 73 minutes of a 4–0 win over [[Hungary national under-17 football team|Hungary]], which was his first international match played in his home country.{{Citation|last=England Football Official|title=England U18s vs Hungary 4-0 @ St. George's Park|date=14 October 2013|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=14xKbeb1pxQ|accessdate=7 August 2016}} After impressive displays for his club, Palmer received his first [[England national under-20 football team|Under-20]] call-up two and a half years after his previous international appearance. He played 45 minutes in a 2–1 defeat to [[Canada men's national under-20 soccer team|Canada]] on 27 March 2016, and marked his debut with his nation’s only goal of the game.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2016/mar/match-report-england-u20s-1-2-canada-u20s|title=England Under-20s beaten by Canada in Doncaster|website=www.thefa.com|accessdate=7 August 2016}} In May 2016, Palmer was part of the [[England national under-21 football team|England Under-21]] squad crowned champions of the [[2016 Toulon Tournament]].{{cite web |first=Nicholas |last=Veevers |title=England under-21s lift Toulon title after win over France |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2016/may/29/france-toulon-final-report-280516 |publisher=The Football Association |date=29 May 2016 |accessdate=17 December 2017}} ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 25 August 2018}}{{Soccerway|kasey-palmer/314424|accessdate=2 December 2017}} {| class="wikitable" Excelsior|Excelsior]] (loan) | caps4 = 9 | goals4 = 0 | years5 = 2017– | clubs5 = → [[FK Partizan|Partizan]] (loan) | caps5 = 53 | goals5 = 8 | nationalyears1 = 2012–2013 | nationalteam1 = [[Serbia national under-17 football team|Serbia U17]]Only official [[UEFA]] matches included | nationalcaps1 = 4 | nationalgoals1 = 1 | nationalyears2 = 2013–2015 | nationalteam2 = [[Serbia national under-19 football team|Serbia U19]] | nationalcaps2 = 12 | nationalgoals2 = 2 | nationalyears3 = 2017– | nationalteam3 = [[Serbia national under-21 football team|Serbia U21]] | nationalcaps3 = 11 | nationalgoals3 = 3 | pcupdate = 16 March 2019 | ntupdate = 2 June 2015 }} '''Danilo Pantić''' ({{lang-sr-Cyrl|Данило Пантић}}, {{IPA-sh|danǐlo pǎːntitɕ|pron}}; born 26 October 1996) is a Serbian [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[midfielder]] for [[FK Partizan|Partizan]] on loan from [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]. He has represented [[Serbia national football team|Serbia]] at multiple youth levels. ==Club career== ===Partizan=== Pantić made his debut on 26 May 2013 in a league fixture against [[FK Spartak Subotica|Spartak Subotica]], replacing [[Vladimir Volkov]] in the 70th minute.{{cite news | url=http://www.sr.partizan.rs/64315-64315/ | title=Partizan – Spartak ZV 5:0 (2:0) | language=Serbian | publisher=partizan.rs | date=26 May 2013 | accessdate=26 May 2013}}{{cite news | url=http://www.sr.partizan.rs/65166-nadolaze-mladi-lavovi/ | title=Nadolaze ‘mladi lavovi’ | language=Serbian | publisher=partizan.rs | date=16 June 2013 | accessdate=16 June 2013}} After a disagreement with Partizan over contract extension proposals, he signed a one-and-a-half year contract with Partizan on December 5, 2013.{{cite web|url=http://www.b92.net/sport/fudbal/vesti.php?yyyy=2013&mm=12&dd=05&nav_id=785517|title=Pantić potpisao na godinu i po dana|publisher=B92|language=sr|date=5 December 2013}} [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] had scouted Pantić since early 2014, allegedly monitoring his status due to his short contract.{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraf.rs/sport/1097528-pantic-ne-moze-u-juventus-pre-januara|title=Pantić ne može u Juventus pre januara!|publisher=Telegraf Sport|language=sr|date=2 June 2014}} After hearing about interest from Juventus, Pantić told ''[[Večernje novosti]]'' that he wished to extend his contract with Partizan before leaving Serbia.{{cite web|url=http://www.novosti.rs/vesti/sport.294.html:497761-Pantic-Ne-zanima-me-Juventus-hocu-u-Ligu-sampiona-s-Partizanom|title=Pantić: Ne zanima me Juventus, hoću u Ligu šampiona s Partizanom!|publisher=[[Večernje novosti]]|language=sr|date=25 June 2014}} ===Chelsea=== On 13 July 2015 Pantić signed for [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] for a reported fee of £1.25 million, on a four-year deal and was immediately loaned out to [[Eredivisie]] side [[Vitesse Arnhem]].{{cite web|url=http://www.football-oranje.com/pantic-the-latest-chelsea-player-to-join-vitesse/|title=Pantic the latest Chelsea player to join Vitesse|publisher=Football Oranje|date=13 July 2015|accessdate=13 July 2015}} ====Loan to Vitesse==== He made his Vitesse debut 17 days later in a [[UEFA Europa League]] third qualifying round first leg against [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] at [[St. Mary's Stadium|St. Mary's]], replacing [[Valeri Kazaishvili]] for the final 23 minutes of a 3–0 defeat.{{cite news|last1=Williams|first1=Adam|title=Southampton 3-0 Vitesse|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33667103|accessdate=7 August 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=30 July 2015}} On 9 August 2015, Pantić made his league debut in a 1–1 draw with [[Willem II (football club)|Willem II]], replacing [[Valeri Qazaishvili]] in the 71st minute.{{Cite news |title=Willem II vs. Vitesse |url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2015/08/09/netherlands/eredivisie/sbv-willem-ii-tilburg/sbv-vitesse/2039258/ |publisher=Soccerway |date=9 August 2015}} On 3 March 2016, after being supposedly 'frozen' out of the Vitesse starting eleven, Pantić stated his passion for a return to London: "I want to come back to Chelsea, just to train. Why am I in Vitesse if I am not good enough? I am [going] crazy! I've made no mistake. If I had a chance and blew it, I would keep quiet. Maybe in Vitesse they don't like us [[Serbia|Serbs]]: [[Nemanja Matić]] did not get a chance here either and [[Uroš Đurđević]] played 22 matches in a year and a half."{{Cite news |title=Chelsea loanee Danilo Pantic angry with Vitesse impasse |url=http://weaintgotnohistory.sbnation.com/2016/3/3/11150312/chelsea-loanee-danilo-pantic-angry-with-vitesse-impasse |publisher=David Pasztor (SB Nation) |date=3 March 2016}} Following this interview, Pantić was suspended by first-team manager [[Rob Maas]] indefinitely.{{citation needed|date=September 2016}} ====Loan to Excelsior==== On 12 August 2016, Pantić joined Excelsior on loan for the 2016–17 campaign.{{cite news|url=http://sbvexcelsior.nl/excelsior-rotterdam-huurt-danilo-pantic-van-chelsea/|title=EXCELSIOR ROTTERDAM HUURT DANILO PANTIĆ VAN CHELSEA|date=12 August 2016|work=S.B.V. Excelsior}} On 17 September 2016, Pantić made his debut against [[Willem II (football club)|Willem II]] off the bench coming on after half-time as Excelsior went on to score a late goal to earn a 1–1 draw.{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.us/match?gameId=451111 |title=Willem II Tilburg 1-1 Excelsior |date=17 September 2016 |publisher=ESPN}} In the following match, on 20 September, he made his full debut, playing a full 90 minutes in a 1–0 win over [[BVV Barendrecht]] in the [[2016–17 KNVB Cup|KNVB Cup]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.us/match?gameId=466501 |title=Barendrecht 0-1 Excelsior |date=20 September 2016 |publisher=ESPN}} ====Loan to Partizan==== On 18 June 2017, Pantić returned to his boyhood club, [[FK Partizan|Partizan]] on a season-long loan.{{Cite news |title=Danilo Pantic back in Partizan! |url=http://www.en.partizan.rs/59473-danilo-pantic-back-in-partizan/ |publisher=FK Partizan |date=18 June 2017 |accessdate=20 June 2017}} On 22 July 2017, Pantić scored a goal against [[FK Mačva Šabac|Mačva Šabac]] in first fixture of the [[2017–18 Serbian SuperLiga]] season in a 6–1 home league win.{{cite news|title=Partizan 'šesticom' najavio dolazak Olimpijakosa|url=http://www.b92.net/sport/fudbal/vesti.php?yyyy=2017&mm=07&dd=22&nav_id=1285505|accessdate=24 July 2017|work=[[B92]]|date=22 July 2017|language=Serbian}} On 5 November, Pantić entered in a game as a substitute for [[Marko Janković (footballer, born 1995)|Marko Janković]] in the 72nd minute and with two assists help club to reach a 3–1 away victory over Mačva.{{Cite web | url=https://sport.blic.rs/fudbal/domaci-fudbal/presuda-sa-bele-tacke-partizan-uz-preokret-odneo-ceo-plen-iz-sapca-video/443de3b | title=PRESUDA SA BELE TAČKE Partizan uz preokret odneo ceo plen iz Šapca | language=Serbian | publisher=blic.rs | date=5 November 2017 | accessdate=12 May 2018}} That match is a big turn for Pantić, because after that match he played in first eleven almost every match until the end of the season. On 23 November 2017, he start in a five match of [[2017–18 UEFA Europa League group stage]], against [[BSC Young Boys|Young Boys]], he made one assist and was one of the best Partizan players on that match, where Partizan advanced to the knockout stage after 13 years.{{Cite web | url=http://www.sportskacentrala.com/2017/11/23/partizan-zimuje-u-evropi-video/ | title=Partizan zimuje u Evropi! [VIDEO+FOTO] | language=Serbian | publisher=sportskacentrala.com | date=23 November 2017 | accessdate=26 November 2017}} In second part of the season, Pantić scored a couple a very nice goals and had a couple assist. Due to his consistent performances throughout the season, Pantić was named in the [[Serbian SuperLiga Team of the Season#2017–18|league's best eleven]].{{cite web |url=http://www.superliga.rs/vesti/812-super-liga-odrzana-manifestacija-prvi-tim-priznanja-u-rukama-najboljih|title=Super liga: Održana manifestacija ''Prvi tim'', priznanja u rukama najboljih|website=Serbian SuperLiga official website|language=Serbian|date=14 May 2018|accessdate=16 May 2018}} On 5 July 2018, Pantić's loan at his boyhood club was extended for a further season.{{Cite news|url=https://www.chelseafc.com/en/news/2018/7/5/pantic-in-serbian-loan|title=Pantic in Serbian loan {{!}} Official Site {{!}} Chelsea Football Club|work=ChelseaFC|access-date=2018-07-05}} ==International career== ===Youth=== Pantić has represented Serbia at the [[Serbia national under-17 football team|U17]] and [[Serbia national under-19 football team|U19]] levels.{{citation|url=http://www.uefa.com/under19/season=2014/teams/player=250055213/index.html|title=UEFA u-19 team|publisher=UEFA}} On 10 October 2014, Pantić scored his first and second goal for the U19 side in the opening twenty minutes against [[San Marino national under-19 football team|San Marino U19]] to help Serbia to a 4–0 victory in their opening match of the [[2015 UEFA European Under-19 Championship qualification|2015 UEFA Euro U19 Championship Qualifiers]].{{citation|url=http://www.uefa.com/under19/season=2015/matches/round=2000537/match=2013531/index.html|title=Serbia U19 4-0 San Marino U19|date=10 October 2014}} Pantić has captained at the U19 level, captaining for the first time on 12 October 2014, against [[Armenia national under-19 football team|Armenia U19]] in a [[2015 UEFA European Under-19 Championship qualification|UEFA Euro U19 Championship Qualifier]] match, which ended in a 1–0 victory for the Serbian side. ==Career statistics== {{updated|match played 22 July 2018.{{Soccerway|danilo-panti/270001}}}} {| He began his career at [[HNK Hajduk Split|Hajduk Split]] before moving to [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] for a reported £3 million in 2014. Chelsea loaned him to [[Elche CF|Elche]], [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]], [[A.C. Milan|Milan]], [[FC Spartak Moscow|Spartak Moscow]] and then [[Atalanta B.C.|Atalanta]]. Pašalić made his senior international debut for [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]] in 2014. ==Club career== ===Hajduk Split=== Born in [[Mainz]], Germany, Pašalić moved to Croatia at early age and started playing football at county club NK GOŠK Kaštel Gomilica before joining the [[HNK Hajduk Split|Hajduk Split]]'s youth academy in 2006. A youth international, he first gained wider recognition in the 2011–12 season, scoring 17 goals for the under-17s, despite being a midfielder, and scoring the winner for the under-19s in a 3–2 success against [[NK Hrvatski Dragovoljac|Hrvatski Dragovoljac]], which secured the club's championship trophy. During the pre-season, however, Pašalić was diagnosed with a [[staphylococcus]] infection, being sidelined for the first half of the [[2012–13 Prva HNL|2012–13 campaign]].{{cite news|url=http://www.dalmacijanews.com/Hajduk/View/tabid/88/ID/108416/Novi-pocetak-Junak-titule-Hajdukovih-juniora-Mario-Pasalic-vraca-se-nakon-teske-bolesti.aspx|title=Hajdukovih juniora Mario Pašalić vraća se nakon teške bolesti|last=Duplančić|first=Blaž|date=5 January 2013|work=Dalmacija News|language=Croatian|accessdate=21 April 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130108105325/http://www.dalmacijanews.com/Hajduk/View/tabid/88/ID/108416/Novi-pocetak-Junak-titule-Hajdukovih-juniora-Mario-Pasalic-vraca-se-nakon-teske-bolesti.aspx|archivedate=8 January 2013|df=}} He played his first match as a professional on 14 April 2013 [[Substitute (association football)|replacing]] [[Ivan Vuković]] in the 90th minute of a 2–1 home success against [[HNK Cibalia|Cibalia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.sportcom.hr/sport/nogomet/domaci-nogomet/maxtv-prva-liga/maxtv-prva-liga-hajduk-pobijedio-pogotkom-iz-zale%C4%91a-lokomotiva-postignula-pet-pogodaka-u-nastavku.html|title=Hajduk pobijedio pogotkom iz zaleđa, petarda lokosa|language=Croatian|publisher=SportCom|date=14 April 2013|accessdate=28 July 2014}} In summer 2013, Pašalić signed a four-year professional contract with Hajduk and went on to make 36 appearances in all competitions during the [[2013–14 Prva HNL|2013–14 season]], scoring 11 goals and assisting a further five. On 14 September 2013, he scored two goals in a [[Eternal derby (Croatia)|derby]] 2–0 victory against [[GNK Dinamo Zagreb|Dinamo Zagreb]],{{cite web|url=http://www.hrsport.net/Vijest.aspx?ID=466158|title=Video: Hajduk pobijedio Dinamo na Poljudu, Mario Pašalić junak derbija|language=Croatian|publisher=HRSport|date=14 September 2013|accessdate=28 July 2014}} and repeated the same fate on 8 February the following year, in a 2–1 win at city rivals [[RNK Split]].{{cite web|url=http://www.hrsport.net/Vijest.aspx?ID=470477|title=Video: Mario Pašalić s dva pogotka u samoj završnici donio preokret Hajduku protiv Splita|language=Croatian|publisher=HRSport|date=8 February 2014|accessdate=28 July 2014}} ===Chelsea=== On 9 July 2014, [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] announced the signing of Pašalić for a reported fee of [[Pound sterling|£]]3 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-2606423/Mario-Pasalic-join-Chelsea-Hajduk-Split-3m-deal-forward-expected-sent-loan-Jose-Mourinho.html|title=Mario Pasalic to join Chelsea from Hajduk Split in £3m deal but forward expected to be sent out on loan by Jose Mourinho|publisher=[[Daily Mail]]|date=16 April 2014|accessdate=23 July 2014}} Upon signing, Pašalić said, "I am very happy because I am now a Chelsea player."{{cite news|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2014/07/pasalic-signs.html|title=Pasalic signs|date=9 July 2014|work=Chelsea Official site|accessdate=9 July 2014}} ====Loan to Elche==== On 22 July 2014, Pašalić joined [[Elche CF|Elche]] on a season-long loan deal.{{cite news|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2014/07/spanish-loan-for-pasalic.html|title=Spanish loan for Pasalic|date=22 July 2014|work=Chelsea Official site|accessdate=23 July 2014}} He made his [[La Liga]] debut on 25 August, starting and being [[Penalty card#Yellow card|booked]] in a 0–3 away loss against [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]].{{cite news|url=http://www.espnfc.com/spanish-primera-division/match/402623/barcelona-elche/report|title=Enrique off to a winning start|publisher=[[ESPN FC]]|date=24 August 2014|accessdate=30 April 2015}} On 12 April 2015, Pašalić scored his first goal in [[Spanish football league system|the top flight of Spanish football]], netting the last in a 2–0 win at [[Córdoba CF|Córdoba]].{{cite news|url=http://www.espnfc.com/spanish-primera-division/match/402324/cordoba-elche/report|title=Cordoba 0–2 Elche|publisher=ESPN FC|date=12 April 2015|accessdate=30 April 2015}} On 29 April 2015, Pašalić scored in a 4–0 victory over [[Deportivo de La Coruña]].{{cite news|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2015/04/29/spain/primera-division/elche-club-de-futbol/real-club-deportivo-de-la-coruna/1821995/|title=Elche 4–0 Deportivo de La Coruña|publisher=Soccerway|date=29 April 2015|accessdate=6 July 2015}} On 3 May 2015, he scored a late goal which turned out to be the winner in the match against [[Málaga CF|Málaga]] in a 2–1 victory.{{cite news|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2015/05/03/spain/primera-division/malaga-club-de-futbol/elche-club-de-futbol/1822015/|title=Málaga 1–2 Elche|publisher=Soccerway|date=3 May 2015|accessdate=6 July 2015}} ====Loan to Monaco==== On 3 July 2015, it was announced that Pašalić will spend the [[2015–16 AS Monaco FC season|2015–16 season]] on loan at [[AS Monaco FC|Monaco]].{{cite web|title=Pašalić rejoint l’AS Monaco|url=http://www.asmonaco.com/fr/article/pasalic-rejoint-l-as-monaco-68320.html|publisher=AS Monaco|accessdate=3 July 2015}} Striker [[Radamel Falcao]] went on loan to Chelsea as part of the loan agreement for Pašalić to join the Monégasque side.{{cite news|title=Radamel Falcao: Chelsea sign Monaco striker on loan. So far he has featured in to pre-season games for Monaco F.C.|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33384795 |publisher=BBC Sport (British Broadcasting Corporation)|date=3 July 2015|accessdate=3 July 2015}} During an interview about his loan move to Monaco, Pašalić stated that staying at Chelsea this season was never an option and that he "needs to improve, grow and then hope to get a chance with Chelsea".{{cite news|title=Pasalic: Monaco move can boost my Chelsea chances|url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/news/69/transfer-zone/2015/07/03/13276822/pasalic-monaco-move-can-boost-my-chelsea-chances|publisher=Goal|date=3 July 2015|accessdate=6 July 2015}} On 28 July, Pašalić made his Monaco debut in a 3–1 victory against Swiss side [[BSC Young Boys|Young Boys]] in the [[UEFA Champions League]] third qualifying round, in which he scored the final goal to make it 3–1.{{Cite news|title=UEFA Champions League 2016 - Young Boys-Monaco — UEFA.com|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2016/matches/round=2000632/match=2015626/index.html|publisher=UEFA|date=28 July 2015}} On 8 August, Pašalić made his [[Ligue 1]] debut after playing 25 minutes in a 2–1 win over [[OGC Nice|Nice]].{{Cite web|title=Chelsea here Chelsea there|url=https://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2015/08/chelsea-here-chelsea-there0.html|work=Chelsea Official site|accessdate=10 August 2015}} On 19 August, Pašalić scored against [[Valencia CF|Valencia]], but it was not enough to stop Monaco from losing 3–1 in the first leg of the Champions League play-off.{{Cite news|title=Valencia 3–1 Monaco: Rodrigo & Co. pick apart wasteful visitors|url=http://www.goal.com/en/match/valencia-vs-monaco/2134112/reportl|publisher=Goal|date=19 August 2015}} In the [[2015–16 Coupe de France]], Pašalić scored twice in two appearances.{{Cite web|title = Evian TG vs. Monaco – 20 January 2016 – Soccerway|url = https://int.soccerway.com/matches/2016/01/20/france/coupe-de-france/football-croix-de-savoie-74/association-sportive-monaco-fc/2184009/|website = int.soccerway.com|access-date = 2016-01-20}} ====Loan to Milan==== On 27 August 2016, Pašalić joined [[Serie A]] side [[A.C. Milan|Milan]] on a season-long loan.{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2016/08/pasalic-in-milan-switch.html|title=Pasalic in Milan switch |publisher=Chelsea F.C. |date=27 August 2016}} A month after the loan was completed, there were reports that stated Milan was looking to cut the loan short and return Pašalić in January.{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/ac-milan-planning-cut-short-mario-pasalics-season-long-loan-deal-1583088 |title=AC Milan planning to cut short Mario Pasalic's season-long loan deal |date=25 September 2016 |publisher=IBT}} He made his debut off the substitutes' bench on 30 October 2016 in a 1–0 win against [[Delfino Pescara 1936|Pescara]].http://www.milannews.it/i-tabellini/milan-pescara-1-0-il-tabellino-del-match-234968 In the following game, Pašalić made his first start in a 2–1 win over [[U.S. Città di Palermo|Palermo]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.us/lineups?gameId=461180 |title=Palermo vs Milan |date=6 November 2016 |publisher=ESPN}} Pašalić scored his first goal for Milan in a 2-1 home victory against [[F.C. Crotone|Crotone]].{{cite web|url=http://www.legaseriea.it/it/serie-a-tim/match-report/2016-17/UNICO/UNI/15/MILCRO|title=Stagione 2016–17 | 15^ Giornata|language=Italian|date=4 December 2016|accessdate=4 December 2016}} Pašalić scored the winning penalty in the [[2016 Supercoppa Italiana]] against [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]], bringing Milan its first major trophy since 2011 after the regular match finished in a 1–1 draw (4–5 penalties). On 8 February 2017 Pašalić scored an 89th-minute winner against Bologna in Milan's 1–0 away win. On 2 April Pašalić scored the equalizer in Milan's 1–1 away draw with Pescara. ==== Loan to Spartak Moscow ==== On 2 August 2017, Pašalić signed a new four-year deal with Chelsea and joined [[FC Spartak Moscow|Spartak Moscow]] on loan for the 2017/18 season.{{Cite web|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2017/08/pasalic-in-russian-loan-move.html|title=Pasalic in Russian loan move|website=www.chelseafc.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2017-08-02}} ====Loan to Atalanta==== On 25 July 2018, Pašalić agreed to join [[Italy|Italian]] side [[Atalanta B.C.|Atalanta]] on a season-long loan with an option to purchase at the end of the spell.{{Cite news |title=Pasalic heads to Italy |url=https://www.chelseafc.com/en/news/2018/7/25/pasalic-heads-to-italy |publisher=Chelsea Official Site |date=25 July 2018 |accessdate=25 July 2018}} ==International career== On 14 May 2014, Pašalić was on [[Croatia national football team|Croatia]] manager [[Niko Kovač]]'s 30-man list that was named to participate in [[2014 FIFA World Cup]].{{cite news|last1=Jones|first1=Simon|title=Chelsea make £3m move for Croatia's teenage sensation
