{{Good article}} {{EngvarB|date=December 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2018}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Tammy Abraham | image = Tammy Abraham 20160511.jpg | image_size = 200 | caption = Abraham warming up for [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in 2016 | fullname = Kevin Oghenetega Tamaraebi Bakumo-Abraham{{cite web |url=https://uk.soccerway.com/players/tammy-abrahamm/372977/ |title=T. Abraham: Summary |website=Soccerway |publisher=Perform Group |accessdate=6 August 2018}} | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1997|10|2|df=y}}{{cite web |url=https://www.11v11.com/players/tammy-abraham-252087/ |title=Tammy Abraham |website=11v11.com |publisher=AFS Enterprises |accessdate=11 November 2017}} | birth_place = [[Camberwell]], London, England | height = {{convert|1.90|m|order=flip}} | position = [[Forward (association football)#Striker|Striker]] | currentclub = [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]]
(on loan from [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]) | clubnumber = 18 | youthyears1 = 2004–2016 | youthclubs1 = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] | years1 = 2016– | clubs1 = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] | caps1 = 2 | goals1 = 0 | years2 = 2016–2017 | clubs2 = → [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] (loan) | caps2 = 41 | goals2 = 23 | years3 = 2017–2018 | clubs3 = → [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] (loan) | caps3 = 31 | goals3 = 5 | years4 = 2018– | clubs4 = → [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] (loan) | caps4 = 31 | goals4 = 21 | nationalyears1 = 2014–2015 | nationalteam1 = [[England national under-18 football team|England U18]] | nationalcaps1 = 5 | nationalgoals1 = 2 | nationalyears2 = 2015–2016 | nationalteam2 = [[England national under-19 football team|England U19]] | nationalcaps2 = 14 | nationalgoals2 = 5 | nationalyears3 = 2016– | nationalteam3 = [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] | nationalcaps3 = 22 | nationalgoals3 = 8 | nationalyears4 = 2017– | nationalteam4 = [[England national football team|England]] | nationalcaps4 = 2 | nationalgoals4 = 0 | club-update = 08:12, 14 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 17:56, 9 February 2019 (UTC) }} '''Kevin Oghenetega Tamaraebi Bakumo-Abraham''' (born 2 October 1997), known as '''Tammy Abraham''', is an English professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)#Striker|striker]] for [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] of the [[EFL Championship|Championship]], on [[loan (sports)|loan]] from {{English football updater|Chelsea}} club [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], and the [[England national football team|English national team]]. An academy graduate of Chelsea, Abraham made his senior debut for the club in 2016 before enjoying [[Loan (sports)|loan]] spells with Championship club [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] and fellow [[Premier League]] team [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]]. During his time with the former, he won the club's Player of the Season and Young Player of the Season awards and was their top goalscorer, becoming the first player ever to do so in a single season. Formerly an [[England national youth football team|England youth international]], Abraham represented the nation from [[England national under-18 football team|under-18 level]], and featured at the [[2017 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]] in Poland. He made his senior debut in November 2017. ==Club career== ===Chelsea=== ====Early career==== [[File:Marcin Wasilewski, Tammy Abraham.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Abraham (right) making his home debut for [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] in 2016]] Abraham joined Chelsea at under-8 level and progressed through the club's academy system.{{cite web |url=https://www.chelseafc.com/teams/development-squad/under-21s/u21-player-profiles/tammy-abraham.html |title=Tammy Abraham |publisher=Chelsea F.C. |accessdate=11 May 2016 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160511120030/https://www.chelseafc.com/teams/development-squad/under-21s/u21-player-profiles/tammy-abraham.html |archivedate=11 May 2016}} He was part of the Chelsea youth team which recorded consecutive triumphs in both the [[UEFA Youth League]] and the [[FA Youth Cup]] in 2015 and 2016. In the [[2015–16 UEFA Youth League|2015–16 edition]] of the UEFA Youth League, Abraham pitched in with a return of eight goals in nine matches, making him the tournament's second highest goal scorer behind [[Roberto Núñez Mañas|Roberto Núñez]].{{cite web |url=http://www.uefa.com/uefayouthleague/news/newsid=2354579.html |title=Atlético Madrid's Nuñez takes top scorer honours |publisher=UEFA |date=18 April 2016 |accessdate=11 November 2017}} He carried his form into the FA Youth Cup and netted the winning goal in Chelsea's victory over [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] in the final in April.{{cite news |last=Belshaw |first=George (27 April 2016) |url=http://metro.co.uk/2016/04/27/chelseas-tammy-abraham-scores-brilliant-header-as-blues-bag-third-consecutive-fa-youth-cup-title-v-manchester-city-5846162/ |title=Chelsea's Tammy Abraham scores brilliant header as Blues bag third consecutive FA Youth Cup title v Manchester City |newspaper=Metro |location=London |accessdate=11 May 2016}} During the 2014–15 and 2015–16 seasons, Abraham scored 74 goals in 98 matches across all competitions for Chelsea's various youth teams.{{cite news |last=Kinsella |first=Nizaar (15 May 2016) |url=http://www.goal.com/en-us/news/85/england/2016/05/15/23570252/chelsea-finally-gives-youth-a-chance-but-will-conte-follow |title=Chelsea finally gives youth a chance, but will Conte follow suit? |publisher=Goal.com |accessdate=17 May 2016}} His form at youth level caught the attention of interim [[Manager (association football)|manager]] [[Guus Hiddink]] who invited him to train with the senior team at the back end of the [[2015–16 Premier League|2015–16]] season.{{cite news |last=Deniran-Alleyne |first=Tashan (9 May 2016) |url=http://www.squawka.com/news/tammy-abraham-training-with-chelseas-first-team-report/665894 |title=Tammy Abraham training with Chelsea's first-team – report |website=Squawka |accessdate=12 May 2016}} On 11 May 2016, Hiddink handed Abraham his Chelsea debut in a 1–1 [[Premier League]] draw with [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]], bringing him on to replace [[Bertrand Traoré]] in the 74th minute.{{cite web |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/how-tammy-abraham-capitalised-on-antonio-conte-s-tactical-advice-to-fire-his-way-into-chelsea-s-a3424506.html |title=How Tammy Abraham capitalised on Antonio Conte's tactical advice to fire his way into Chelsea's first team plans |newspaper=London Evening Standard |last=Bhardwaj |first=Vaishali |date=20 December 2016 |accessdate=11 November 2017}} Abraham then made his home debut at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]] the following week, once again coming on as a second-half [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] for Traoré in a 1–1 draw with newly-crowned Premier League Champions [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]]. ====Loan to Bristol City==== [[File:Referee James Linington feels Tammy Abraham's pain (28712920603).jpg|thumb|upright|Abraham (right) playing for [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] in 2016]] On 5 August 2016, Abraham signed for [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City]] on a season-long [[Loan (sports)|loan]] from Chelsea.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/36985799 |title=Tammy Abraham: Bristol City sign Chelsea forward on loan |publisher=BBC Sport |date=5 August 2016 |accessdate=5 August 2016}} He made his debut for the club the following day, coming off the bench for fellow debutant [[Josh Brownhill]] to score City's first goal in a 2–1 come-from-behind win over [[Wigan Athletic F.C.|Wigan Athletic]], although the goal was later credited to [[Hörður Björgvin Magnússon|Hörður Magnússon]] instead.{{cite web |url=http://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2016/09/29/tammy-abraham-three-performances-that-show-why-striker-is-pfa-pl/ |title=Tammy Abraham: Three performances that show why striker is PFA Player of the Month |website=HITC |last=Feehan |first=Katie |date=29 September 2016 |accessdate=2 January 2017}} He started in his second game and scored the only goal of the match in a 1–0 win over [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.|Wycombe Wanderers]], helping Bristol City advance to the Second Round of the [[2016–17 EFL Cup|EFL Cup]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/36949819 |title=Tammy Abraham scored his second goal in two Bristol City games |date=9 August 2016 |accessdate=2 January 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport}} The following week, on 13 August, he scored his first professional brace in a 2–1 victory over newly promoted [[Burton Albion F.C.|Burton Albion]], including the last-minute winner.{{Cite news |title=Burton Albion 1–2 Bristol City |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/36993972 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 August 2016 |accessdate=13 August 2016}} In September, Abraham scored his second brace against [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]], although Bristol City ultimately lost 3–2.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37282509 |title=Sheffield Wednesday 3–2 Bristol City |publisher=BBC Sport |date=13 September 2016 |accessdate=30 September 2016}} He scored a further two goals during the month which saw him named Championship Player of the Month for September.{{cite news |last=Rathborn |first=Jack (29 September 2016) |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/tammy-abraham-wins-championship-player-8938878 |title=Tammy Abraham wins Championship Player of the Month as Bristol City boss jokes over permanent move |newspaper=Daily Mirror |location=London |accessdate=30 September 2016}} He was also awarded the [[EFL Young Player of the Month]] award for September.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37755928 |last=Garry |first=Tom |title=Tammy Abraham: EFL Young Player award for Bristol City's on-loan Chelsea striker |publisher=BBC Sport |date=25 October 2016 |accessdate=25 October 2016}} On 31 January 2017, Abraham scored his 16th Championship goal in a 2–2 draw against Sheffield Wednesday, which saw him break the record of former [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]] striker [[Moussa Dembélé (French footballer)|Moussa Dembélé]] for the most goals scored by a teenager since the beginning of the Football League Championship era.{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-za/news/tammy-abraham-is-the-record-breaking-teenager-the-future-of/wqygm5ptmqhi1dwhcjlqbono2 |title=Tammy Abraham: Is the record-breaking teenager the future of Chelsea? |publisher=Goal.com |date=20 March 2017 |accessdate=11 November 2017}} Abraham ended the season with 23 goals to his name, second only to [[Chris Wood (footballer, born 1991)|Chris Wood]] of [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]], as City completed the campaign in 17th position, thereby avoiding relegation.{{cite news |url=http://metro.co.uk/2017/05/07/bristol-city-fans-gutted-to-see-chelsea-loan-star-tammy-abraham-play-final-game-for-club-6621079/ |title=Bristol City fans gutted to see Chelsea loan star Tammy Abraham play final game for club |newspaper=Metro |location=London |last=Barry |first=Coral |date=7 May 2017 |accessdate=7 May 2017}} His performances throughout the season also earned him Bristol City's Player of the Year, Young Player of the Year and Top Goalscorer awards. In doing so, he became the first ever player to earn all three awards in the same season.{{cite web |url=https://www.bcfc.co.uk/news/abraham-makes-history-with-triple-crown-of-awards/ |title=Abraham makes history with triple crown of awards |publisher=Bristol City F.C. |last=Baker |first=Adam |date=7 May 2017 |accessdate=8 May 2017 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180103233351/https://www.bcfc.co.uk/news/abraham-makes-history-with-triple-crown-of-awards/ |archivedate=3 January 2018}} ====Loan to Swansea City==== [[File:06 Tammy Abraham, Samuel Clucas & Tom Carroll IMG 3741 (24212924278).jpg|thumb|upright|Abraham celebrating a [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] goal in 2017]] On 4 July 2017, Chelsea announced that Abraham had signed a new five-year contract with the club and later that day he joined fellow Premier League club [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] on a season-long loan.{{cite web |url=http://kwese.espn.com/football/story/3150431/chelsea-striker-tammy-abraham-joins-swansea-on-season-long-loan |title=Chelsea striker Tammy Abraham joins Swansea on season-long loan |publisher=ESPN |last=Twomey |first=Liam |date=4 July 2017 |accessdate=4 July 2017}} He made his debut for the club on 12 August, starting in a 0–0 draw with [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]].{{Cite web |url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/swansea-city-team-news-tammy-13467927 |title=Swansea City team news: Tammy Abraham handed full debut at Southampton as Paul Clement opts to leave Roque Mesa on the bench |website=WalesOnline |publisher=Media Wales |last=Gwilym |first=Andrew |date=12 August 2017 |accessdate=12 August 2017}} Ten days later, he scored his first competitive goal in a 4–1 League Cup win over [[EFL League One|League One]] team [[Milton Keynes Dons F.C.|Milton Keynes Dons]] before scoring his first Premier League goal in his next match, opening the scoring in a 2–0 victory over [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].{{cite web |url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/mk-dons-1-swansea-city-13514869 |title=MK Dons 1 Swansea City 4: Leroy Fer at the double and Tammy Abraham opens his account as Swans cruise through in Carabao Cup |website=WalesOnline |publisher=Media Wales |last=Gwilym |first=Andrew |date=22 August 2017 |accessdate=22 August 2017}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/aug/26/crystal-palace-swansea-city-premier-league-match-report |title=Gloom for Crystal Palace after Tammy Abraham inspires Swansea to easy win |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |last=Nakrani |first=Sachin |date=26 August 2017 |accessdate=26 August 2017}} On 14 October 2017, he scored his first brace for his club in a 2–0 win over newly promoted [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] which secured Swansea their first home win of the season.{{cite web |url=https://www.walesonline.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/swansea-city-v-huddersfield-town-13761352 |title=Tammy Abraham's brace gives Swans 2–0 victory in Premier League clash at the Liberty Stadium |website=WalesOnline |publisher=Media Wales |last=Esonu |first=Emmanuel |date=16 October 2017 |accessdate=16 October 2017}} Both club and player struggled for form thereafter, however, and by the end of the year Abraham had failed to add to his goal tally.{{cite web |url=https://www.eurosport.com/football/premier-league/2017-2018/premier-league-preview-manchester-united-take-on-burnley_sto6456844/story.shtml |title=Premier League preview: Who will end 2017 on a high? |website=Eurosport |last=Netherton |first=Alexander |date=29 December 2017 |accessdate=4 January 2018}} On 6 February 2018, having gone 825 minutes without a goal, Abraham returned to the scoresheet when he netted twice and [[Assist (football)|assisted]] a further two in an 8–1 [[FA Cup]] Fourth Round replay win over [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]].{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-za/news/tammy-abraham-delighted-to-be-back-with-the-goals/vpfsb910obuh1ewsmlgb9rblg |title=Tammy Abraham delighted to be 'back with the goals' |website=Goal |last=Olasoji |first=Tolu |date=6 February 2018 |accessdate=7 February 2018}} The result was also Swansea's biggest ever win in the competition.{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/34651/11239534/swansea-8-1-notts-county-hosts-record-biggest-ever-fa-cup-win |title=Swansea 8–1 Notts County: Hosts record biggest-ever FA Cup win |website=SkySports |date=7 February 2018 |accessdate=10 February 2018}} On 7 April, he scored his first league goal since his double in October. His goal earned Swansea a late draw against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Brom]] and edged the club a point closer to safety from the relegation zone, though they were ultimately relegated on the final day of the season following a defeat to [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]].{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/04/07/west-brom-denied-long-awaited-win-late-tammy-abraham-leveller/ |title=West Brom denied long-awaited win by late Tammy Abraham leveller for Swansea |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |last=Culley |first=Jon |date=7 April 2018 |accessdate=7 April 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.si.com/soccer/2018/05/13/swansea-stoke-swans-relegation-confirmed-potters-bow-out-win |title=Swansea Relegation Confirmed as Stoke City Bows Out With Win |date=13 May 2018 |accessdate=13 May 2018}} Abraham scored eight goals in 39 appearances across all competitions during his loan spell with the club.{{soccerbase season|91497|2017|accessdate=12 August 2018}} ====Loan to Aston Villa==== Following Abraham's return from loan at Swansea, new Chelsea manager [[Maurizio Sarri]] indicated that he planned to keep him at Chelsea and included him in the squad for the club's [[FA Community Shield|Community Shield]] defeat to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].{{cite news |url=https://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/1000979/Chelsea-transfer-news-Maurizio-Sarri-Tammy-Abraham-gossip-rumours |title=Chelsea transfer news: Maurizio Sarri makes plan for Blues youngster Tammy Abraham |newspaper=Daily Express |last=Malam |first=Charlie |date=9 August 2018 |accessdate=31 August 2018}} On 31 August, however, Abraham was sent out on loan once again, returning to the Championship to sign for [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] for the remainder of the season.{{cite web |title=Tammy Abraham: Aston Villa sign Chelsea forward on loan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45371400 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=31 August 2018 |date=31 August 2018}} He made his debut for the club on 15 September, starting in a 1–1 draw with [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]], and scored on his home debut four days later in a 2–0 win over [[Rotherham United F.C.|Rotherham United]].{{cite news |url=http://www.goal.com/en-za/news/he-has-done-very-well-steve-bruce-on-tammy-abrahams-aston/n3rpddbem6b911qfs9fhlp5st |title=‘He has done very well’ – Steve Bruce on Tammy Abraham's Aston Villa debut |publisher=Goal |last=Olasoji |first=Tolu |date=16 September 2018 |accessdate=16 September 2018}}{{cite news |url=http://www.goal.com/en-za/news/aston-villa-coach-bruce-hail-abraham-bolasie-after/1rfhu36kxxvn140cjgezr0pxt |title=Aston Villa coach Bruce hail Abraham, Bolasie after goalscoring home debuts |publisher=Goal |last=Olasoji |first=Tolu |date=19 September 2018 |accessdate=20 September 2018}} On 28 November, he scored four goals in a 5–5 draw with [[Nottingham Forest F.C|Nottingham Forest]] in the league; the first time a draw of that score had ever been played out to at [[Villa Park]].{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/nov/28/tammy-abraham-scores-four-as-aston-villa-draw-5-5-with-nottingham-forest |title=Tammy Abraham scores four as Aston Villa draw 5–5 with Nottingham Forest |newspaper=The Guardian |date=28 November 2018 |accessdate=29 November 2018}} In doing so, he became the first Aston Villa player to score four goals in a single match in the 21st century.{{cite news |url=https://www.goal.com/en-za/news/outstanding-tammy-abraham-named-championship-player-of-the/27qgcnwdwjmx1ku2mwjnxpv0s |title=Outstanding Tammy Abraham named Championship Player of the Month |publisher=Goal |last=Taiwo|first=Taiye |date=7 December 2018 |accessdate=29 December 2018}} He was later named Championship Player of the Month for November after scoring six goals in four appearances for the month. By the turn of the year, Abraham had scored 16 goals in 20 appearances and was the joint-top goalscorer in the league. His strong form sparked speculation that he would be recalled by Chelsea, who retained the option until 14 January 2018, given the club's own goal scoring troubles.{{cite news|url=https://www.goal.com/en-za/news/recalling-tammy-abraham-would-confirm-chelsea/1jwwy9i1o3nir1y1tcvge9e95i|title=Recalling Tammy Abraham would confirm Chelsea thoughtlessness|publisher=Goal|last=Omidiora|first=Seye|date=29 December 2018|accessdate=5 January 2019}}{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2019/01/03/chelsea-decide-tammy-abrahams-future-january-14/|title=Chelsea to decide on Tammy Abraham's future by January 14|publisher=The Telegraph|last=Percy|first=John|date=3 January 2019|accessdate=5 January 2019}} It later became apparent that Premier League side [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] had also made an approach for his signature, although [[FIFA]]'s rules prohibiting a player from representing three clubs in a season cast doubt over any potential move.{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/premier-league/wolves-transfer-news-tammy-abraham-latest-chelsea-aston-villa-premier-league-fifa-a8711736.html|title=Wolves remain confident of signing Tammy Abraham from Chelsea despite possible complications|publisher=The Independent|last=Mashiter|first=Nick|date=4 January 2019|accessdate=5 January 2019}} Following a week of media speculation surrounding his future, Abraham rejected a loan move to Wolves in favour of staying with Villa for the remainder of the season.{{cite news|url= https://www.theguardian.com/football/2019/jan/08/tammy-abraham-snubs-wolves-loan-move-stay-aston-villa-transfer-window-football|title=Tammy Abraham snubs Wolves loan to stay and help Villa promotion push|publisher=The Guardian|date=9 January 2019|accessdate=9 January 2019|last=James|first=Stuart}}{{cite news|url=https://www.goal.com/en-za/news/i-felt-here-was-home-tammy-abraham-opens-up-on-aston-villa/1c1f1dnkdwea212yu27si79zxs|title='I felt here was home' - Tammy Abraham opens up on Aston Villa decision|publisher=Goal|last=Taiwo|first=Taiye|date=4 February 2019|accessdate=14 February 2019}} On 26 January, he scored a brace in a 2–1 win over [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich]] and in doing so became the first player since [[Pongo Waring]] in 1933 to score in seven consecutive home games for the club.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/46928848|title=Aston Villa 2–1 Ipswich|publisher=BBC Sport|date=26 January 2019|accessdate=27 January 2019}} The following month, he became the first player since [[Peter Withe]] in 1981 to score 20 goals for the club in a single season when he scored in a 3–3 come–from–behind draw with [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]].{{cite news|url=https://www.goal.com/en-za/news/20-goal-tammy-abraham-backed-to-lead-aston-villas-promotion/1jdom91itsepy1r9iwdjr5bbx4|title=20-goal Tammy Abraham backed to lead Aston Villa’s promotion push|publisher=Goal|last=Taiwo|first=Taiye|date=13 February 2019|accessdate=14 February 2019}} ==International career== Despite being an [[England national youth football team|England youth international]], and having featured in non-competitive fixtures for the senior team, Abraham remains eligible to represent [[Nigeria national football team|Nigeria]] through his paternal lineage and was in the past sounded out by the Nigerian Football Association.{{cite news |last=Emmanuel |first=Ifeanyi (7 July 2016) |url=http://www.allnigeriasoccer.com/read_news.php?nid=19669 |title=Officials Hold Talks With Chelsea Striker Tammy Abraham, Dad Over Playing For Nigeria |website=All Nigeria Soccer |accessdate=28 August 2016}} Abraham's father is close friends with [[Nigeria Football Federation]] President, [[Amaju Pinnick]] and on 21 September 2017, Pinnick claimed that Abraham had switched his allegiance to Nigeria. Abraham issued a statement the same day denying the claim and reaffirming his availability for England selection.{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/sep/21/tammy-abraham-chelsea-nigeria-england-switch |title=Chelsea's Tammy Abraham denies he is set to switch allegiance to Nigeria |newspaper=The Guardian |location=London |last=Aarons |first=Ed |date=21 September 2017 |accessdate=28 September 2017}} Upon receiving his first England call-up in November 2017, Abraham stated that there was never any prospect of him choosing to play for Nigeria.{{cite web |url=http://kwese.espn.com/football/swansea-city/story/3262129/swansea-forward-tammy-abraham-firmly-committed-to-england |title=Swansea forward Tammy Abraham firmly committed to England |publisher=ESPN |last=Miller |first=Nick |date=7 November 2017 |accessdate=10 November 2017}} ===Youth=== Abraham has represented England at both [[England national under-18 football team|under-18]] and [[England national under-19 football team|under-19]] level. He scored his first goals at age group level for England in March 2015, netting a brace as England U18 defeated [[Switzerland national under-18 football team|Switzerland]] 6–1.{{cite web |last=Stonehouse |first=Gary |date=28 March 2015 |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/england/development/2015/mar/tammy-abraham-keep-on-scoring-england-u18s-v-switzerland-280315 |title=Tammy Abraham: 'I've just got to keep on scoring' |publisher=The Football Association |accessdate=12 June 2016}} Later that year, while representing the U19 team in a [[Exhibition game#Association football|friendly]] against [[Japan national under-19 football team|Japan]], Abraham and teammate [[Patrick Roberts]] played a game of [[rock–paper–scissors]] on the pitch to decide who would take a penalty. Abraham was triumphant but missed the resultant spot-kick. Just a minute later, however, Roberts assisted Abraham for the second goal of the match, which ultimately ended 5–1 in England's favour.{{cite news |last=Olver |first=Tom (15 November 2015) |url=http://metro.co.uk/2015/11/15/tammy-abraham-and-patrick-roberts-play-rock-paper-scissors-to-decide-penalty-taker-for-england-under-19s-5503761/ |title=Tammy Abraham and Patrick Roberts play rock, paper, scissors to decide penalty taker for England Under-19s |newspaper=Metro |location=London |accessdate=12 June 2016}} [[File:2017083201737 2017-03-24 Fussball U21 Deutschland vs England - Sven - 1D X - 0230 - DV3P6556 mod.jpg|thumb|left|200px|Abraham playing for [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] in 2017]] On 6 July 2016, Abraham was one of four Chelsea players named in [[Aidy Boothroyd]]'s [[2016 UEFA European Under-19 Championship squads#England|squad]] for the [[UEFA European Under-19 Championship|U19 European Championship]].{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2016/jul/06/under-19s-euro-squad-named-060716 |title=England U19s squad named for Euros Challenge |publisher=The Football Association |last=Veevers |first=Nicholas |date=7 July 2016 |accessdate=12 November 2017}} He featured in three out of four matches as England were eliminated by [[Italy national under-19 football team|Italy]] in the [[semi-final]].{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2016/jul/21/italy-report-210716 |title=England U-19s' Euro dreams ended by Italy in semi-final |publisher=The Football Association |date=21 July 2016 |accessdate=12 November 2017}} Abraham also received his first [[England national under-21 football team|England U21]] call-up on 29 September 2016. He made his first appearance for the team on 6 October, coming on as a substitute with eight minutes remaining against [[Kazakhstan national under-21 football team|Kazakhstan]] in a qualifier for the U21 European Championships to help England to a 1–0 victory which secured the nation's progression to the tournament proper. He made his full debut for the U21s in their final group stage match against [[Bosnia and Herzegovina national under-21 football team|Bosnia and Herzegovina]] and netted twice in a 5–0 victory for England.{{cite web |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/england-u21-vs-bosnia-and-herzegovina-u21/338970 |title=England U21s 5–0 Bosnia-Herzegovina U21s: Tammy Abraham nets brace in convincing win |publisher=Sky Sports |last=Yew |first=Oliver |date=11 October 2016 |accessdate=12 November 2017}} The following year, he was named in the [[2017 UEFA European Under-21 Championship squads#England|England squad]] for the [[2017 UEFA European Under-21 Championship]] in Poland.{{cite web |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2017/jun/05/england-u21s-euro-squad-selected-050617 |title=U21's Euros Squad Selected |publisher=The Football Association |date=5 June 2017 |accessdate=20 June 2017 |last=Veevers |first=Nicholas}} He scored his first, and only goal for the tournament in the semi-final against [[Germany national under-21 football team|Germany]]. England ultimately lost the match after a [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shoot-out]], with Abraham one of the players who missed his spot-kick.{{cite news |url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11668/10934481/tammy-abraham-to-swansea-why-the-chelsea-striker-will-be-a-success |title=Tammy Abraham to Swansea: Why the Chelsea striker will be a success |publisher=Sky Sports |last=Bate |first=Adam |date=4 July 2017 |accessdate=4 July 2017}} On 18 May 2018, having been omitted from [[2018 FIFA World Cup squads#England|England's squad]] for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]], Abraham was recalled to the [[2018 Toulon Tournament squads#England|under-20 side]] for the [[Toulon Tournament]] in France where they had been drawn in a group alongside [[Qatar national under-20 football team|Qatar]], China and [[Mexico national under-20 football team|Mexico]].{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/newsbeat-44154538 |title=How I found out about my England call-up |publisher=BBC |date=17 May 2018 |accessdate=18 May 2018}}{{cite web |publisher=The Football Association |date=18 May 2018 |accessdate=18 May 2018 |title=England U21s head to Maurice Revello Tournament in Toulon with a 20-man squad |url=http://www.thefa.com/news/2018/may/18/england-u21s-squad-named-for-toulon-180518}} On 27 May, England opened their title defence with a 2–1 win over China in which Abraham scored the winning goal.{{cite news |title=Tammy Abraham rescues England in Toulon opener |first=Matt |last=Reed |date=27 May 2018 |accessdate=30 May 2018 |publisher=NBC Sports |url=https://soccer.nbcsports.com/2018/05/27/tammy-abraham-rescues-england-in-toulon-opener/}} He did not feature in the subsequent match against Mexico but returned to score in a 4–0 win over Qatar which saw England qualify for the semi-finals where they were drawn against [[Scotland national under-20 football team|Scotland]].{{cite news |title=Toulon Tournament: England and Mexico play out draw in France |date=29 May 2018 |accessdate=30 May 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44297181}}{{cite news |url=https://bleacherreport.com/articles/2779012-england-fail-to-secure-automatic-toulon-qualification-despite-big-win-over-qatar |title=England Fail to Secure Automatic Toulon Qualification Despite Big Win over Qatar |publisher=Bleacher Report |last=Jones |first=Matt |date=1 June 2018 |accessdate=6 June 2018}}{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2018/06/05/england-u21-manager-says-semi-final-spot-toulon-tournament-minimum/ |title=England U21 manager says semi-final spot at Toulon Tournament is minimum target, but warns against complacency |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |last=Edwards |first=Luke |date=5 June 2018 |accessdate=6 June 2018}} Abraham was only used as a late substitute as England defeated Scotland but was selected to start in the final where they met Mexico. There he was unlucky not to score, hitting the post in the second half, but helped England claim their third successive title with a 2–1 win.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/44426516 |title=Toulon Tournament: England U21s secure third successive title with 2–1 win over Mexico |publisher=BBC |last=O'Keefe |first=Greg |date=9 June 2018 |accessdate=12 June 2018}} ===Senior=== On 2 November 2017, Abraham was one of three uncapped players called up to the senior [[England national football team|England]] team for [[Exhibition game#Association football|friendlies]] against [[Germany national football team|Germany]] and [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]].{{cite web |url=http://kwese.espn.com/football/england/story/3255581/joe-gomez-ruben-loftus-cheek-and-tammy-abraham-get-england-call-ups |title=Joe Gomez, Ruben Loftus-Cheek and Tammy Abraham get England call-ups |publisher=ESPN |date=2 November 2017 |accessdate=2 November 2017}}{{cite web |title=England: Tammy Abraham, Joe Gomez & Ruben Loftus-Cheek called up |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41848591 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=2 November 2017 |date=2 November 2017}} He made his debut against the former on 10 November, starting in a 0–0 draw at [[Wembley Stadium]].{{cite news |first=Phil |last=McNulty |title=England 0–0 Germany |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/41854505 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 November 2017 |accessdate=11 November 2017}} ==Personal life== Abraham was born in [[Camberwell]], London. He has a younger brother, Timmy, who is also a footballer and plays in the academy system at [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]].{{cite news |url=http://www.hitc.com/en-gb/2017/05/25/fulham-sign-chelsea-striker-tammy-abrahams-brother-timmy |title=Timmy Abraham, brother of Chelsea foward [sic] Tammy |newspaper=HITC |location=London |last=Brown |first=Christian |date=25 May 2017 |accessdate=27 August 2017}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.getwestlondon.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/chelsea-stars-younger-brother-joins-13089934 |title=Chelsea star's younger brother joins Fulham after impressing on trial |website=Get West London |last=O'Donovan |first=Ryan |date=25 May 2017 |accessdate=9 August 2017}} In January 2017, Abraham was involved in a motor vehicle accident while on loan at Bristol City. At the time of the accident he was alleged to have been driving without a licence or insurance, and was summoned to court as a result. He later obtained his licence, passing the test in March of the same year.{{cite news |url=http://www.bristolpost.co.uk/news/bristol-news/tammy-abraham-passes-driving-test-10765 |title=Tammy Abraham C.|Crystal Palace]] (on loan from [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]]) | clubnumber = 23 | youthyears1 = 2003–2005 | youthclubs1 = RFC Evere | youthyears2 = 2005–2006 | youthclubs2 = RUSA Schaarbeek | youthyears3 = 2006–2007 | youthclubs3 = [[RWDM Brussels FC|Brussels]] | youthyears4 = 2007–2008 | youthclubs4 = [[RSC Anderlecht|Anderlecht]] | youthyears5 = 2008–2009 | youthclubs5 = [[RWDM Brussels FC|Brussels]] | youthyears6 = 2008–2011 | youthclubs6 = [[Standard Liège]] | years1 = 2011–2014 | clubs1 = [[Standard Liège]] | caps1 = 97 | goals1 = 39 | years2 = 2014–2016 | clubs2 = [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] | caps2 = 62 | goals2 = 26 | years3 = 2016– | clubs3 = [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]] | caps3 = 32 | goals3 = 7 | years4 = 2018 | clubs4 = → [[Borussia Dortmund]] (loan) | caps4 = 10 | goals4 = 7 | years5 = 2018–2019 | clubs5 = → [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] (loan) | caps5 = 15 | goals5 = 1 | years6 = 2019– | clubs6 = → [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] (loan) | caps6 = 6 | goals6 = 2 | nationalyears1 = 2012–2014 | nationalteam1 = [[Belgium national under-21 football team|Belgium U21]] | nationalcaps1 = 13 | nationalgoals1 = 7 | nationalyears2 = 2015– | nationalteam2 = [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] | nationalcaps2 = 23 | nationalgoals2 = 12 | medaltemplates = {{Medal|Sport|Men's [[Association football|football]]}} {{Medal|Country|{{fb|BEL}}}} {{Medal|Comp|[[FIFA World Cup]]}} {{Medal|3rd|[[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 Russia]]|}} | club-update = 19:36, 9 March 2019 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = 14:07, 22 March 2019 (UTC) }} '''Michy Batshuayi-Atunga''' ({{IPA-fr|mi(t)ʃi batʃu.a.(j)i}}; born 2 October 1993) is a Belgian professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Forward (association football)#Striker|striker]] for [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], on loan from [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], and the [[Belgium national football team|Belgium national team]].
He began his professional career at [[Standard Liège]] in 2011, scoring 44 goals in 120 games across all competitions. His 21 goals in the [[2013–14 Belgian Pro League]] made him the second-highest scorer and contributed to his [[Ebony Shoe Award]]. He then transferred to [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] for £4.5 million, helping them reach the [[2016 Coupe de France Final]]. In July 2016, he was signed by Chelsea for £33 million, and scored the goal that won the [[List of English football champions|Premier League title]] in his [[2016–17 Premier League|debut season]].
Batshuayi scored in his international debut for Belgium against [[Cyprus national football team|Cyprus]] in March 2015. He was part of their side that reached the quarter-finals of [[UEFA Euro 2016]] and third place at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]].
==Club career== ===Standard Liège=== [[File:UEFA Euroleague FC Salzburg gegen Standard Lüttich 34.JPG|thumb|left|Batshuayi and [[Frédéric Bulot]] prepare to kick off in a [[UEFA Europa League]] game against [[FC Red Bull Salzburg|Red Bull Salzburg]] in October 2013.]] Born in [[Brussels]], Batshuayi had a nomadic youth career with spells at Evere, Schaarbeek, [[FC Brussels|Brussels]] (twice) and [[R.S.C. Anderlecht|Anderlecht]] before he joined [[Standard Liège]].<ref name=four/>
Batshuayi made his debut for the senior team on 20 February 2011 in a 4–1 loss away to [[KAA Gent|Gent]], replacing [[Franck Berrier]] for the last seven minutes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://soccernet.espn.go.com/match/_/id/312017?cc=3436|title=KAA Gent 4 Liege 1|date=20 February 2011|publisher=ESPN Soccernet|accessdate=2 February 2012}}</ref> Six days later, he made his only other appearance of the [[Belgian Pro League]] [[2010–11 Belgian Pro League|season]], filling in for [[Aloys Nong]] in the last minute of a 3–0 victory against [[KV Mechelen]] at the [[Stade Maurice Dufrasne]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Standard Liege 3–0 KV Mechelen|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/match?gameId=303421|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=29 June 2016}}</ref>
On 21 July, Batshuayi was an unused [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] in the [[2011 Belgian Super Cup]], a 1–0 loss to Gent.<ref>{{cite news|title=Genk edge Standard to win first Super Cup|url=http://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/association=bel/news/newsid=1652485.html|accessdate=29 June 2016|publisher=UEFA|date=21 July 2011}}</ref> On 15 December, he scored his first professional goal, the only one away to [[F.C. Copenhagen|Copenhagen]] in the last match of Group B during the [[2011–12 UEFA Europa League group stage#Group B|2011–12 UEFA Europa League]] group stage, advancing his team into the knockout stages.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuropaleague/season=2012/matches/round=2000272/match=2007411/postmatch/report/index.html|title=Solid Standard march on unbeaten after FCK win|date=15 December 2011|publisher=UEFA|accessdate=2 February 2012}}</ref> Six days later, he added two more in a 2–1 win at [[Lierse S.K.|Lierse]] in the quarter-final first leg of the [[Belgian Cup]], although his side lost 5–4 on aggregate.<ref>{{cite news|title=Standard: Batshuayi l'homme du match, au Lierse|trans-title=Standard:Batshuayi man of the match, at Lierse|url=http://www.sudinfo.be/264344/article/sports/foot-belge/standard/2011-12-22/standard-batshuayi-l%E2%80%99homme-du-match-au-lierse|accessdate=29 June 2016|publisher=Sud Info|date=22 December 2011|language=French}}</ref> He scored his first league goal on 14 January 2012 to round off a 6–1 home win over [[Beerschot A.C.|Germinal Beerschot]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Standard vernedert zwak Beerschot|trans-title=Standard humiliate weak Beerschot|url=http://sporza.be/cm/sporza/voetbal/Jupiler_Pro_League/1.1195302|accessdate=29 June 2016|publisher=Sporza|date=14 January 2012|language=Dutch}}</ref> and ended the campaign with six. He was sent-off as a substitute in a 3–2 loss at Genk on 22 April for stamping on the chest of [[Jeroen Simaeys]], for which the [[Royal Belgian Football Association]] suspended him for four matches.<ref>{{cite news|title=Foot : Michy Batshuayi (Standard) convoqué devant le Comité sportif mardi|trans-title=Football: Michy Batshuayi (Standard) summoned before the Sports Committee on Monday|url=http://www.lesoir.be/59063/article/actualite/fil-info/2012-08-27/foot-michy-batshuayi-standard-convoqu%C3%A9-devant-comit%C3%A9-sportif-mardi|accessdate=29 June 2016|work=Le Soir|date=22 April 2012|language=French}}</ref>
Batshuayi was again sent-off on 25 September 2012 in a 3–2 win at [[Royal Mouscron-Péruwelz|Mouscron]] in the sixth round of the Belgian Cup, having elbowed Benjamin Delacourt within the first half-hour; he was suspended for the next two matches of the competition and fined €200.<ref>{{cite news|title=Le Standard accepte la suspension de Batshuayi|trans-title=Standard accept Batshuayi's suspension|url=http://www.7sur7.be/7s7/fr/1745/Standard/article/detail/1507843/2012/09/27/Le-Standard-accepte-la-suspension-de-Batshuayi.dhtml|accessdate=29 June 2016|publisher=7sur7|date=27 September 2012|language=French}}</ref> In an interview a month later, he said he felt "destroyed" by the suspension.<ref>{{cite news|title=Batshuayi : "C’était très dur pour moi après Mouscron"|trans-title=Batshuayi: "It was very hard for me after Mouscron|url=http://www.dhnet.be/sports/football/division1/standard/batshuayi-c-etait-tres-dur-pour-moi-apres-mouscron-51b74c52e4b0de6db9785a91|accessdate=29 June 2016|publisher=DH|date=2 November 2012|language=French}}</ref> He recorded 12 goals in 26 matches over the campaign, including two on 19 May 2013 to decide a 4–3 home win over [[K.S.C. Lokeren Oost-Vlaanderen|Lokeren]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Batshuayi redt Standard tegen Lokeren|trans-title=Batshuayi saves Standard against Lokeren|url=http://sporza.be/cm/sporza/matchcenter/mc_voetbal/2.22186/MG_SP10_SP_I_en_terugmatch_finale_PO_II/1.1632792|accessdate=29 June 2016|publisher=Sporza|date=19 May 2013|language=Dutch}}</ref>
[[File:Michy Batshuayi 2014.jpg|thumb|right|Batshuayi playing for Standard Liège during a match in March 2014]] In the [[2013–14 Belgian Pro League|2013–14 season]], Batshuayi scored 21 goals in 34 matches, putting him in second place for the league's top scorer behind Lokeren's [[Hamdi Harbaoui]].<ref name=four>{{cite news|title=Michy Batshuayi: The SpongeBob-loving Spurs target tearing up Ligue 1|url=http://www.fourfourtwo.com/features/michy-batshuayi-spongebob-loving-spurs-target-tearing-ligue-1|accessdate=29 June 2016|work=FourFourTwo|date=23 December 2015}}</ref> This tally included a first professional [[hat-trick]] on 15 September in a 4–2 win at [[K.V. Oostende|Oostende]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Batshuayi consolida el liderato del Standard en Bélgica|trans-title=Batshuayi consolidates Standard's lead in Belgium|url=http://futbol.as.com/futbol/2013/09/15/internacional/1379274344_586475.html|accessdate=29 June 2016|work=Diario AS|date=15 September 2013|language=Spanish}}</ref> He was awarded the [[Ebony Shoe Award]] for the season's best player of African origin, ahead of Harbaoui.<ref name=ebony>{{cite news|title=The Belgian Ebony Shoe 2014 goes to Standard Liège’s Michy Batshuayi|url=http://www.benefoot.net/the-belgian-ebony-shoe-2014-goes-to-standard-lieges-michy-batshuayi/|accessdate=29 June 2016|publisher=Benefoot|date=6 May 2014}}</ref>
===Marseille=== On 8 August 2014, Batshuayi signed with French club [[Olympique de Marseille|Marseille]] for a £4.5 million transfer fee.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dhnet.be/sports/football/division1/standard/batshuayi-vers-marseille-53a7a85c3570c0e743403706#.U6dnGeSbi_Q.twitter|title=Batshuayi vers Marseille !|trans-title=Batshuayi to Marseille!|date=23 June 2014|publisher=DHNET|accessdate=23 June 2014|language=French}}</ref><ref name=sky/> He made his debut the next day as Marseille began the [[Ligue 1]] season with a 3–2 win at [[SC Bastia|Bastia]], replacing [[Dimitri Payet]] with 11 minutes remaining. On 29 October, he scored his first goal for the club to open a 2–1 defeat at [[Stade Rennais F.C.|Rennes]] in the third round of the [[Coupe de la Ligue]].<ref>{{cite news|title=L'OM éliminé à l'ultime seconde !|trans-title=OM eliminated in the last second!|url=https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/match/334512|accessdate=29 June 2016|work=L'Equipe|date=19 October 2014|language=French}}</ref> He scored nine league goals for [[Marcelo Bielsa]]'s team, despite rarely starting matches.<ref name=four/> On 22 February 2015, within five minutes of coming on for [[André-Pierre Gignac]], he scored twice away to [[AS Saint-Étienne|Saint-Étienne]] in an eventual 2–2 draw.<ref>{{cite news|title=Match nul à suspense à Geoffroy-Guichard.|trans-title=Suspenseful draw at ''Geoffroy-Guichard''|url=https://www.lequipe.fr/Football/match/316426|accessdate=29 June 2016|work=L'Equipe|date=22 February 2015|language=French}}</ref> In March, he added further braces in away victories at [[Toulouse FC|Toulouse]] and [[RC Lens|Lens]] (6–1 and 4–0 respectively), the latter after taking Gignac's place at half-time.<ref>{{cite news|title=Michy Batshuayi leads rout as Marseille refind form at Toulouse|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/mar/06/toulouse-marseille-ligue-1-match-report|accessdate=29 June 2016|work=The Guardian|date=6 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=BATSHUAYI BAGS BRACE IN MARSEILLE ROMP|url=http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/article/batshuayi-bags-brace-in-marseille-romp.htm|accessdate=29 June 2016|publisher=Ligue 1|date=22 March 2015}}</ref>
On 23 August 2015, Batshuayi scored his first goals of the season, a brace, in a 6–0 victory over [[Troyes AC|Troyes]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Scott|first1=A|title=MICHEL'S MARSEILLE HIT TROYES FOR SIX|url=http://www.ligue1.com/ligue1/article/michel-s-marseille-hit-troyes-for-six.htm|publisher=[[Ligue 1]]|accessdate=27 August 2015|date=23 August 2015}}</ref> Soon after, club president Vincent Lebrune said, "There is not a single top 15 world club that is not interested in Batshuayi. He is one of the most wanted players on the market. There were a lot of offers for him this summer, but he didn't want to leave. He's proving himself on the pitch, and if clubs want him then they are going to have to pay around €50m."<ref name=four/> By the mid-season break, he had 11 goals from 19 matches, behind only [[Le Classique|arch-rival]] [[Paris Saint-Germain F.C.|Paris Saint-Germain]]'s [[Zlatan Ibrahimović]], with Marseille in tenth in the league table and PSG in first.<ref name=four/> Batshuayi finished the league season with 17 goals. He added two more goals from five games in the [[Coupe de France]], one being in [[2016 Coupe de France Final|the final]], where Marseille lost 4–2 to PSG on 21 May 2016.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ibrahimovic nets brace in cup triumph|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/match/olympique-marseille-vs-psg/2215915/report|accessdate=29 June 2016|publisher=Goal.com|date=21 May 2016}}</ref>
===Chelsea=== [[File:Michy Batshuayi v Burnley.jpg|thumb|upright|Batshuayi in action against [[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]] in August 2017]] In April 2016, English [[Premier League]] club [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]] were reported as the favourites to sign Batshuayi, having offered a €35 million bid.<ref name=batsman>{{cite news|last1=Atchinson|first1=Jack|title=Profile of West Ham transfer target Michy Batshuayi of Marseille|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11685/10259822/profile-of-west-ham-transfer-target-michy-batshuayi-of-marseille|accessdate=7 July 2016|publisher=Sky Sports|date=28 June 2016}}</ref> Two months later, their London neighbours [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] made a €38 million (£31.5 million) bid which would have made him their record signing, while Italian champions [[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]] were also among the interested parties.<ref name=sky>{{cite news|last1=Trehan|first1=Dev|title=Michy Batshuayi subject of £31.5m bid from Crystal Palace|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11706/10327157/michy-batshuayi-subject-of-163315m-bid-from-crystal-palace|accessdate=29 June 2016|publisher=Sky Sports|date=28 June 2016}}</ref> Although Palace's bid was accepted, Batshuayi did not want to make the move, instead engaging with a €40 million (£33.2 million) offer from [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], for which he left Belgium's [[UEFA Euro 2016]] squad to undergo a medical.<ref>{{cite news|title=Michy Batshuayi set for Chelsea medical before £33m move from Marseille|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2016/jun/28/michy-batshuayi-chelsea-medical-33m-marseille|accessdate=29 June 2016|work=The Guardian|date=29 June 2016}}</ref> On 3 July, he signed a five-year deal at Chelsea.<ref>{{cite news|title=Batshuayi signs|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2016/07/batshuayi-signs.html?extcmp=SOCIA_TW_ENG_ARTICLES|date=3 July 2016|accessdate=3 July 2016|publisher=Chelsea F.C.}}</ref> He was the first signing by their new manager [[Antonio Conte]], and said his aim was to get the team back to winning the Premier League and qualifying for the [[UEFA Champions League]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Spence|first1=Liam|title=Chelsea new boy Michy Batshuayi opens up about Champions League hopes and Antonio Conte|url=http://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/686719/Chelsea-new-boy-Michy-Batshuayi-opens-up-Champions-League-hopes-Antonio-Conte-Gossip|accessdate=7 July 2016|work=Daily Express|date=6 July 2016}}</ref> Batshuayi added he was eager to work alongside their midfielder [[Oscar (footballer, born 1991)|Oscar]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Cannon|first1=James|title=Michy Batshuayi "can’t wait" to convert Oscar’s assists following Chelsea transfer|url=http://www.squawka.com/news/michy-batshuayi-cant-wait-to-covert-oscars-assists-following-chelsea-transfer/715297|accessdate=7 July 2016|publisher=Squawka|date=3 July 2016}}</ref> Batshuayi joined Chelsea for pre-season in Austria, and on 20 July, he made his debut in a friendly against [[Wolfsberger AC]].<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.goal.com/en/news/1862/premier-league/2016/07/20/25799992/batshuayis-debut-chelseas-bid-for-morata-and-costa-staying-conte- |title= Batshuayi's debut, Chelsea's bid for Morata and Costa staying – Conte wants firepower |publisher= Goal.com |date= 20 July 2016}}</ref> A day later, he scored his first two goals in an 8–0 friendly victory against Atus Ferlach.<ref>{{cite news|title=Blues cruise|url=http://www.chelseafc.com/news/latest-news/2016/07/blues-cruise.html?extcmp=SOCIA_FB_ENG|accessdate=21 July 2016|publisher=Chelsea F.C.|date=21 July 2016}}</ref>
On 15 August, Batshuayi made his competitive debut in Chelsea's opening match of the [[2016–17 Chelsea F.C. season|2016–17 season]], coming off the substitutes' bench to set-up [[Diego Costa]]'s late winner in a 2–1 win over West Ham.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/report?gameId=451007 |title=Diego Costa's late winner helps Chelsea defeat West Ham in opener |date=15 August 2016 |publisher=ESPN}}</ref> Five days later, after replacing Oscar, he went on to score his first Premier League goal in a victory by the same score at [[Watford F.C.|Watford]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37067781 |title=Watford 1–2 Chelsea: Diego Costa scored the winner for the second game |date=20 August 2016 |publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 23 August, Batshuayi made his first start for Chelsea in the [[2016–17 EFL Cup|EFL Cup]], scoring a brace in a 3–2 home victory against [[Bristol Rovers F.C.|Bristol Rovers]].<ref>{{Cite news |title=Chelsea 3–2 Bristol Rovers |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/37091061 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=23 August 2016 |accessdate=23 August 2016}}</ref>
On 12 May, Batshuayi came on as a second-half substitute against [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]] with the score 0–0, with Chelsea needing a victory to clinch the [[2016–17 Premier League|Premier League]] title.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.foxsports.com/soccer/story/chelsea-west-brom-premier-league-title-clinch-video-051217 |title=Chelsea can clinch Premier League title with win at West Brom |work=Fox Sports |author=Sports Illustrated |date=12 May 2017}}</ref> In the 82nd minute, he slotted a goal past goalkeeper [[Ben Foster (footballer)|Ben Foster]] to win Chelsea their fifth Premier League title.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/39813798|title=West Bromwich Albion 0–1 Chelsea|date=12 May 2017|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]}}</ref> Batshuayi went on to score three goals in Chelsea's final two matches, including the last goal of the season in the 92nd minute of Chelsea's 5–1 win over [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] at [[Stamford Bridge (stadium)|Stamford Bridge]]. Batshuayi finished the season with 5 goals in only 236 minutes of Premier League action, equaling a rate of one goal every 47 minutes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/club/chelsea/363/blog/post/3131899/michy-batshuayi-unerring-eye-for-goal-is-earning-young-charge-a-second-chelsea-chance |title=Batshuayi's unerring eye for goal is earning young charge a second chance |publisher=ESPNFC |date=22 May 2017 |accessdate = 23 May 2017 }}</ref>
Batshuayi scored his first Chelsea hat-trick on 20 September 2017 in a 5–1 home win over [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] in the third round of the [[2017–18 EFL Cup|EFL Cup]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Aarons|first1=Ed|title=Batshuayi hits treble and Musonda excels as Chelsea silence Forest|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2017/sep/20/chelsea-nottingham-forest-carabao-cup-match-report|accessdate=27 September 2017|work=The Guardian|date=20 September 2017}}</ref> In a [[2017–18 UEFA Champions League group stage|UEFA Champions League group stage]] match away to [[Atlético Madrid]] a week later, substitute Batshuayi scored the added-time winning goal in a 2–1 victory.<ref>{{cite web|last=Henry|first=Matthew|title=Atletico Madrid 1–2 Chelsea|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/41379696|accessdate=28 September 2017|date=27 September 2017|work=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 17 January 2018, he scored in a third-round [[2017–18 FA Cup|FA Cup]] win over [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] on his 50th appearance for Chelsea. The match finished 1–1 after extra time, with the ''Blues'' going on to win 5–3 on penalties.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.itv.com/news/2018-01-17/fa-cup-9-man-chelsea-beat-norwich-on-penalties|title=FA Cup: 9-man Chelsea beat Norwich on penalties|publisher=ITV News|date=17 January 2018}}</ref>
====Loan to Borussia Dortmund==== On 31 January 2018, Batshuayi joined German [[Bundesliga]] club [[Borussia Dortmund]] on [[loan (sports)|loan]] for the remainder of the [[2017–18 Borussia Dortmund season|2017–18 season]].<ref>{{cite |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42890254 |title=Olivier Giroud: Chelsea sign Arsenal striker as Michy Batshuayi joins Dortmund |publisher=BBC Sport |date=31 January 2018 |accessdate=31 January 2018}}</ref> His debut came on 2 February away to [[1. FC Köln]], where he scored twice and had a third disallowed via the [[video assistant referee]], as he was in an offside position. He also made an assist. The match ended 3–2 to Dortmund as an away victory.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/football/5488740/michy-batshuayi-scoring-borussia-dortmund-debut-loan-chelsea/ |title=Michy Batshuayi scores twice on Borussia Dortmund debut following loan spell from Chelsea |work=The Sun |first=Andrew |last=Richardson |date=2 February 2018}}</ref> Batshuayi became the first player to score multiple goals on his Bundesliga debut since the player he replaced at Dortmund, [[Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.goal.com/en-tza/news/batshuayi-first-bundesliga-striker-to-score-debut-brace/1t0d8azi51vkm1rezug3i89bjf |title=Batshuayi first Bundesliga striker to score debut brace since Aubameyang |work=Goal.com |first=Thomas |last=Floyd |date=2 February 2018}}</ref> The following week, on [[2017–18 Bundesliga|matchday 22]], he again scored the opening goal against [[Hamburger SV]] as Dortmund won 2–0.<ref>{{cite news|title= Gotze, Batshuayi score as Dortmund sink Hamburg|url=http://www.espn.in/football/report?gameId=487066|work=ESPN|date=10 February 2018}}</ref> On 15 February, he scored twice against [[Atalanta B.C.|Atalanta]] in the round of 32 first leg of the [[2017–18 UEFA Europa League knockout phase|UEFA Europa League]] as Dortmund won 3–2 and took the lead going into the second leg.<ref>{{cite news|title="Delighted" Batshuayi is the talk of Dortmund (and London)|first=Nicholas|last=Mendola|date=15 February 2018|accessdate=16 February 2018|url=http://soccer.nbcsports.com/2018/02/15/delighted-batshuayi-is-the-talk-of-dortmund-and-london/|work=soccer.nbcsports.com|publisher=NBC Sports}}</ref> Dortmund's draw in Italy meant the club progressed to the round of 16, although Batshuayi reported hearing "[[Monkey chanting|monkey noises]]" during the match.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chelsea forward Michy Batshuayi accuses Atalanta fans of racism|agency=Associated Press|date=23 February 2018|work=The Guardian|publisher=Guardian Media Group|accessdate=1 March 2018|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/23/chelsea-forward-michy-batshuayi-accuses-atalanta-fans-of-racism|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180301003700/https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/23/chelsea-forward-michy-batshuayi-accuses-atalanta-fans-of-racism|archivedate=1 March 2018|df=}}</ref> In March, [[UEFA]]'s investigation led to both teams being fined for use of pyrotechnics and other crowd disturbances, but Batshuayi's allegations of racism were dismissed. He criticised European football's governing body for their judgement.<ref>{{cite news|title=Michy Batshuayi criticises Uefa for ending investigation into racial abuse claim|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/43588304|accessdate=31 March 2018|publisher=BBC Sport|date=30 March 2018}}</ref> In a 2–0 loss to [[FC Schalke 04|Schalke 04]] on 15 April, Batshuayi injured his ankle ligaments and was ruled out for the remainder of the season.<ref>{{cite web|title=Michy Batshuayi's Dortmund season over, doubt for World Cup with Belgium|url=http://www.espn.com/soccer/borussia-dortmund/story/3458854/belgiums-michy-batsahuayi-doubt-for-world-cup-after-injury-ends-borussia-dortmund-season|publisher=[[ESPN FC]]|date=16 April 2018|accessdate=16 April 2018}}</ref>
====Loan to Valencia==== On 10 August 2018, Batshuayi was loaned to Spanish [[La Liga]] club [[Valencia CF|Valencia]] for the [[2018–19 Valencia CF season|2018–19 season]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Michy Batshuayi: Chelsea striker joins Valencia on a season-long loan |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45148680 |accessdate=10 August 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=10 August 2018}}</ref> Ten days later, he made his Liga debut as a 76th-minute substitute for [[Carlos Soler (footballer)|Carlos Soler]] in a 1–1 home draw with Atlético Madrid, then continued that role in subsequent matches in a side possessing [[Rodrigo (footballer, born 1991)|Rodrigo]], [[Santi Mina]] and [[Kevin Gameiro]] as striking options.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Harbord |first1=Oliver |title=Why Michy Batshuayi is struggling to shake off substitute tag after stuttering start in Spain |url=https://www.football.london/chelsea-fc/players/michy-batshuayi-latest-chelsea-news-15113891 |accessdate=7 September 2018 |publisher=Football London |date=5 September 2018}}</ref> On 26 September, he scored his first goal in a 1–1 draw with [[RC Celta de Vigo|Celta de Vigo]], therefore becoming the first player to score in the top leagues of France, Germany, England and Spain in the 21st century.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Guest |first1=Rob |title=The incredible record Chelsea ace Michy Batshuayi has set after scoring his first Valencia goal |url=https://www.football.london/chelsea-fc/players/michy-batshuayi-chelsea-news-latest-15208990 |accessdate=28 September 2018 |publisher=Football London |date=28 September 2018}}</ref>
====Loan to Crystal Palace==== In January 2019, Batshuayi's loan to Valencia was cut short and he joined English Premier League club [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]] on loan until the end of the 2018–19 season.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cpfc.co.uk/news/2019/february/michy-batshuayi-joins-palace-on-loan/|title=Michy Batshuayi Joins Palace on Loan|website=cpfc.co.uk|date=1 February 2019|accessdate=1 February 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47081617|title=Michy Batshuayi: Crystal Palace sign Chelsea striker on loan until end of season|work=BBC Sport|date=1 February 2019|accessdate=1 February 2019}}</ref> He made his debut on 2 February in a home 2–0 win against [[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]], providing an assist for [[Jeffrey Schlupp]] to score the second goal.<ref>{{cite news|title=Benteke eager to become the new partner for 'Batman'|last=Collings|first=Simon|work=[[Evening Standard]]|location =London|date=4 February 2019|page=59}}</ref> On 23 February, Batshuayi scored his first goal for Crystal Palace in 4–1 win against [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.in/football/report?gameId=513571|website=espn.in|title=Crystal Palace rout Leicester to step up pressure on Puel|date=23 February 2019|accessdate=5 March 2019}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:ENG-BEL (28).jpg|thumb|right|Batshuayi playing for [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]] at the [[2018 FIFA World Cup]]]] Batshuayi was eligible to play for the [[DR Congo national football team|DR Congo national team]] through his parents, but in March 2015, he ruled out this option, stating that although his Congolese heritage is important to him, he would rather represent [[Belgium national football team|Belgium]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.caughtoffside.com/2015/03/05/olympique-marseilles-michy-batshuayi-chooses-belgium-over-dr-congo/|title=Olympique Marseille’s Michy Batshuayi Chooses Belgium Over DR Congo|date=5 March 2015|publisher=Caught Offside|accessdate=7 March 2015}}</ref>
Batshuayi made his international debut for Belgium on 28 March 2015 in a [[UEFA Euro 2016 qualifying]] match against [[Cyprus national football team|Cyprus]]. Replacing [[Christian Benteke]] in the 77th minute, he scored from outside the penalty area three minutes later to seal a 5–0 victory at home.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Scholten|first1=Berend|title=Classy Belgium too strong for Cyprus|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/qualifiers/season=2016/matches/round=2000446/match=2013931/postmatch/report/|accessdate=8 April 2015|publisher=UEFA|date=28 March 2015}}</ref> He was selected for the [[UEFA Euro 2016|final tournament]] in France, making his competition debut in the last 16 against [[Hungary national football team|Hungary]] in [[Toulouse]] on 26 June. With his first touch, he finished [[Eden Hazard]]'s assist for the second goal of a 4–0 victory.<ref name=telegraph>{{cite news|title=Euro 2016: Hungary 0 Belgium 4 – Alderweireld, Hazard, Batshuayi and Carrasco goals set up quarter-final against Wales|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2016/06/26/hungary-v-belgium-euro-2016-live/|accessdate=29 June 2016|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=26 June 2016}}</ref>
In Belgium's [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (UEFA)|2018 FIFA World Cup qualification]], Batshuayi scored once in a 4–3 win away to [[Bosnia and Herzegovina national football team|Bosnia and Herzegovina]] on 7 October 2017, with the ''Red Devils'' already assured of their place in the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|final tournament]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bhardwaj|first1=Vaishali|title=Bosnia-Herzegovina 3 Belgium 4: Vertonghen and Batshuayi on target as Fellaini forced off with knee injury|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/sport/football/bosniaherzegovina-3-belgium-4-vertonghen-and-batshuayi-on-target-as-fellaini-forced-off-with-knee-a3653036.html|accessdate=31 March 2018|work=Evening Standard|date=7 October 2017}}</ref> Manager [[Roberto Martínez]] named him in the 23-man squad to go to Russia.<ref>{{cite news |title=World Cup 2018: Belgium include Vincent Kompany but Christian Benteke misses out |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44353673 |accessdate=23 June 2018 |publisher=BBC Sport |date=4 June 2018}}</ref> In their second group stage match, he came on as a 68th-minute substitute against [[Tunisia national football team|Tunisia]] and missed several chances before finally scoring the fifth goal for Belgium in a 5–2 victory.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Massart |first1=Simon |title=Batshuayi's perseverance pays dividends |url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/batshuayi-perseverance-pays-dividends-2966457 |accessdate=23 June 2018 |publisher=FIFA |date=23 June 2018}}</ref>
==Style of play== A December 2015 profiling by ''[[FourFourTwo]]'' likened Batshuayi for his speed, strength, positioning and link-up play to [[Didier Drogba]], despite being shorter than the Ivorian.<ref name=four/>
==Personal life== Batshuayi is nicknamed "Batsman", a play on the name of the superhero [[Batman]].<ref name=batsman/> His younger brother [[Aaron Leya Iseka]] plays for Toulouse in the same position, coming through at Anderlecht and signing for Marseille on loan, one month after Batshuayi's exit.<ref name=bfm>{{cite news |title=OM : cinq choses à savoir sur Aaron Leya Iseka, le petit frère de Michy Batshuayi|trans-title=OM: five things to know about Aaron Leya Iseka, Michy Batshuayi's little brother |url=https://rmcsport.bfmtv.com/football/om-cinq-choses-a-savoir-sur-aaron-leya-iseka-le-petit-frere-de-michy-1030312.html |accessdate=11 August 2018 |publisher=BFM |date=27 August 2016 |language=French}}</ref>
